 June 2008




2. TRAFFIC ANALYSIS METHODOLOGY
Before discussing traffic operations for the roadway facilities, a thorough understanding of the methodologies
used to develop traffic forecasts and to conduct the traffic analysis is provided.

TRAVEL DEMAND FORECASTING METHODOLOGY
Fehr & Peers examined a number of alternatives for developing travel demand forecasts for this analysis.
Previous studies had concluded that the available travel demand forecasting models were not sensitive enough to
local roadways to accurately predict traffic growth on the relatively small scale required for this analysis.
Therefore, Fehr & Peers reviewed previous studies, available forecasting models, historical traffic counts, and
land use projections to develop forecasts for future traffic conditions.

Background

In March 2004, as part of a separate project, RKH Civil and Transportation Engineering studied this same
segment and determined a growth rate for future traffic based on their own counts (performed in 2000) and
projections from two regional traffic models. Their analysis showed the following:

    ·   A review of traffic counts collected by Caltrans over a 14-year period between 1988 ­ 2002 showed an
        average traffic growth of 0.36% annually on northbound SR 1, south of Linda Mar Boulevard (just south of
        the project study area), and 0.46% annually on northbound SR 1 north of Reina del Mar Avenue.
    ·   The City/County Association of Governments (C/CAG) travel demand forecasting model for San Mateo
        County was not well-enough calibrated in this area to make meaningful traffic forecasts.
    ·   The Metropolitan Transportation Commission (MTC) model projects average traffic growth of 0.5%
        annually between 1998 and 2035.

Based on these findings, the previous analysis recommended use of a 0.5% annual growth factor to project the
background growth for year 2035 conditions traffic volumes along the study corridor. The previous study
recommended adding traffic from individual planned development projects within the City of Pacifica to the
background growth. Caltrans ultimately agreed with and approved this forecasting approach.

Updated Analysis ­ Traffic Growth Projections on SR 1

The RKH analysis was completed in 2004 and based on 2002 traffic volumes. Because conditions may have
changed since then, Fehr & Peers used a similar approach to developing a reasonable growth factor for purposes
of forecasting background traffic growth on SR 1 in Pacifica.

Traffic Counts

The RKH study noted that traffic volumes on northbound SR 1, south of Linda Mar Boulevard were 15,500
vehicles per day in 1988 and 16,300 vehicles per day in 2002, an average annual increase of 0.36% over 14
years. Comparison of 2000 counts with new 2007 traffic counts shows that recent trends are for slightly higher
annual growth. As shown in Table 1, traffic growth between 2000 and 2007 has been generally between 0.50%
and 0.74% annually. This suggests a growth factor of 0.75% annually would provide a conservatively high
estimate of background traffic growth along the study corridor.




                                                                                                              4
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




                                    Table 1: AM Peak Period Traffic Volume Increases


                                                                                       Average
                                            Year 2000      Year 2007        Increase   Annual %
                                                                                        Growth
                           Direction
                        Southbound            2,047             2,125            78     0.50 %
                        Northbound            4,926             5,180            254    0.74 %
                        Total                 6,973             7,305            332    0.68 %


                        Sources: RKH 2004, Fehr & Peers 2007.


C/CAG Model

The RKH study determined that the C/CAG model, designed as a regional traffic forecasting tool, did not offer
meaningful guidance for forecasting traffic on this localized portion of SR 1. However, the C/CAG model has
been updated since the RKH study was performed. Fehr & Peers has prepared a comparison of the newly-
updated C/CAG model to determine how well the model predicts existing traffic volumes and how reasonable the
model's growth forecasts are.

Table 2 presents a comparison of the existing traffic volumes with the C/CAG model forecasts. As shown, the
four-hour peak period model over-predicts actual peak direction travel by approximately fifty percent in the
morning and evening peak periods.




                     Table 2: Comparison of C/CAG Model Volumes with Existing Traffic Counts

                                                                  Model Base Year
                        Direction          Counts (2007)                               % Difference
                                                                      (2005)
                   AM Peak Period
                                                8,109                   12,424           + 53 %
                   Northbound
                   PM Peak Period
                                                8,922                   13,700           + 54 %
                   Southbound


                   Sources: RKH 2004, Fehr & Peers 2007.




Fehr & Peers also compared the model's traffic growth predictions. As shown in Table 3, the C/CAG model
predicts a two percent annual traffic growth in the peak direction over the next 25 years. Similar rates of traffic
growth can be observed in quickly-growing areas, such as urbanizing areas of San Joaquin or Stanislaus
Counties. However, in areas that are already developed, such as San Mateo County, and on facilities that are
already experiencing peak period congestion, it is unlikely that such a high rate of traffic growth can be achieved.



                                                                                                                  5
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




                                    Table 3: C/CAG Model Predicted Traffic Growth

                                                                  Future Year    Average Annual
                        Direction         Base Year (2005)
                                                                    (2035)        Growth Rate
                   AM Peak Period
                                               12,424                18,781             2%
                   Northbound
                   PM Peak Period
                                               13,700                20,768             2%
                   Southbound


                   Sources: RKH 2004, Fehr & Peers 2007.


While useful as a regional travel demand forecasting tool, the C/CAG model does not match existing volumes at
this specific location well, and the traffic growth projected appears to be unrealistically high; therefore, we do not
recommend using the C/CAG model for purposes of this project.

MTC Model

The RKH study presented results from the MTC travel demand forecasting model that supported a growth factor
of 0.5% annually. The MTC model has not substantially changed since these forecasts were developed in 2004.

Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG) Land Use Projections

One element that the RKH study did not examine was regional land use projections, and                whether growth
projections support the use of historical information to produce a future growth rate estimate.      The peak traffic
flows on the study portion of SR 1 are northbound in the morning and southbound in the evening.      This is primarily
due to residential uses to the south and employment in the San Francisco area to the north.          Thus, the major
influence on traffic flows in the study area is the growth in households.

Fehr & Peers reviewed Projections 2007, the latest version of ABAG growth projections to see if the projected
growth in households and jobs in San Mateo County, and more specifically, the coastal areas likely to affect traffic
on SR 1, were consistent with a traffic growth rate of 0.75%. Table 4 shows the 2005 and projected 2035
numbers of households and jobs in San Mateo County, the Coastside Region, and Half Moon Bay.




                                                                                                                    6
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




                            Table 4: Growth in Jobs and Households between 2005 and 2035



                                                                                                        Annual %
          Region               Category          2005            2035       Change       % Change
                                                                                                         Change


                              Households       254,104         312,030      57,926        22.80%         0.76%


  San Mateo County               Jobs          386,590         522,000      135,410       35.03%         1.17%


                                 Total         640,694         834,030      193,336       30.18%         1.01%


                              Households        24,940          28,630       3,690        14.80%         0.49%
  Coastside

  (Half Moon Bay,
                                 Jobs           15,300          18,880       3,580        23.40%         0.78%
  Pacifica, Half Moon Bay
  Unincorporated,
  Remainder)
                                 Total          40,240          47,510       7,270        18.07%         0.60%


                              Households         8,410          10,050       1,640        19.50%         0.65%

  Half Moon Bay +
  Half Moon Bay                  Jobs            7,060          8,400        1,340        18.98%         0.63%
  Unincorporated Only

                                 Total          15,470          18,450       2,980        19.26%         0.64%


  Source: Projections 2007, Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG); and Fehr & Peers, April 2007




Total household growth in San Mateo County overall is expected to occur at an average annual rate of 0.76%,
consistent with the proposed traffic growth rate of 0.75%. While total job growth in San Mateo County is expected
to occur at a faster rate over the next 30 years, most of that growth is expected to occur in the inland areas, closer
to the US 101 corridor, and is not likely to have a substantial effect on traffic volumes on SR 1.

Much of the land uses in San Mateo County that contribute traffic to the subject SR 1 corridor lie in the
"Coastside" subarea of the County, defined by ABAG as the City of Half Moon Bay, the City of Pacifica,
unincorporated areas around Half Moon Bay, and the county "remainder" (i.e., rural, unincorporated areas of the
County not associated with specific cities or towns). Within this area, household growth is expected to occur at
just below 0.5% annually and job growth is expected to occur just above the proposed annual traffic growth rate of
0.75%. Overall, growth in jobs and households in the Coastside region is expected to be 0.6% annually. (Note
that this is an average for general comparison purposes and does not account for the fact that jobs and
households generate traffic at different rates).


                                                                                                                    7
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




The primary urban area that contributes peak traffic to the subject area is the Half Moon Bay region. A focused
analysis of this area shows that both jobs and households are expected to grow at a rate at or just under 0.65%,
annually.

In summary, the growth estimates from Projections 2007 show that the total household growth in San Mateo
County overall, the Coastside subarea, and the City of Half Moon Bay are all expected to occur at an annual rate
consistent with a traffic growth rate of 0.75%.

Updated Analysis - Other Roadways

There are two other primary roadways in the study area: Reina del Mar Avenue and Fassler Avenue. Reina del
Mar Avenue is a small residential street that serves an area that is largely built-out. Therefore, background
growth is not likely on this street.

Fassler Avenue is a slightly more significant street in southern Pacifica that serves primarily residential land uses
to the east of SR 1 and a largely built-out commercial retail development to the west. Because the western side
or SR 1 is largely built out, background growth on Rockaway Beach Avenue is unlikely. However, because of its
somewhat larger role as a collector street serving residential traffic east of SR 1, traffic on the east side of SR 1
could increase due to additional development. Projections 2007 estimates total household growth in the City of
Pacifica to occur at a rate of 0.4 percent annually. This represents a reasonable traffic growth assumption for
Fassler Avenue east of SR 1.

Conclusion

Based on the above information, a growth rate of 0.75% was determined to represent a reasonable and
conservative annual growth rate for background traffic along SR 1, consistent with recent traffic counts, the MTC
model, and projections of future development in coastal San Mateo County. It is unlikely that background traffic
will grow on Reina del Mar or on Rockaway Beach Avenue. Traffic on Fassler Avenue east of SR 1 may have
some background traffic growth because of the larger area it serves and the potential for additional development.
This background growth would likely be similar to the total growth in Pacifica's housing supply, or 0.4 percent
annually.

TRAFFIC OPERATIONS ANALYSIS METHODOLOGY
The traffic operations analysis addressed intersection operations at the two key study intersections (SR 1 / Reina
del Mar Avenue and SR 1 / Fassler Avenue). Key assumptions related to this analysis are listed below:

            ·   All analyses were conducted using procedures and methodologies contained in the Highway
                Capacity Manual (Transportation Research Board, 2000) (HCM 2000). These methodologies
                were applied using VISSIM, a microsimulation software program.

            ·   The HCM 2000 assigns level of service (LOS) based on average control delay. Because VISSIM
                does not measure control delay, total delay will be used instead to determine LOS. This
                conservative approach is recommended in Guidelines for Applying Traffic Microsimulation
                Modeling Software (Caltrans, 2002) since the other components of delay are significantly less
                than control delay.




                                                                                                                   8
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




            ·      A two hour and fifteen minute AM peak period (7:15 to 9:30 AM) and a two hour and forty-five
                   minute PM peak period (4:45 to 7:30 PM) were modeled in VISSIM. The AM peak hour was
                   between 7:30 and 8:30 while the PM peak hour occurred between 5:00 and 6:00 PM. Volumes
                   entered into the simulation were based on peak period traffic counts, subtotaled every fifteen
                   minutes. Similar patterns were assumed for future conditions. All LOS analysis results are for
                   the peak hour.

The analysis methodology described above was used to measure the AM and PM peak hour traffic operations for
the study intersections and study portions of SR 1. The analysis results include a descriptive term known as level
of service (LOS). LOS is a quantitative measure of traffic conditions that varies from LOS A (free-flow) to LOS F
(oversaturated). Table 5 summarizes the relationship between control delay and LOS for signalized intersections.



                            Table 5: Intersection LOS Definitions for Signalized Intersections



                                                                                                        Average
        Level of                                                                                      Control Delay
                                           Description of Traffic Conditions
        Service                                                                                        Per Vehicle
                                                                                                       (Seconds)


                       Insignificant Delays: No approach phase is fully utilized and no vehicle
           A                                                                                              <10
                       waits longer than one red indication.

                       Minimal Delays: An occasional approach phase is fully utilized. Drivers
           B                                                                                             >10-20
                       begin to feel restricted.

                       Acceptable Delays: Major approach phase may become fully utilized.
           C                                                                                             >20-35
                       Most drivers feel somewhat restricted.

                       Tolerable Delays: Drivers may wait through more than one red indication.
           D                                                                                             >35-55
                       Queues may develop but dissipate rapidly, without excessive delays.

                       Significant Delays: Volumes approaching capacity. Vehicles may wait
           E                                                                                             >55-80
                       through several signal cycles and long vehicle queues form upstream.

                       Excessive Delays: Represents conditions at capacity, with extremely long
            F                                                                                             >80
                       delays. Queues may block upstream intersections.


      Source: Highway Capacity Manual, Special Report 209, and Transportation Research Board, 2000.




                                                                                                                      9
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




3.       EXISTING CONDITIONS ANALYSIS
The existing conditions analysis presents the physical and operational characteristics of the roadway, transit,
bicycle, and pedestrian system in the project study area.

PROJECT STUDY AREA
As shown previously in Figure 1, the project study area includes analysis of two study intersections:

     1. SR 1 / Reina del Mar Avenue

     2. SR 1 / Fassler Avenue

DATA COLLECTION
Prior to collection of new traffic counts, Fehr & Peers performed field observations to understand the extent and
duration of existing queuing in the study area. In the AM peak period, northbound queues extend south of
Fassler, and nearly reach Crespi Drive on a typical weekday. This queuing begins and mostly dissipates within
the two-hour peak period from 7 AM to 9 AM. Small queues occasionally linger beyond 9 AM, but all congestion
is cleared by 9:15 AM. Queuing also develops on the westbound approach to SR 1 from Fassler Avenue for a
similar time period. This queuing extends past Roberts Boulevard during its peak, and can reach lengths of up to
½ mile. Another source of AM peak period queuing is on Reina del Mar Avenue. An elementary school just east
of SR 1 results in short-term surges in traffic volumes as parents drop off children. Parents exiting the school
must wait through a long traffic signal cycle on Reina del Mar at SR 1 to enter SR 1. This causes substantial
queuing of sometimes over 1,000 feet on westbound Reina del Mar for short periods near the beginning of the
school day.

In the evening, congestion is primarily on southbound SR 1. While there is congestion on southbound SR 1
between Fassler Avenue and Reina del Mar Avenue, the primary congestion is north of Reina del Mar Avenue.
Southbound queues from this intersection can stretch past Sharp Park Road, for queues of over one mile. Sharp
Park Road also experiences congestion due to relatively high volumes of traffic attempting to enter southbound
SR 1 from Sharp Park Road and the Francisco Boulevard ramps.

Once the extent of congestion was identified, Fehr & Peers selected the appropriate locations for new traffic
counts, which were collected in March 2007. Counts were collected upstream of the congested areas to ensure
that the counts represented all of the traffic demand. Counts consisted of AM and PM peak hour intersection
turning movement counts and peak period freeway mainline traffic counts. Intersection turning movement counts
were collected at the following intersections and are shown on Figure 2:

     ·   SR 1 / Crespi Drive

     ·   SR 1 / Fassler Avenue

     ·   SR 1 / Reina del Mar Avenue

     ·   SR 1 / Westport Street

     ·   SR 1 / Francisco Boulevard Southbound On-Ramp




                                                                                                              10
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




In addition, peak period freeway mainline counts were collected for southbound traffic on SR 1 at the Paloma
Avenue overcrossing.

In summary, traffic counts were collected at locations on SR 1 between Paloma Avenue and Crespi Drive. Since
both Paloma Avenue and Crespi Drive are outside of the congested areas, traffic counts in congested areas were
balanced to these uncongested volumes to develop intersection demand volume estimates. Figure 2 presents
the resulting existing AM and PM peak hour intersection turning movement demand volumes for the two primary
study intersections.

TRANSIT SERVICE
Transit service in Pacifica is provided by the San Mateo County Transit District, known as samTrans. samTrans
operates four bus routes in Pacifica.

    ·   Route CX provides express service along SR1 within the project area, with stops at Crespi Drive, Fassler
        Avenue, and Reina del Mar Avenue. The southern terminus is the Linda del Mar shopping center, while
        the northern terminus is the Colma BART station. Route CX operates with approximately 20 minute
        headways during commute hours, on weekdays only. Fares are $1.50 for adults, $1.00 for youth, and
        $0.75 for seniors and the disabled.

    ·   Route DX provides express service along SR1 within the project area, with stops at Crespi Drive, Fassler
        Avenue, and Reina del Mar Avenue. The southern terminus is the Linda del Mar shopping center, while
        the northern terminus is the Embarcadero BART station in downtown San Francisco. Route DX operates
        with approximately 20 minute headways during commute hours, on weekdays only. Fares are $4.00 for
        adults and $2.00 for youth, seniors and the disabled.

    ·   Route 110 provides local service along SR1 within the project area, with stops at Crespi Drive, Fassler
        Avenue, and Reina del Mar Avenue. The southern terminus is the Linda del Mar shopping center, while
        the northern terminus is the Daly City BART station. Route 110 operates with approximately 30 minute
        headways on weekdays from 8 am to 10 pm; approximately 60 minute headways on Saturdays from 7 am
        to 7:30 pm; and approximately 90 minute headways on Sundays and Holidays from 10 am to 5 pm.
        Fares are $1.50 for adults, $1.00 for youth, and $0.75 for seniors and the disabled.

    ·   Route 16 provides local school service along SR1, Fassler Avenue and Crespi Drive. Operation is limited
        to a few buses school days only, timed for the school day. Fares are $1.50 for adults, $1.00 for youth,
        and $0.75 for seniors and the disabled.

    The San Mateo County Transit District also operates RediCoast, a paratransit service. Riders are required to
    plan their trip at least one day in advance.

PEDESTRIAN FACILITIES
Pedestrian facilities include sidewalks, crosswalks, and pedestrian signals. North of Reina del Mar Avenue, there
is a sidewalk on the west side of the road; between Reina del Mar Avenue and Fassler Avenue, the sidewalk is on
the east side of the road. South of Fassler Avenue, there is a sidewalk on the west side of the road.. West of the
project site are popular recreational trails providing waterfront access.



Crosswalks with pedestrian signals are installed at Crespi Drive, Reina del Mar Avenue and Fassler Avenue.



                                                                                                               11
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




BICYCLE FACILITIES
There is a Class II Bicycle Lane on both sides of SR1 from Crespi Drive to Fassler Avenue. The remainder of
SR1 is a Class III Bicycle Route, with a shoulder that accommodates bicycles. According to the San Mateo
County Comprehensive Bicycle Route Plan, these shoulders are anticipated to be striped as Class II Bicycle
Lanes.

Bicycles are also permitted to ride on the recreational trails west of the project site.

TRAFFIC OPERATIONS MODEL DEVELOPMENT
The VISSIM model was constructed over an aerial photo of the project area to ensure that roadways and
locations of intersections were input to scale. Traffic signal operation (i.e., cycle lengths, phasing, and timing
plans) were provided by Caltrans and entered into the model. Traffic volumes were input into the model, based
on the counts and adjustments to reflect actual demand, as described above.

The AM and PM peak hour VISSIM models were calibrated and validated to existing conditions based on traffic
volumes and observed maximum vehicle queues. During this process, the model was visually inspected to
ensure that it reflected observed conditions.

As identified by the vehicle counts, the AM peak hour occurs from 7:30 to 8:30 AM, while the peak PM period is
from 5:00 to 6:00 PM. The model was constructed to start 15 minutes prior to the beginning of the peak period, to
properly "seed" the model with traffic before the peak-hour analysis. Thus, the model begins at 7:15 AM for the
AM model, and at 4:45 PM for the PM model. In addition to the 15-minute "seed" period and the 60-minute peak
hour analysis, the models included additional time after the peak hour to verify that the queue dissipated
consistently with observations. The AM model includes an additional 60 minutes (for a total of 135 minutes) and
the PM model includes an additional 90 minutes (for a total of 165 minutes). The results presented in the existing
conditions section of this memo are for the peak hour only.

Due to the width of Calera Parkway, when pedestrians are crossing, the amount of signal "green" time is
extended to allow for adequate pedestrian clearance. When this occurs, traffic operations are affected because
less green time is available for thru-traffic on SR 1. Pedestrian activity at the intersections were observed and
modeled in the simulation to account for this phenomenon.

Calibration

During calibration of a VISSIM model, individual components are adjusted to match field-observed data.
Calibration involves setting background traffic operation and driver behavior characteristics including yielding
right-of-way at intersections, gap acceptance, and traffic composition characteristics. The default values were
adjusted during this process so that the model would accurately reflect observed conditions. Adjusted default
values and other refinements made to calibrate/validate the VISSIM model are summarized as follows:

    ·   Reduced speed zones were placed on turns at intersections to reflect the effect turning vehicles have on
        through traffic

    ·   The vehicle mix was adjusted to include 2% heavy vehicles

    ·   Vehicle travel speeds were entered based on the posted speed limits, with a distribution of +/- 5 mph




                                                                                                                12
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




    ·   The portions of SR 1 north of Reina del Mar were coded as freeway links, with default driver behavior
        parameters more representative of freeway facilities, while other links in the network were coded as urban
        arterial links, with default driver behavior parameters more commonly exhibited on arterial streets.

Validation

As noted earlier, the model was validated to observed peak direction queuing based on visual inspection of the
model. In the AM peak period model, the SR 1 northbound queues extend approximately to Crespi Drive, the
westbound Fassler Avenue queues extend past Roberts Boulevard, and the queues on Reina del Mar extend
past the elementary school for a short period, all of which are consistent with field observations. In addition, after
reaching their maximum lengths, all queues dissipate to uncongested conditions within 45 minutes following the
peak hour.

In the PM peak period, the southbound queues on SR 1 extend just past the Sharp Park Road overcrossing.
Congestion also occurs near the SR 1 / Fassler Avenue intersection, with queues from the southbound left turn
lanes occasionally extending beyond the storage capacity of the turn lanes, occasionally blocking through traffic.
This model replicates this queuing in terms of extent and duration, consistent with field observations.

The models accurately reflect key bottleneck locations and queuing and are consistent with field observations.

Once each model was built and verified against field observations, it was run a total of 10 times using different
random seed values. Since microsimulation models such as VISSIM rely on the random arrival of vehicles,
multiple runs will each provide a slightly different simulation, which represent the day-to-day fluctuations in
congestion. Therefore, averaging the results of 10 separate runs provides a reasonable level of statistical
accuracy and validity.

EXISTING INTERSECTION OPERATIONS
Each study intersection was analyzed based on the volumes shown on Figure 2, existing (year 2007) lane
configurations, and the existing traffic signal timing data provided by Caltrans. The results are summarized in
Table 6. Detailed LOS calculations are contained in the Appendix.

Although these intersections are operated by Caltrans, it has traditionally been Caltrans' policy to adhere to locally
adopted operational performance standards. The City of Pacifica has adopted a standard of LOS D or better for
signalized intersections. During the AM and PM peak hours, as shown in Table 6, study intersections in the
project vicinity currently operate at LOS E or F. Therefore, these intersections operate unacceptably, based on
the City of Pacifica's performance standards.

Examining the entire network, we can also determine the average delay per vehicle that travels through the
network, whether they travel through one or both intersections. The average delay per vehicle for the AM and PM
peak hours is:

   ·   127 average seconds of delay per vehicle in the AM peak hour
   ·   128 average seconds of delay per vehicle in the PM peak hour

 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




4. PROJECT DESCRIPTION
The proposed improvements along SR 1 have been developed to address recurring peak period queuing in the
area. This chapter provides a discussion of the three alternatives analyzed, in addition to the No Project
alternative.

NO PROJECT ALTERNATIVE
For the no project alternative, existing roadway configurations and future traffic volume projections were used to
determine future roadway operations if no improvements were made to the study corridor.

OPTION AROADWAY WIDENING ALTERNATIVE
Under this alternative, SR 1 between just south of Fassler Avenue and just north of Reina del Mar avenue would
be widened to provide three through travel lanes in each direction. This would provide increased throughput
capacity through the two study intersections.

In the northbound direction, a third lane would be added to SR1 beginning 1,250 feet south of the intersection with
Fassler Avenue. This third lane would be carried north, through the intersection with Reina del Mar Avenue. The
lane would end 1,600 feet north of the intersection with Reina del Mar Avenue, at which point the roadway would
begin to transition back to the existing two-lane configuration.

In the southbound direction, a third lane would be added to SR1 beginning 1,250 feet north of Reina del Mar
Avenue. This third lane would carry through the intersection with Reina del Mar Avenue. Three southbound
lanes would be provided between Reina del Mar Avenue and Fassler Avenue. One of these lanes would become
one of the two southbound left turn lanes from SR1 to Fassler Avenue, leaving only two southbound through
lanes south of Fassler Avenue.

Because the intersections at both Fassler Avenue and Reina del Mar Avenue would be widened, a pedestrian
would require extra time to cross the street. The analysis assumes that minimum required pedestrian crossing
times across SR1 would be increased by 8 seconds at each intersection.

OPTION BROADWAY WIDENING + PEDESTRIAN OVERCROSSING ALTERNATIVE
This alternative is similar to the Option A, except that in addition, a pedestrian overcrossing would be provided
across SR 1 on the south side of the Reina del Mar Avenue intersection. Currently, when the pedestrian signal
phase is actuated across SR 1, the amount of green time allocated to the eastbound Reina del Mar Avenue
approach is increased to allow sufficient crossing time for pedestrians. This shortens the amount of green time
provided to northbound and southbound movements on SR 1. If a pedestrian overcrossing were provided,
pedestrians could cross SR 1 freely without affecting the traffic throughput of the SR 1 / Reina del Mar Avenue
intersection.

While a pedestrian overcrossing theoretically removes pedestrians and bicyclists from the road (thus improving
safety), there is no guarantee that pedestrians will use it. If not designed properly, overcrossings can produce a
circuitous and strenuous route for pedestrians. Under these circumstances, some pedestrians may choose to
cross at the street level, which can be a major safety hazard because the pedestrian signal phase would be
removed. For these reasons, many jurisdictions do not construct overcrossings. Construction of any
overcrossing should strive to provide the most direct connection, as well as adequate barriers to direct
pedestrians to the structure and discourage street-level crossings.


                                                                                                                16
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




OPTION CGRADE SEPARATION ALTERNATIVE
This alternative would involve constructing a grade separation of the SR 1 / Reina del Mar Avenue intersection.
As currently envisioned, SR 1 would be elevated to pass over Reina del Mar Avenue. Access to SR 1 from Reina
del Mar Avenue would be provided via a tight diamond interchange, with stop sign control on the off-ramps to
Reina del Mar Avenue.

In addition, this alternative would widen SR1 north and south of the intersection with Fassler Avenue, to increase
its capacity. In the northbound direction, a third lane would be added to SR1 1,250 feet before the intersection
with Fassler Avenue. This lane would be carried through the intersection until 400 feet north of the intersection
with Fassler Avenue, followed by a transition back to the existing two-lane configuration. Approaching the Reina
del Mar Avenue overpass along northbound SR 1, an exit ramp would be provided 500 feet before the cross
street. The entrance ramp for traffic entering northbound SR 1 from Reina del Mar Avenue would also be 500
feet long and would have a 700-foot merge section.

In the southbound direction, there would be an exit ramp from SR1 to Reina del Mar Avenue 500 feet before the
cross street. There would also be a 500-foot entrance ramp from Reina del Mar Avenue to southbound SR 1 that
would become a third southbound lane. Similar to the other alternatives, between Reina del Mar Avenue and
Fassler Avenue, one of the three southbound lanes would become a left-turn only lane for the southbound left
turn onto Fassler Avenue. As exists today, only two lanes would travel southbound through the intersection with
Fassler Avenue.

Because the intersection of SR1 and Fassler Avenue would be widened by two lanes, it would take a pedestrian
extra time to cross the street. To account for this, pedestrian crossing times across SR1 have been increased by
8 seconds at Fassler Avenue.




                                                                                                               17
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




5. CONSTRUCTION YEAR (2015) OPERATIONS ANALYSIS
This section describes the construction year 2015 AM and PM peak hour operating conditions within the study
area, as modeled in the simulation, under each of the three project scenarios and the No Project alternative.
Measures of effectiveness including intersection levels of service, travel times, and queue lengths are presented.

YEAR 2015 TRAFFIC FORECASTS
The methodology for development of traffic forecasts was described earlier in this report. The resulting traffic
forecasts are described below.

Annual Growth Factor

As described earlier, an annual background traffic growth rate of 0.75% was chosen for SR 1, both in the
northbound and southbound directions, and for both the AM and PM peak hours. As the future year is 2015, and
the base year counts were conducted in 2007, there are eight years of growth. This creates an expected overall
traffic growth over the time period of 6.2%.

The traffic forecasting methodology discussion also identified an annual background traffic growth rate of 0.4% for
other roadways within Pacifica experiencing new development. This creates an overall growth of 3.2% over the
eight year period. This growth was applied to Fassler Avenue east of SR 1.

The other roads shown in the VISSIM traffic analysis model (Reina del Mar Avenue and Fassler
Avenue/Rockaway Beach Avenue west of SR 1) are not anticipated to see traffic growth due to regional
background growth. Thus, traffic from these streets was not scaled upward.

Anticipated Developments

In addition to background traffic growth along the study corridor due to regional development and regional traffic
increases, traffic associated with several developments in the City of Pacifica was also incorporated into the traffic
forecasts. The City of Pacifica provided Fehr & Peers with the traffic impact studies of several pending
developments within the study area. Each of these developments is expected to generate trips at one or both of
the study intersections. These projects include:

    1.   5 single family residential units on Piedmont Avenue
    2.   34-unit condominium development on Fassler Avenue, The Prospects
    3.   63-unit condominium development on Fassler Avenue at Route 1
    4.   11 single family residential units on Higgins Way
    5.   22-room addition to an existing hotel on Kick Gust Way
    6.   7-unit condominium project on Adobe Drive
    7.   14 single family residential units on Roberts Road
    8.   13 single family residential units in Pedro Point, Shoreside

    Source: RKH Transportation Consultants

                                                                                                           2015 CONDITIONS INTERSECTION

April 2008
                                                                                                                                                             FIGURE 3
SF07-0312\graphics\0312-3
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




The trips generated from these projects were added to the future conditions model. The resulting traffic volume
forecasts, which incorporate the regional growth and traffic increases associated with individual developments
within Pacifica, are depicted in Figure 3.

Levels of Service

The VISSIM analysis results compared over all alternatives to the 2015 No Build alternative are summarized in
Tables 8 and 9. Detailed LOS and queue length calculations are contained in the Appendix.

Although these intersections are operated by Caltrans, it has traditionally been Caltrans' policy to adhere to locally
adopted operational performance standards. The City of Pacifica has adopted a standard of LOS D or better for
signalized intersections. As described in the Existing Conditions chapter of this report, the two study intersections
currently operate at LOS E or F in both the AM and PM peak hours, which is below the City's adopted standard.

While LOS is a typical Measure of Effectiveness (MOE) in most corridor studies, when dealing with severely
congested intersections, LOS alone cannot convey the entire situation. For example, a signal with 90 seconds of
delay and a signal with 300 seconds of delay are both labeled as LOS F, although the relative experience for a
driver may be very different between the two.

This report provides several other MOE's, which, taken collectively, can effectively measure and describe
operating conditions. Percentage of demand served shows the amount of travel demand that can get through an
intersection in a peak hour, with the unserved demand waiting in queue. Queue length shows how many cars are
waiting, and also indicates that long queues may spill back into upstream intersections, compounding delay.
Travel times are probably the most relevant to the typical motorist, and provide an indication of his or her traveling
experience. Seconds of delay per vehicle is a good baseline measurement which takes into consideration all
vehicles, not only those in the peak direction.

ANALYSIS RESULTS
Tables 8 and 9 summarize and compare the results analysis of the three alternatives and the No Build alternative.
All three alternatives would improve traffic flow in the year 2015. All three options offer substantial improvement
to intersection levels of service, travel times, and queuing. Of the three, Option C, the grade separation
alternative, has the greatest benefit to traffic operations. Options A and B offer similar levels of improvement.
While Option C does offer greater benefits to drivers compared to the other options, other factors, such as
pedestrian circulation and cost should be considered before selecting a preferred alternative.

A discussion of the expected opening day operating conditions for each of the alternatives is provided below.

No Build Alternative

Under this alternative, no changes would be made to the roadway network. As traffic would increase due to both
background growth and new development, as listed above, congestion and delay would increase as well.

AM Peak Period

Congestion during the AM period would deteriorate compared to existing conditions. Operations would remain
similar for the Reina del Mar intersection, with an increase in delay from 66 to 68 seconds per vehicle. This is
because traffic approaching this intersection is metered by the Fassler Avenue signal. The Fassler intersection


                                                                                                                   20
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




would degrade from 195 to 345 seconds of delay. Maximum queue lengths on the northbound approach to
Fassler Avenue would increase from 3,260 to 5,305 feet. Northbound travel times will increase by approximately
20%, from 5.1 to 5.9 minutes.

PM Peak Period

Increased demand will cause delay at the Reina del Mar intersection will increase, from 138 to 202 seconds. This
will cause southbound queues to grow, from 7,685 to 9,549 feet. Because the Reina del Mar intersection meters
traffic to the Fassler intersection, delay at Fassler Avenue will only increase from 117 to 124 seconds. Travel
times will increase from 8.4 to 9.5 minutes, or 13%.




                                           Table 8: Intersection Levels of Service
                                                    Year 2015 Conditions


                                                                   AM Peak Hour                  PM Peak Hour
                                                Traffic                         Peak                         Peak
                                                Control                         Hour                         Hour
                                                           Delay       LOS     Demand
                                                                                         Delay       LOS    Demand
                                                                               Served                       Served

          SR1 & Reina del Mar (No Build)        Signal       68         E         91%    202          F         86%

          SR1 & Reina del Mar (Option A)        Signal       51         D         100%    34          C         100%

          SR1 & Reina del Mar (Option B)        Signal       49         D         100%    24          C         100%
         SR1 East Ramps & Reina del Mar
                                                 Stop        33         D         84%     17          C         89%
                   (Option C)
        SR1 West Ramps & Reina del Mar
                                                 Stop        11         B         93%     17          C         100%
                  (Option C)




         SR1 & Fassler Avenue (No Build)        Signal      345         F         91%    124          F         85%

         SR1 & Fassler Avenue (Option A)        Signal       60         E         100%    54          D         100%

         SR1 & Fassler Avenue (Option B)        Signal       59         E         100%    47          D         100%

         SR1 & Fassler Avenue (Option C)        Signal       61         E         100%    32          C         100%

    Source: Fehr & Peers, January 2008




                                                                                                                       21
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




Option A--Roadway Widening Alternative

With this alternative, both directions of SR1 would be widened from 2 to 3 lanes. The traffic operational analysis
assumed that traffic signal timing would be optimized for the changed roadway configuration. Specifically, the
analysis assumes that traffic signal timing for the intersection of SR1 and Fassler Avenue would be modified to
give more green time to the westbound Fassler Avenue approach of SR1, with a corresponding reduction for the
northbound SR1 movement (which now has three lanes). The overall cycle length was not changed.

AM Peak Period

In the AM peak period, this alternative presents substantial improvements in service compared to the No Build
Alternative. Both study intersections experience a LOS improvement of one letter grade. One hundred percent of
traffic is served, compared to approximately 90 percent served under the No Build Alternative. In addition,
maximum vehicle queues would decrease by approximately 75 percent compared to the No Build alternative.
Travel time and overall delay also substantially improve. Travel time would improve by approximately 1/3, or two
minutes. Despite this improvement, the intersection of Fassler Avenue / SR 1 would operate at LOS E. The
overall average network wide delay would be 55 seconds of delay per vehicle in the AM peak hour, compared to
201 seconds under No Build conditions, a decrease of 73 percent.




                                            Table 9: SR1 Travel Times and Queues
                                                     Year 2015 Conditions

                            Travel Time         Average Reina Maximum Reina Average Fassler   Maximum
                             (minutes)
                                       1        del Mar Queue del Mar Queue     Queue       Fassler Queue

                                                   AM Peak Hour - Northbound
          No Build               5.9                 1,074               2,804                 4,361               5,305
          Option A               3.8                  446                2,312                 142                  876
          Option B               3.8                  404                2,103                 132                  830
                                                            2                 2
          Option C               2.8                  n/a                 n/a                  157                  823
                                                   PM Peak Hour - Southbound
          No Build               9.5                 4,893               9,549                 2,627               3,207
          Option A               3.4                  109                 951                  448                 2,400
          Option B               3.4                  52                  772                  319                 2,061
                                                            2                 2
          Option C               3.2                  n/a                 n/a                   95                 1,102
          Source: Fehr & Peers, January 2008.
          1. Travel times measured from just north of Crespi Drive to just north of Reina del Mar Avenue (for AM Northbound, a
                  distance of 1.6 miles), and from about 1.8 miles north of Reina del Mar Avenue to just south of Fassler Avenue
                  (for PM Southbound, a distance of 2.5 miles).
          2. Because there is no longer an intersection, there are no queues under Option C.



                                                                                                                                   22
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




PM Peak Period

In the PM peak period, Option A presents even greater improvements in service than in the AM peak period. The
southbound left-turn movement at Fassler Avenue will continue to experience congestion, but queues from this
intersection will not spill back to the intersection with Reina del Mar Avenue. Because there would be three
southbound lanes instead of two between Reina del Mar Avenue and Fassler Avenue, and one of the lanes would
become one of the two left-turn lanes, queues would not spill back from the Fassler Avenue intersection to disrupt
through traffic.

Based on observations of the simulation model, southbound queues at the intersection of Reina del Mar Avenue
dissipate within each signal cycle. Virtually all congestion on SR1 north of Reina del Mar Avenue would be
eliminated. This is reflected at the Reina del Mar Avenue intersection, which would improve from LOS F under
No Build conditions to LOS C. Travel times would be reduced by 63 percent, while overall vehicle delay would be
reduced by 81 percent. Both study intersections would operate at acceptable LOS D or better.


The average network-wide delay per vehicle would be 44 seconds per vehicle in the PM peak hour, compared to
163 seconds under No Build conditions, a decrease of 73 percent.

Option B--Roadway Widening + Pedestrian Overcrossing Alternative

This alternative is the same as the alternative listed above, except that a pedestrian overcrossing would be
installed at the intersection of Reina del Mar Avenue and SR1. This would eliminate the pedestrian signal phase
across SR 1 at this intersection, which would allow more green time for the vehicular through movements. (Note
that Option B includes all of the improvements associated with Option A.)

AM Peak Period

While constructing the pedestrian overcrossing as proposed under Option B may have traffic operational benefits
if it were a stand-alone project, combining the pedestrian overcrossing with the roadway widening described in
Option A offers few additional benefits compared to Option A, as shown in Tables 8 and 9. The overall average
network wide delay would be 53 seconds of delay per vehicle in the AM peak hour, compared to 201 seconds
under No Build conditions, a decrease of 74 percent.

PM Peak Period

Similar to the AM peak period, the construction of the pedestrian overcrossing provides very little improvement in
operations, compared to the benefit associated with Option A. The overall average network wide delay would be
36 seconds of delay per vehicle in the AM peak hour, compared to 163 seconds under No Build conditions, a
decrease of 78 percent.

Option CGrade Separation Alternative

This scenario assumes the construction of a grade-separated intersection at Reina del Mar Avenue and SR1. A
diamond interchange would be built for access to Reina del Mar Avenue. Ramp terminal intersections on Reina
del Mar Avenue would be side-street stop sign controlled. This configuration would have the benefit of the
removal of the traffic signal for northbound and southbound traffic, which is the primary traffic bottleneck in the AM
peak hour, and a substantial contributor to congestion in the PM peak hour. Similar to the analysis of Options A
and B, the analysis of Option C assumes that at the SR1 intersection with Fassler Avenue, traffic signal green
time would be shifted from the northbound approach to the westbound approach. The northbound and


                                                                                                                   23
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




southbound directions along SR 1 would have three lanes instead of two, and therefore require less signal green
time.

AM Peak Period

Option C provides the most substantial traffic operation benefit of the options. In the northbound direction,
vehicles would travel at free-flow speeds north of Fassler Avenue. The intersection of Fassler Avenue and SR1
would improve as a result of grade separation at SR1 and Reina del Mar Avenue because queues from that
intersection would no longer back up to Fassler Avenue. In addition, SR1 would be widened to three northbound
lanes just north and south of Fassler Avenue allowing more vehicles to travel through the intersection. The
intersection of SR1 and Fassler Avenue would improve from LOS F under No Build conditions to LOS E, and
queues on northbound SR1 at Fassler Avenue, as well as westbound Fassler Avenue, would generally clear
within each signal cycle length. The two ramp terminal intersections at Reina del Mar Avenue would operate at
LOS A. The overall average network wide delay would be 48 seconds of delay per vehicle in the AM peak hour,
compared to 201 seconds under No Build conditions, a decrease of 76 percent.

PM Peak Period

While the Reina del Mar interchange has been eliminated, drivers under this alternative would still experience
some congestion during the PM peak hour due to the heavy left-turn volume from southbound SR1 to Fassler
Avenue. With removal of the SR 1 / Reina del Mar Avenue intersection, more vehicles would be able to reach the
SR 1 / Fassler Avenue intersection. However, as with Options A and B, one of the three southbound lanes
between Reina del Mar Avenue and Fassler Avenue would become a left-turn lane, meaning that queues for left-
turning traffic would not impede through traffic. The two ramp terminal intersections at Reina del Mar Avenue
would operate at LOS B or better.

Despite this, Option C would continue to provide substantial improvements to SR 1, compared to the No Build
alternative. It would also offer the most benefits of the project alternatives. The overall average network wide
delay would be 28 seconds of delay per vehicle in the PM peak hour, compared to 163 seconds under No Build
conditions, a decrease of 83 percent.




                                                                                                             24
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




6. CUMULATIVE YEAR (2035) OPERATIONS ANALYSIS
This section describes the future year 2035 AM and PM peak hour operating conditions within the study area, as
modeled in the simulation, under each of the three project scenarios and the No Project alternative. Measures of
effectiveness including intersection levels of service, travel times, and queue lengths are presented.

YEAR 2035 TRAFFIC FORECASTS
The methodology for development of traffic forecasts was described earlier in this report. The resulting traffic
forecasts are described below. Figure 4 shows year 2035 projected traffic volumes in the study area.

Annual Growth Factor

As described earlier, an annual background traffic growth rate of 0.75% was chosen for SR 1, both in the
northbound and southbound directions, and for both the AM and PM peak hours. As the future year is 2035 and
the base year counts were conducted in 2007, there are 28 years of growth. This creates an expected overall
traffic growth over the time period of 23.3%.

The traffic forecasting methodology discussion also identified an annual background traffic growth rate of 0.4% for
other roadways within Pacifica experiencing new development. This creates an overall growth of 11.8% over the
28 year period. This growth was applied to Fassler Avenue east of SR 1.

The other roads shown in the VISSIM traffic analysis model (Reina del Mar Avenue and Fassler
Avenue/Rockaway Beach Avenue west of SR 1) are not anticipated to see traffic growth due to regional
background growth over the 28-year period. Thus, traffic from these streets was not scaled upward.

Anticipated Development

All of the minor developments assumed in the 2015 Operations Analysis were assumed to also be present in the
2035 analysis.

Development of the Quarry Site

Immediately to the west of the study corridor is a large vacant site known as the "Quarry Site." Several
developments have been proposed on this parcel, but due to local opposition to further development, the site
remains vacant.

While it is impossible to predict what development, if any at all, will ultimately take place on this site, this analysis
assumed that the land would be developed according to its current zoning, which is zoned for light industrial and
warehousing uses, as well as a commercial shopping center.

Development of this site will increase the volume of northbound left-turning vehicles into this site. The northbound
left-turn pocket will need to be extended from the current 250 to 350 feet.

                                                                                                                                                     SR 1 Calera Parkway PA-ED

                                                                                                                  2035 CONDITIONS INTERSECTION
                                                                                                                   TURNING MOVEMENT VOLUMES
March 2008
                                                                                                                                                                    FIGURE 4
SF07-0312\graphics\0312-4
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




The ABAG growth projections for Pacifica indicate 90 new industrial jobs and 150 new retail jobs will be added
between 2005 and 2035. After conversation with the Pacifica Planning and Economic Development Department,
it was assumed that 90 percent of these new jobs would take place on the Quarry site, as this represents
approximately 90 percent of the developable land remaining in Pacifica. Using the ITE Trip Generation
Handbook, the site's trip generation was forecasted. Trips were assigned north or south on SR 1 based on
existing traffic proportions. It was assumed that half of the trips would access the site via Reina del Mar Avenue,
and the other half via Fassler Avenue. The additional traffic associated with the other anticipated developments
in Pacifica as well as potential development at the Quarry Site was added on top of the background growth
discussed earlier associated with regional traffic increases to present a conservative analysis.

Other Changes to the Network

Development of the Quarry site would likely entail access improvements. The analysis assumes that if the Quarry
Site were developed, an eastbound right turn pocket would be built at the intersection of Reina del Mar Avenue
and SR 1, for vehicles leaving the project site and traveling south. At the intersection of Fassler Avenue and SR
1, a right turn pocket already exists, so no improvements are expected there associated with the Quarry Site.

No other elements of the network were changed.

ANALYSIS RESULTS
Tables 10 and 11 summarize and compare the results of the three alternatives and the No Build alternative. All
three alternatives will improve traffic flow in the year 2035. Similar to the 2015 analysis, Option C, the grade
separation alternative, has the greatest benefit to traffic operations, because it essentially replaces a signalized
intersection with a grade-separated facility. However, as with the year 2015 analysis, all three options offer
substantial benefits compared to the No Build alternative.

No Build Alternative

Under this alternative, no changes would be made to the roadway network except for the installation of a right-
turn pocket for eastbound Reina del Mar Avenue, associated with potential development at the Quarry Site, as
described earlier. Traffic volumes would increase due to background growth, new smaller development, and the
development of the Quarry Site.

It should be noted that under this alternative, vehicle queue lengths extended beyond the limits of the model,
specifically beyond Linda del Mar Boulevard (in the AM) and Sharp Park Road (in the PM). The model could not
be extended because data was not collected at these intersections. To estimate the additional queue length
beyond the model limits, 25 feet was added for each unserved vehicle. To estimate the additional travel time
through this extra queue, travel speeds were assumed to be 9 miles per hour.

AM Peak Hour

Compared to existing conditions, operations would severely degrade. While average delay at the Reina del Mar
intersection would only increase from 66 to 70 seconds (due to the metering effect of the upstream Fassler
intersection), delay at Fassler Avenue would increase from 195 to 389 seconds. This will cause the northbound
queue at on SR 1 at Fassler Avenue to grow from 3,260 to 9,213 feet. Northbound travel time will increase
almost 150%, from 5.1 to 12.6 minutes.




                                                                                                                 27
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




PM Peak Hour

During the PM rush hour, delay at the Reina del Mar intersection is expected to almost double, from 138 seconds
to 251 seconds, per vehicle. Queue lengths at the southbound approach at Reina del Mar will increase from
7,685 feet to 11,575 feet, and southbound travel times will grow from 8.4 to 15.4 minutes, about an 83% increase.

Option A--Roadway Widening Alternative

As described previously, Option A would involve widening SR 1 between just south of Fassler Avenue to just
north of Reina del Mar Avenue from four lanes to six. To accommodate additional demand, the northbound left-
turn pocket at Reina del Mar Avenue would need to be extended approximately 100 feet.



AM Peak Period

In the AM peak period, Option A presents substantial improvements in service compared to the No Build
Alternative, but congestion would remain. Option A would increase the percentage of traffic demand that could be
served from approximately 75 percent under No Build conditions to over 90 percent. Both intersections would
operate worse than the LOS D threshold maintained by the City of Pacifica, but would operate substantially better
than if no improvements were made. Option A would improve AM peak hour travel times by over 40 percent. In
general, Option A would offer strong improvements to traffic operations, but by year 2035, traffic conditions may
be similar to today's conditions due to regional traffic growth. The overall average network wide delay would be
78 seconds of delay per vehicle in the AM peak hour, compared to 224 seconds per vehicle under No Build
conditions, a decrease of 65 percent.




                                                                                                              28
State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
June 2008

                                            Table 11: SR1 Travel Times and Queues
                                                     Year 2035 Conditions


                                                Average Reina Maximum Reina    Average                         Maximum
                            Travel Time         del Mar Queue del Mar Queue Fassler Queue                    Fassler Queue
                                       1
                             (minutes)               (feet)        (feet)       (feet)                           (feet)
                                                   AM Peak Hour - Northbound
                                       3
          No Build              12.6                 1,095               2,804                 4,946              9,2133
          Option A               4.5                  858                2,940                 293                 1,141
          Option B               4.4                  709                2,866                 277                 1,142
                                                            2                 2
          Option C               3.3                  n/a                 n/a                  539                 1,894
                                                   PM Peak Hour - Southbound
                                       3
          No Build              15.4                 6,907              11,5753                2,567               3,210
          Option A               4.2                  334                2,600                 736                 2,693
          Option B               4.2                  340                2,826                 662                 2,727
                                                            2                 2
          Option C               3.5                  n/a                 n/a                  308                 2,055
          Source: Fehr & Peers, January 2008.
          1. Travel times measured from just north of Crespi Drive to just north of Reina del Mar Avenue (for AM Northbound, a
                  distance of 1.6 miles), and from about 1.8 miles north of Reina del Mar Avenue to just south of Fassler Avenue
                  (for PM Southbound, a distance of 2.5 miles).
          2. Because there is no longer an intersection, there are no queues under Option C.
          3. Queue extends beyond model limits. Length increased to estimate full queue length by adding 25 feet per unserved
                 vehicle. Travel time increased by assuming 9 mph average speed in queue.




PM Peak Period

Option A also provides substantial improvements in service during the PM peak hour. The southbound left-turn
movement at Fassler Avenue will experience congestion, but queues will not spill back to the intersection with
Reina del Mar Avenue. Queues for the southbound left turn movement from SR 1 at Fassler Avenue would not
interfere with through traffic.

Travel times in the PM peak hour would be substantially improved in year 2035 under Option A, even compared
to existing conditions. The overall average network wide delay would be 62 seconds of delay per vehicle in the
PM peak hour, compared to 181 seconds per vehicle under No Build conditions, a decrease of 66 percent.


While the southbound left turn pocket at Reina del Mar Avenue is not expected to see an increase in demand
over existing volumes, an analysis was performed to determine if the existing 500-foot turn pocket would be
adequate in the future. The VISSIM application can only report average and maximum queue lengths; however,
transportation facilities are usually sized based on the 95th percentile queue length. As a supplement to the
VISSIM analysis results, the southbound let-turn pocket was analyzed in Synchro, which presents queue lengths
for the 95th percentile.



                                                                                                                                   30
 State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
 June 2008




The analysis revealed that the southbound left turn queue would have a 95th percentile queue length of 677 feet.
Thus, the left turn pocket should be extended to 675 feet. The supplemental Synchro queue analysis is
presented in the appendix.



Option B--Roadway Widening + Pedestrian Overcrossing Alternative

This alternative is the same as Option A, except that a pedestrian overcrossing would be installed at the
intersection of Reina del Mar Avenue and SR1. This would eliminate the pedestrian signal phase across SR 1 at
this intersection, which would allow more green time for the northbound and southbound vehicular through
movements on SR1.

AM Peak Period

Similar to findings for Option B in year 2015 conditions, there is little marginal benefit to adding the pedestrian
overcrossing across SR 1 in year 2035 conditions to the improvements included in Option A. Overall average
network wide delay would be 75 seconds of delay per vehicle in the AM peak hour, compared to 224 seconds
under No Build conditions, a decrease of 67 percent.

PM Peak Period

Similar to the AM peak period analysis, construction of the pedestrian overcrossing offers few additional benefits
to the improvements associated with Option A. The overall average network wide delay would be 59 seconds per
vehicle, compared to 181 seconds per vehicle under No Build conditions, a decrease of 67 percent.

Option CGrade Separation Alternative

This scenario assumes the construction of a grade-separated intersection at Reina del Mar Avenue and SR1. A
tight diamond interchange would be built for access to Reina del Mar Avenue. This would have the benefit of the
removal of the traffic signal for northbound and southbound traffic, which is a key bottleneck.

AM Peak Period

Similar to the year 2015 analysis, Option C would provide the most substantial benefit in terms of the overall
percentage of traffic demand served, travel times, and queuing. Elimination of the bottleneck at the SR 1 / Reina
del Mar Avenue intersection would improve travel times by nearly 60 percent (or nearly five minutes) compared to
No Build conditions. The intersection of SR 1 and Fassler Avenue would still operate at LOS F, but would serve
nearly all expected traffic demand, which is an improvement compared to the No Build alternative, which would
only serve 75 percent of the travel demand. Overall average network wide delay would be 91 seconds of delay
per vehicle in the AM peak hour, compared to 224 seconds under No Build conditions, a decrease of 59 percent.

PM Peak Period

While the Reina del Mar interchange has been eliminated, this alternative still experiences some congestion in the
PM peak period due to the heavy left-turn volume from southbound SR1 to Fassler Avenue. However, left-turn
queues would remain confined to the long southbound left turn pocket, and would not interfere with the
southbound through traffic. Queues on southbound SR 1 from the Fassler Avenue intersection would not reach
the Reina del Mar interchange. Overall average network wide delay would be 41 seconds of delay per vehicle in
the PM peak hour, compared to 181 seconds under No Build conditions, a decrease of 77 percent.

State Route 1 / Calera Parkway Project ­ Final Traffic Operations Report
June 2008

Fehr & Peers                                                                                5/6/2008
                      Calera Parkway: Transit Analysis
                              October 28, 2008

Issue
This analysis examines the feasibility of increasing transit service as a means of
alleviating road congestion along Highway 1 from Reina del Mar Avenue to Fassler
Avenue.


Project Description
The Calera Parkway project area includes Highway 1, from 1.3 miles north of Reina
del Mar Avenue to 1 mile south of Fassler Avenue. The alternatives being considered
for improvements to the corridor is the widening of Highway 1 from 2 to 3 lanes in
each direction. An environmental study is currently being undertaken and is expected
to be completed in 2009.


Existing Conditions
Highway 1 is a two-lane roadway, which widens to four lanes in Pacifica. Just north of
the study area, Highway 1 becomes a freeway for five miles before merging with
Interstate 280. Adjoining streets which create the intersections include Fassler
Avenue, a four-lane roadway that extends east of Highway 1 into the Pacifica Hills,
and Reina del Mar Avenue, a short two-lane street extending east of Highway 1.

a) Congestion and Travel Patterns
    Peak period congestion in the AM is caused by or exacerbated by travel due
     to child drop-off at schools in the area.
    Peak period congestion in the AM and PM is possibly due to job related
     commutes from San Francisco (employment center) to the "Coastside"
     (residential center).
    The congestion also appears to be related to conflicts between local and
     through traffic at intersections, which includes pedestrian crossing major
     intersections that require longer cross-traffic time.

b) Existing Transit Routes in the project area
   The following table shows the seven routes that operate in the project area and
   lists average weekday ridership (AWR), the time of service, headway, and a brief
   description of the route.




                                                                             Page 1 of 4
Table 1: Existing SamTrans Transit Routes near Pacifica

              Avg.                              Headways*
            Weekday
 Route                                                                         Description
            Ridershi        Pea       Mid-      Evenin     Saturda   Sunda
               p             k        day         g           y        y
                                                                               Bi-directional Loop route through
   14           490          30        60         60*        60*      60*      Linda Mar - begins and ends at
                                                                               Linda Mar Park and Ride lot
                                       no          no        no        no
   16           210          n/a
                                     service     service   service   service
                                                                               School days at bell times only

                                                                               Pacifica to Daly City BART - local
  110          1,160         30        60          60        60       90       via Daly City
                                                   no                          Pacifica to Colma BART - local
  112           610          60        60        service     60       60       via Serramonte Shopping Center
                                                   1                           Pacifica to Hillsdale in San Mateo
  294           380          90        90       schedule    120       180      via Half Moon Bay
                            15 -       no          no        no        no      Pacifica to Colma BART Express
   CX           230                  service     service   service   service   on Hwy 1 - regular fare charged
                             35
                                                                               Pacifica to Downtown SF Express
