                                                                               via Hwy 1, I-280, US101 - peak
                             35                                                direction only

   *service is clockwise only during these times & days
   **headways noted in minutes



Discussion and Analysis
Existing traffic congestion along this corridor appears to be the result of conflicts
between local and through traffic at the signalized intersections resulting in level of
service (LOS) E and F in the AM peak and LOS F in the PM peak periods. This
situation is exacerbated by the high volume of pedestrians crossing the intersection.
These existing conditions (i.e. high volume to capacity ratio) have resulted in delayed
travel time and long queue length leading up to the intersections.

An alternative approach to expanding roadway capacity to relieve congestion on this
stretch of Highway 1 is to reduce the amount of vehicle miles traveled (especially
single occupancy vehicles) by providing additional transit service. The additional
transit service options such as dedicated school service, fixed route service, and
shuttle service are discussed below.

a) Additional Fixed Route Service
   As Table 1 demonstrates, the area is served by seven fixed-route transit lines.
   While providing additional transit service is a possible consideration, additional
   analysis would need to be undertaken to determine whether augmenting the
   existing service would be both optimal and cost effective. The Traffic Operations
   Analysis Report for the Calera Parkway project indicates that some of the
   congestion is related to intersection queues, particularly during the peak periods.
   This traffic appears to be generated from surrounding low density communities,
   whose land use patterns typically do not fare well for increasing ridership in


                                                                                                      Page 2 of 4
   comparison to higher density, urbanized ridership. Moreover, an increase in
   transit service will not likely eliminate the queuing at intersections. Hence, it is
   unlikely that providing additional transit service to this area which is predominately
   low-density residential, would significantly decrease existing congestion.

b) Additional School Service
   SamTrans currently provides seven routes that serve the study area. Routes
   14, 16, 110, and 112 have additional service during the school day-only.
   Routes 294, CX and DX do not offer special school-day service. The following
   table summarizes the school day-only service found on the seven routes
   serving the area.

        Table 2: SamTrans School Day Service

         School Day Service
         Route Description
             14   2 additional schedules each school day
             16   all 8 schedules school day only
            110   4 additional & 2 modified schedules each school day
            112   2 additional schedules each school day
            294   no school day only schedules
             CX   no school day only schedules
             DX   no school day only schedules



   Under the Federal-Aid Highway Act, the Federal Transit Administration (FTA)
   provides financial assistance to public transportation operations that do not
   provide exclusive school bus transportation to students. FTA regulations exempt
   "tripper service," which is mass transportation open to the public which
   accommodates the needs of students. Therefore, as a condition of using federal
   funds, services offered by SamTrans must be open and available to the fare
   paying general public.

   While bus service tailored to meet the needs of students at their schools and bell
   times have high ridership per trip, they are very expensive to provide. School
   trips function as one way trips with significant deadheading. Discounts offered to
   student passengers further erode the cost effectiveness of providing school day
   only trips. Plus, additional service provided to the area would have to be off-set by
   a reduction in service elsewhere in the system. Moreover, additional school
   service would potentially only mitigate the AM peak period congestion attributed
   to schools, but not address the degraded level of service due to the afternoon
   peak period traffic. Therefore, SamTrans would be limited both by regulatory
   constraints and resources to provide additional school day-only service.




                                                                                Page 3 of 4
c) Shuttle Service
   SamTrans currently operates Routes 14, 110, 112, 294, CX and DX that provide
   service to the beach side community via Highway 1. In 2006, C/CAG provided
   funding for a shuttle serving parts of Pacifica, called the Gold Line. The Gold Line
   service, while well-utilized, was costly to provide and provided redundant service
   to SamTrans Route 14. After community service and public input was sought, it
   was determined that the Gold Line be discontinued and instead integrated into the
   existing Route 14 service with increased frequency such as providing expanded
   weekend service. The expanded Route 14 service has been a successful model
   thus far. Average weekday ridership increased 11.5% from the prior year 2007
   ridership.

   It has been proposed that SamTrans provide additional shuttle services to the
   coastal areas via Highway 1. However, as was the case with the Gold Line, the
   service is expensive to provide on a per passenger basis, funding for such a
   shuttle is limited and not financially sustainable in the long term, and moreover is
   duplicative of existing SamTrans service that can provide more cost effective
   service. The route was integrated with Route 14 after it was determined that the
   Gold Line, which carried an average of 50 passengers per day, was taking away
   these passengers from SamTrans service, rather than attracting new riders.
   Based on this experience, it is therefore advised that revisiting community-based
   shuttle service not be recommended at this time.

Future Operational Plans
In the near future, SamTrans plans to initiate a Comprehensive Operational Analysis
(COA) to examine all fixed-route service provision within its network. This analysis
will provide more robust data, as well as incorporate factors such as cost
effectiveness metrics and level of service coverage from a system-wide perspective.
The COA will study the provision of SamTrans services and operations to more
efficiently and effectively serve the county's transit needs within the constraints of t he
current financial and operating environment. The transit service needs of Pacifica will
be factored into the system-wide analysis.

Conclusion
While augmented transit service may be a viable solution to alleviate some of the key
drivers of congestion impacting the study area, (e.g. vehicle miles traveled from
single-occupancy vehicles) it is clear that transit is not the only solution. Expanded
transportation demand management programs, such as carpooling and rideshare
should also be considered. In light of current financial and operating constraints,
expanded transit in this area is not recommended. However, expanded transit can
be part of future solutions once a complete analysis of the entire system and network
impacts in undertaken.

References:
1) Highway 1/ Calera Parkway Project. Final Traffic Operations Report, July 2008
2) Project Study Report (04-SM-01 P.M. 42/R43.2), July 1999
3) Ridership Trends/Coastside 07/Route 14, July 2008.

December 8, 2009



Mr. Joseph Hurley
San Mateo County Transportation Authority
1250 San Carlos Avenue
San Carlos, California 94070
Recipient's address

Re:      Additional Transit Analysis for the SR 1/Calera Parkway Project
         Pacifica, California

Dear Joe:

Fehr & Peers has prepared this letter to describe the results of some supplemental analysis we
have conducted for the SR 1 / Calera Parkway project in Pacifica, California. The additional
analysis includes assessment of whether the reduced congestion and more stable vehicle flow
through the study corridor would increase or reduce overall greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
This letter also includes a discussion in response to questions raised by the California Coastal
Commission (CCC) related to a transit analysis memorandum previously submitted by SamTrans.

Because much of our supplemental analysis involves discussion of potential alternative transit
operations, a summary of existing transit service is provided.

SUMMARY OF EXISTING TRANSIT SERVICE

This section describes the nature of existing transit service in the area, as it relates to the project
study corridor. This section does not provide specific responses to any of the questions raised by
the California Coastal Commission; however it does provide useful background discussion to
inform our responses to their questions presented later in this letter. Figure 1 shows the existing
routes. Due to the relatively low density, primarily residential land development in the area,
transit service has been designed to serve two primary functions:

         So-called "Community Service" routes that commonly derive low ridership but provide
         local circulation, generally to providing mobility for transit-dependent residents that do not
         own automobiles

         Commuter and/or express service designed to transport commuters from the lower-
         density coastal residential areas into urban job centers (or to provide connections to other
         regional transit services that serve urban job centers)

SamTrans service in the area provides both of these services.

Routes 14 and 16 are local circulator routes that generally provided local circulation within
Pacifica. Each of these routes provides service to the Linda Mar Park & Ride Lot, where riders
can access commuter-oriented routes that, in turn, connect to regional transit facilities serving
San Francisco and other urbanized job centers.




                332 Pine Street, 4th Floor, San Francisco, CA 94104 (415) 348-0300 Fax (415) 773-1790
                                                  www.fehrandpeers.com
Mr. Joe Hurley
December 8, 2009
Page 2 of 11




    Route 14 offers service approximately every 30 minutes during peak hours from 6 AM until
    approximately 8 PM. Based on ridership data provided by SMCTA, approximately 50 riders
    use this route in peak directions during each of the two-hour AM and PM peak periods.
    Assuming a vehicle capacity of approximately 55 passengers per vehicle and two vehicles
    per hour during the peak hour (total of four vehicles during the two-hour peak period), this
    route operates at less than 25 percent capacity at its peak.

    Route 16 provides local service during typical school commute periods only. Generally, the
    route circulates throughout Pacifica, with stops at Terra Nova High School, the Pacifica
    Library, and the Linda Mar Park & Ride Lot. The route generally has four runs in the AM
    peak hour, each serving different origins and destinations, but generally designed to provide
    supplemental service for school trips. Similarly, the route provides four runs in the afternoon,
    between approximately 2:50 and 3:40 PM. Total average ridership is 173 in the AM peak
    hour and 148 in the afternoon peak hour. Assuming four vehicles in the AM and four in the
    afternoon, each with a capacity of approximately 55 passengers per vehicle, the ridership is
    just under 80 percent occupied. This suggests ridership is very good, but not so high that it
    constrains ridership.

Routes 110 and 112 are so-called "BART Connection" routes that provide service from the Linda
Mar Park & Ride lot to the Daly City and Colma BART stations, respectively.

    Route 110 operates from approximately 6 AM to 11 PM. Between 6 and 8 AM, the route
    operates between near the Pacific Manor shopping center and Daly City; after 8 AM, the
    route provides service to the Linda Mar Park & Ride. In the evening, service to the Linda Mar
    Park & Ride operates until 11 PM. AM and PM peak hour service to the Linda Mar Park &
    Ride operates at approximately one-hour frequency. Ridership information specific to service
    to the Linda Mar Park & Ride was not available; however, discussions with SamTrans staff
    suggest this route operates at approximately 80 percent capacity.

    Route 112 operates between the Linda Mar Park & Ride and the Colma BART Station, with
    hourly service from 8:20 AM to approximately 7:30 PM. The route serves approximately 39
    passengers in the two-hour AM peak period (approximately 35 percent capacity) and 53
    passengers in the PM peak period (approximately 50 percent capacity).

Route 294 is a co-called "Caltrain Connection" route that provides service between the Linda Mar
Park & Ride and the Hillsdale Caltrain Station to the east.

    Route 294 operates between the Linda Mar Park & Ride lot in Pacifica and the Hillsdale
    Caltrain station in San Mateo. The route operates between approximately 5:30 AM and 8:30
    PM. During peak hours, the route provides service approximately every 90 minutes from
    Pacifica through Montara, El Granada, and Half Moon Bay, before traveling east to the
    Hillsdale Caltrain Station. The route operates with 54 riders in the two-hour AM peak period
    (approximately 50 percent capacity) and 27 riders in the PM peak period (approximately 25
    percent capacity). The peak direction in the AM peak hour is northbound, toward Pacifica.
 Mr. Joe Hurley
 December 8, 2009
 Page 3 of 11




 Routes CX and DX are so-called "Express Service" which operate between the Linda Mar Park &
 Ride and the Colma BART Station and the Transbay Terminal in San Francisco, respectively.

         Route CX operates between the Linda Mar Park & Ride and the Colma BART Station.
         Service is provided approximately every 15 ­ 20 minutes in the AM and PM peak hours. The
         one-way trip takes between 15 ­ 20 minutes. Ridership on this route is approximately 57
         passengers in the two hour AM peak period. Assuming three vehicles per hour, this route is
         less than 20 percent of capacity. Ridership in the PM peak hour is higher, at 88 passengers
         per hour, or nearly 40 percent of capacity. This route will be renamed Route 118 in
         December 2009.

         Route DX operates between the Linda Mar Park & Ride and the Transbay Terminal in
         Downtown San Francisco. AM peak hour service operates northbound only, between
         approximately 6 AM and 8:30 AM. PM peak hour service operates southbound only,
         between approximately 4 PM and 7 PM. Ridership information was unavailable; however,
         due to its current $28.4 million budget shortfall, Samtrans is planning to discontinue this route
         in December 2009 since it offers similar service to other routes in the system and displaced
         riders have alternate routes (such as parallel service to Daly City and Colma BART stations).

 Overall ridership provided by SamTrans is summarized in Table 1, below. AM and PM peak hour
 capacity utilization for each of the routes is presented in Table 2.

                                                   Table 1
                                       Existing Transit Ridership Data1

                                                                    Route
            Ridership                                                                              Totals
                                      14          16          110           112    294    CX

  SUPPLEMENTAL SIMULATION ANALYSIS

  Overall, the Calera Parkway project would address recurring peak period congestion through the
  study corridor, which is projected to get substantially worse if no action is taken. As you know,
  one of the key questions we have been asked is what effect the project would have on overall
  GHG emissions. Fortunately, the analysis models we have already developed are highly-detailed
  and able to produce metrics related to the improvements in overall GHG emissions related to
  improved traffic stability.

  Table 3 shows expected GHG and fuel consumption differences between the No Project and With
  Project conditions during the AM and PM peak hours for year 2035 conditions. As shown, peak-
  hour GHG emissions would drop approximately 9 percent during the AM peak hour with the
  project, compared to no project. Similar calculations for the PM peak hour show a 10 percent
  reduction in GHG emissions.
 Mr. Joe Hurley
 December 8, 2009
 Page 5 of 11




                                                     Table 3
                                             Greenhouse Gas Emissions

                                              AM Peak Hour                                    PM Peak Hour
            GHG                                 2035                                            2035
                                2035 No-                                        2035 No-
                                                With          Difference                        With            Difference
                                 Build                                           Build
                                               Project                                         Project
Emissions CO [g]                 65,467        59,571        -5,896 [-9%]         68,256       61,569          -6,687 [-10%]
Emissions Nox [g]                12,738        11,590        -1,147 [-9%]         13,280       11,979          -1,301 [-10%]
Emissions VOC [g]                15,173        13,806        -1,366 [-9%]         15,819       14,269          -1,550 [-10%]
Fuel Consumption [gal]            937           852            -84 [-9%]           976          881              -96 [-10%]

Source: Fehr & Peers, 2009



 We recognize that the comparison above is based on the same set of traffic forecasts (i.e., we
 have not accounted for potential changes to travel demand associated with the project). We have
 performed a sensitivity analysis to determine whether, if traffic volumes were lower without the
 project, the benefits of the project with respect to GHG emissions would be reduced. Our
 sensitivity analysis assumes the following:

             Typical commute times for auto traffic traveling through the study corridor are longer than
             average, given the relatively remote location of residential areas to the south. We
             assume they are approximately 60 minutes under year 2035 conditions without the
             project.

             The project would reduce the travel time of a private-vehicle commute by approximately
             8.5 minutes (14 percent) during the AM peak hour. Based on a 0.76 elasticity between
             vehicle volume and travel time reduction1, a 14 percent improvement in travel time would
             increase peak-hour travel demand by about 11 percent during the AM peak hour.

             The majority of the peak hour traffic volume increase would be trips that shift their trip
             times from off-peak periods to peak periods. Assuming 2/3 of the traffic is simply shifted
             times and 1/3 is new trips, the net new traffic demand increase would be 3.7 percent.

             Similar assumptions suggest a 4.8 percent increase in PM peak hour travel demand.

 Since typical daily and peak hour traffic volumes can vary by as much as ten percent on a daily
 basis, any induced demand effects of the project would be negligible. We recognize that the
 assumptions above are from very generalized information and should be used cautiously.
 However, they do form a helpful basis for which to make conclusions about the general benefits
 of the project.

 PROJECT BENEFITS TO TRANSIT

 In addition to reducing GHG emissions, the project would also improve travel times. While the
 travel time benefits to autos were described in the project's traffic operations report, this section

 1
     Victoria Transport Policy Institute (VTPI) On-line TDM Encyclopedia (http://www.vtpi.org/tdm/tdm11.htm)
Mr. Joe Hurley
December 8, 2009
Page 6 of 11




quantifies and describes the benefits that travel time savings would have to transit routes
operating along the corridor.

In year 2035 conditions, the project would decrease the northbound travel time along SR 1 in the
AM peak hour from 12.6 minutes to 4.5 minutes, a savings of 8.1 minutes, and would decrease
the southbound travel time along SR 1 during the PM peak hour from 15.4 minutes to 4.2
minutes, a savings of 11.2 minutes.

The per-mile operating costs for the three peak-hour routes along this corridor, the 110, the 112,
and CX, have an average operating cost of $4.60 per mile. Average run speeds were calculated
using schedule data for travel time, and came out to approximately 12 miles per hour for Route
112, 17 miles per hour for Route 110, and 25 miles per hour for Route CX. Multiplying the
average run speeds by the cost per mile for each route yielded an average per-hour cost of $89
during the AM peak hour and $91 during the PM peak hour.

With the planned elimination of Route DX, there will be five northbound buses through the
corridor during the AM peak hour and five southbound buses through the PM peak hour. An
expected daily cost savings can be acquired by multiplying the number of buses by the hourly
operating costs of each bus, and by the hours of travel time the project would save. This process
yields an expected weekday cost savings of $146 during the two-hour AM peak period and $180
during the PM peak period. Extrapolated out over an entire year, this sums to approximately
$84,000 of cost savings for Samtrans due to congestion reduction during weekday peak hours in
the peak direction.

POTENTIAL TRANSIT CAPACITY EXPANSION

Currently, there are approximately 345     transit riders along the study corridor in the peak
northbound direction during the two-hour   AM peak period (excluding school trips on Route 16,
which operates a unique local service).     A similar number of riders travel through the study
corridor during the PM peak period. This   equates to ridership of approximately 175 passengers
per hour.

With elimination of Route DX, there will be five northbound buses and five southbound buses
along the study corridor during the AM and PM peak hours, which represents a capacity of 275
passengers per hour.

With the project, approximately 93 percent of the peak hourly vehicle demand would be served in
2035 plus project conditions. The CCC has posed the question as to whether operating
additional transit service would reduce travel demand such that the facility would serve 100
percent of demand with the project. To do this, transit service, therefore, would need to reduce
the overall demand to 93 percent of currently projected levels. This corresponds to a needed
reduction of 258 northbound private vehicles during the AM peak hour and 224 southbound
private vehicles during the PM peak hour. Assuming the average vehicle occupancy along the
corridor is 1.6 people per auto, based on the National Household Travel Behavior Survey, the
enhancements in transit service would need to generate 413 new riders in the AM peak hour and
358 new riders in the PM peak hour. In other words, transit ridership would need to increase to
588 riders in the AM peak hour, a 336 percent increase, and to 533 in the PM peak hour, a 305
percent increase over existing conditions.
Mr. Joe Hurley
December 8, 2009
Page 7 of 11




A study conducted by the Victoria Transport Policy Institute presents a range of elasticity values
relating changes in transit capacity and transit ridership. A conservative estimate shows an
elasticity of 0.5, which would mean that a 10% increase in transit capacity would yield a 5%
increase in transit ridership. To achieve the ridership increases necessary to accommodate
unserved demand under conditions with the proposed project, transit capacity would need to
increase by 672 percent in the AM peak hour and 610 percent in the PM peak hour. This
corresponds to the addition of approximately 31 northbound buses of 55 seats each during the
AM peak hour, and 34 southbound buses during the PM peak hour.

This level of transit service would be cost-prohibitive, and even if financially feasible, would not be
the best use of scarce transit operating funds.

RESPONSE TO SPECIFIC COMMENTS

In addition to the information described above, we have prepared specific responses to ten
questions raised by the CCC in response to a letter prepared by the SMCTA. The Coastal
Commission's comments and our discussion follow.

1. Page 2 of the October 2008 Transit Analysis states that while additional fixed route
   service may relieve congestion by reducing VMT, "additional analysis would need to
   be undertaken to determine whether the existing service would be both optimal and
   cost effective." As I noted above, we understand that much of this information is
   currently available and ask that you provide such an analysis.

Additional transit service could potentially reduce VMT, but the reductions would be minimal
relative to the cost of the service. Since funding for transit operation is scarce, changes to transit
service requiring additional operational funding should be targeted to those areas where the
scarce resources produce the highest return on investment (i.e., ridership).

As described above and summarized on Table 2, the existing transit services have excess
capacity. Routes offering scheduled service from regional Park & Ride lots in Pacifica to regional
transit hubs are typically underutilized (generally less than 50 percent utilized). As a result,
expanding transit service would not provide a significant VMT reduction.

Further, an expansion of transit service would neither generate enough reduction in auto traffic to
either meet the purpose and need of the proposed project, nor to reduce the footprint of the
project. To illustrate, consider the number of current transit riders in the AM and PM peak hours.
The AM peak hour consists of 518 total northbound riders. If riders from Route 16 are removed
(since they are associated with school service only), the northbound non-school ridership is 345
passengers in the two-hour peak, or 173 riders per hour. In the PM peak hour, southbound
ridership is similar, at 350 riders in the two-hour peak, or 175 per hour.

Based on information provided by the Victoria Transport Policy Institute's (VTPI) TDM
Encyclopedia, typical transit ridership elasticity relative to transit capacity is approximately 0.5.
This means that every time transit capacity is doubled, on average, ridership would increase by
50 percent. Assuming that funds were available to double transit service through he study
corridor, a 50 percent increase in peak hour ridership would mean approximately 88 new riders in
each peak hour and direction. Assuming a standard vehicle occupancy of 1.6, based on the
National Household Travel Survey, this would translate to a reduction of 55 vehicles in the
northbound direction in the AM peak hour and 55 vehicles in the southbound direction in the PM
Mr. Joe Hurley
December 8, 2009
Page 8 of 11




peak hour. This would be a 1.5 percent reduction in peak direction vehicle travel demand during
the AM and PM peak hours, respectively. Given typical daily fluctuations in traffic volumes, which
can approach 10 percent, this substantial increase in transit service would produce a negligible
reduction in congestion and overall auto travel demand.

Finally, this comment requests information that may be readily available related to an analysis of
the cost-effectiveness of increased transit in the study area. As noted below in Comment 9,
Samtrans is currently initiating a Comprehensive Operational Analysis that will look at
systemwide operating effectiveness; however, that data will not be available for some time.

2. Page 2 also says that increased transit would not likely be effective because the
   surrounding communities are low density. However, transit may be made more
   effective in low density communities with various additional amenities such as shuttle
   service and commuter parking lots at transit stations. Therefore, please include in the
   analysis measures that would be necessary to increase the effectiveness of transit
   services given the residential density of Pacifica.

In lower-density residential areas, such as the coastal areas of San Mateo County, typical
amenities to encourage transit include Park & Ride lots, shuttles to regional transit connections
(e.g., BART, Caltrain), express service to job centers, and construction of transit-stop amenities
such as curb bulb-outs to increase sidewalk widths or covered pedestrian shelters.

Many of these features are provided throughout the area, but are not fully utilized. For example,
the existing park and ride lots at Crespi and Linda Mar Avenues are only 44 percent utilized2. Of
this amount, anecdotal evidence suggests that a large portion of those vehicles that do park at
the Park & Ride lots are using the lots for beach access, and not for commuting. This suggests
that provision of additional Park & Ride lot capacity would not increase transit ridership in the
area. Further, Table 2 illustrates that even with these amenities, transit service throughout the
corridor is underutilized.

Routes 294, 110, 112, and CX all provide direct connections from outer areas to regional transit
hubs. However, as presented earlier in this letter, those routes are not well-utilized, and provision
of additional service would not increase ridership substantially.

Transit oriented amenities, such as express service, park & ride lots, and shuttles are an
important part of encouraging transit ridership in lower-density areas. Those services are already
in place, and data suggests that adding capacity in the immediate area of the project would not
substantially increase transit ridership to a quantity that would justify the cost and impact of the
additional amenities.

3. We recall at our previous meeting that you said you would submit the traffic counts
   from south of Crespi, so that we may get a better sense of how many cars are traveling
   to the area from south of Pacifica. Please provide Commission staff with those traffic
   counts.

These counts are attached to this letter in Appendix A. The counts generally indicate that
approximately 25 percent of peak hour traffic traveling through the study corridor is from SR 1
south of Linda Mar Avenue.

2
    Based on a September 2009 weekday count after 9 AM
Mr. Joe Hurley
December 8, 2009
Page 9 of 11




4. It appears that a large portion of the congestion comes from traffic generation south of
   Fassler Avenue. Please include an analysis of the feasibility of increasing transit
   services from south of the project site to job centers, including from Montara and
   HMB.

Route 294 currently operates between the Linda Mar Park & Ride and the Hillsdale Caltrain
Station. Potential riders can take this route north, to connect with express bus service to BART
stations, or southeast, to connect with Caltrain. Since this route operates at less than 50 percent
capacity during both peak hours, it suggests that, while additional service may increase ridership
marginally, it would not have a substantial effect at reducing overall traffic generation. For
example, even if transit ridership on the corridor serving areas south of Pacifica were doubled or
even tripled, the result would be a reduction in auto travel of less than 30 vehicles per hour. This
would have a negligible effect at overall congestion reduction, but would come at considerable
cost to Samtrans.

Secondly, as also noted earlier, the severe financial constraints of operating a transit agency
generally require that transit investments be made in higher-density areas where there are more
potential riders to get the greatest reduction in traffic, or to provide life-line systems that provide
the only means of transportation for transit-dependent individuals. Although like most transit
operators today, Samtrans is currently looking for ways to cut its budget rather than increase it,
should funds become available for additional transit services, the areas south of the project site
would not be the most efficient target for service improvements to maximize the overall transit
ridership.

5. Please provide a more complete analysis of the feasibility of providing additional
   school service as a way to reduce VMTs. Is there demand for additional service? If
   so, what measures could be implemented to feasibly meet this demand? In addition,
   please explain the statement in the transit analysis that additional service provided to
   the area would require a reduction elsewhere in the system.

Based on ridership numbers presented by SamTrans, while the school "tripper" service does
operate at higher capacity levels than other service in the area, it is not operating at levels high
enough to suggest demand is being suppressed by limited capacity. Therefore, providing
increased service would not produce a substantial increase in riders compared to the existing
situation. Additionally, school traffic typically affects only the morning peak period. Providing
additional tripper service would not provide any effect to the severe PM peak period congestion in
the area.

Finally, the previous memo prepared by Samtrans noted that additional service provided to this
area would require a reduction somewhere else in the system. That statement was made in
recognition that Samtrans operates with a very limited and fixed budget. In order to fund service
enhancements in the study area, cost savings would likely have to be made in other locations.
Given the discussion and analysis above regarding the efficacy of enhanced transit service in this
study area, this trade-off would be undesirable.
Mr. Joe Hurley
December 8, 2009
Page 10 of 11




6. Please provide an analysis of the feasibility and benefits (including estimated
   reduction of VMT) that would result from developing a formal carpooling and rideshare
   program. This analysis should include the reduction in congestion that could be
   expected to result from a carpool program in combination with an HOV lane.

The San Mateo County Transportation Authority already operates a formal carpooling and
rideshare program. Further, new developments are required to participate in the program and to
provide additional "Transportation Demand Management" (TDM) measures to reduce peak period
automobile travel. Therefore, the benefits of such programs are already realized. Without them,
conditions would be worse than those analyzed.

Further, we have examined the feasibility of converting one of the proposed travel lanes in the
study corridor to an HOV lane. Implementing an HOV lane for such a short roadway segment
would not be practical. To be beneficial, HOV lanes typically need to be implemented over much
longer distances to provide sufficient benefit to justify their cost. In addition, the existing project
configuration will present some geometric design and operational challenges in terms of providing
separation from the HOV lanes and turn lanes at the intersections within the project area. Setting
aside the above geometric challenges, we have considered two possible HOV lane bypass
scenarios.

First, if the currently-proposed footprint of the project were maintained, vehicle queuing would be
similar to that identified for the "No Project" scenario. Therefore, all vehicles would have to wait in
relatively long queues approaching the widened roadway. HOV's would be able to bypass the
portion of the queue where the roadway is currently proposed to be widened. The travel time
benefits of this small queue bypass would be relatively small (likely less than 5 percent of total trip
times), and not enough to cause a mode shift, in which more people would carpool. Therefore,
the project would incur the same construction cost and overall increases to the roadway footprint
as currently proposed, but with benefits limited to a small group of users.

The second scenario would involve constructing the HOV lane to bypass the entirety of the
queue. This would provide substantial travel time advantages for HOV's over SOV's. However,
the shift in the number of people who carpool versus existing conditions would be relatively small,
and the overall size and cost of the project would be substantially larger. Because this would
increase the overall amount of pavement for a relatively small benefit, this scenario would not be
desirable.

Therefore, neither of the HOV lane scenarios appears to be viable.

7. Please provide a transit map that shows all of the mentioned routes, and show how the
   school routes work to serve the school.

A transit map is provided in Appendix B.
Mr. Joe Hurley
December 8, 2009
Page 11 of 11




8. Please explain how the average weekday ridership figures are determined, and the
   time range that the figures represent (e.g. are they monthly figures? Yearly? Are 2008
   and 2009 represented?)

The average weekday ridership figures presented in previous memo were average daily
boardings. These volumes were compared to more recent data, collected in April 2009, and were
found to be similar. Table 1 shows the average weekday ridership figures from the month of April
2009.

9. What is the status of the SamTrans comprehensive operational analysis (COA)? And,
   are there any updates to the traffic analysis emanating from this work?

The SamTrans Comprehensive Operational Analysis (COA) is still in the scoping phase to
determine metrics such as cost effectiveness, service coverage, headways, and frequency for
transit service. The service evaluation is expected to begin in February 2010 and last for 12
months, with the implementation plan to follow in February 2011.

10. Finally, how does the Transportation Authority view this project in relation to the
    various pieces of recent legislation calling for the reduction of greenhouse gases (e.g.
    AB 32, SB 375, etc.)?

As discussed under the supplemental simulation analysis, this project is forecasted to reduce
overall GHG emissions because it would improve overall traffic stability and reducing idling or
traveling at low speeds.



We hope you have found this information useful. We look forward to meeting with you and the
CCC on Monday, December 14 to discuss this information.

Sincerely,

FEHR & PEERS




Chris Mitchell, P.E.
Senior Associate



Matt Plumb, P.E.
Transportation Engineer

                                               AMENDMENT
                      SAN MATEO COUNTY SUPERINTENDENT OF SCHOOLS AGREEMENT
                          WITH INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR FOR SR2S ACTIVITIES
                                    AT PACIFICA SCHOOL DISTRICT
                                        July 1, 2012 to June 30, 2013

Contractor Name and Address:                                                    Contractor: Upon completion of work or agreed-upon work
                                                                                periods, mail invoice with above Agreement Number to:
Alta Planning & Design
                                                                                Department: Safe Routes to Schools
2560 9th Street, Suite 212
                                                                                Attention: Daina Lujan
Berkeley, CA 94710
                                                                                Address: San Mateo County Office of Education_____________

                                                                                101 Twin Dolphin Drive

                                                                                City, State, Zip: Redwood City, CA 94065-1064

It is agreed between the San Mateo County Superintendent of Schools, San Mateo, California, ("Superintendent") and Contractor as follows:

1.   Services to be performed by Contractor In consideration of the payments hereinafter set forth, Alta Planning & Design, hereinafter
     referred to as the Contractor, shall perform for the Superintendent map development and grant application facilitation for the Pacifica
     School District. The contractor shall develop six school specific, draft walk and bike route maps. The contract shall then circulate and
     revise draft maps based on stakeholder input. Deliverables shall include 1 (one) community meeting, 6 (six) routes maps in both draft
     and finalized forms. The contractor shall also prepare (1) one Safe Routes to School grant application for school route related
     improvements. The contractor will work with key stakeholders, to include, but not limited to, City staff, school district staff, law
     enforcement and other agencies as applicable to facilitate the development of the grant proposal. Deliverables shall include 1 (one) grant
     application in both draft and finalized form. The contractor will also conduct 1 (one) traffic study at Vallemar Elementary School.
     Deliverables shall include 1 (one) draft traffic count memo and 1 (one) final traffic count memo. See Exhibits "A" and "B" (Scope of
     Work) attached hereto for a detailed description of the Route Map/Grant Application. Contractor shall ensure compliance with all state,
     federal and local laws, regulations or rules applicable to performance of the work required under this contract.

2.   Contract Term The term of this Agreement shall be from July 1, 2012 to June 30, 2013 unless terminated earlier by the
     Superintendent.

3.   Payments In consideration of the services rendered in accordance with all terms, conditions and specifications set forth herein and in
     Exhibits "A" and "B", Superintendent shall make payment to Contractor in the amount of $27, 400 (TWENTY-SEVEN THOUSAND
     FOUR HUNDRED DOLLARS) 33,800 (THIRTY-THREE THOUSAND EIGHT HUNDRED DOLLARS). In the event that the
     Superintendent makes any payments for services in advance of the provision of such services, Contractor agrees to refund any amounts
     in excess of the amount owed by the Superintendent at the time of contract termination. The Superintendent reserves the right to
     withhold payment if the Superintendent determines that the quantity or quality of the work performed is unacceptable. In no event shall
     total payment for services under this Agreement exceed $27, 400 (TWENTY-SEVEN THOUSAND FOUR HUNDRED DOLLARS)
     33,800 (THIRTY-THREE THOUSAND EIGHT HUNDRED DOLLARS).

4.   Relationship of the Parties Contractor agrees and understands that the work/services performed under this Agreement are performed as
     an Independent Contractor and not as an employee of the San Mateo County Office of Education or the Superintendent and that
     Contractor acquires none of the rights, privileges, powers or advantages of such employees.

5.   Workers' Compensation Insurance The Contractor shall have in effect, during the entire life of this Agreement, Worker's
     Compensation and Employer Liability Insurance providing full statutory coverage. In signing this Agreement, Contractor certifies
     awareness of the provisions of section 3700 of the California Labor Code which requires every employer to be insured against liability
     for Worker's Compensation or to undertake self-insurance in accordance with the provisions of the Code, and certifies compliance with
     such provisions before commencing the performance of this work of the Agreement as set forth in California Labor Code section 1861.

6.   Insurance The Contractor shall take out and maintain during the life of this Agreement such Bodily Injury Liability and Property
     Damage Liability Insurance as shall protect him/her while performing work covered by this Agreement from any and all claims for
     damages for bodily injury, including accidental death, as well as any and all operations under this Agreement, whether such operations
     be by himself/herself or by any Subcontractor or by anyone directly or indirectly employed by either of them. Such insurance shall be
     combined single limit bodily injury and property damage for each occurrence and shall not be less than $1,000,000.

7.   Hold Harmless Contractor agrees to indemnify and defend the Superintendent and County Office of Education and its employees and
     agents from any and all claims, damages and liability in any way occasioned by or arising out of the negligence of Contractor in the
     performance of this Agreement, including any sanctions, penalties or claims of damages resulting from Contractor's failure to comply

                                                                                                                                             1
     with the requirements set forth in the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) and all Federal regulations
     promulgated thereunder, as amended.

8.   Confidentiality All data produced or compiled by Contractor shall be considered confidential unless it can be obtained as public record
     and shall not be shared with a third party without the prior written consent of Superintendent. All financial, statistical, personal,
     technical, and other data and information relating to the County Office of Education's operations which is made available to the
     Contractor in order to carry out this Agreement shall be presumed to be confidential. Contractor shall protect said data and information
     from unauthorized use and disclosure. Contractor shall not, however, be required by this paragraph to keep confidential any data or
     information, which is or becomes publicly available, is already rightfully in Contractor's possession, is independently developed by
     Contractor outside the scope of the Agreement or is rightfully obtained from third parties.

9.   Non-Assignability Contractor shall not assign this Agreement or any portion thereof to a third party without the prior written consent of
     Superintendent, and any attempted assignment without such prior written consent in violation of this Section shall automatically
     terminate this Agreement.

10. Termination of Agreement Superintendent may, at any time from execution of Agreement, terminate this Agreement, in whole or in
    part, for the convenience of the County Office of Education, by giving written notice specifying the effective date and scope of such
    termination. Termination shall be effective on a date not less than thirty days from notice. In the event of termination, all finished or
    unfinished documents, data, studies, maps, photographs, reports, and materials (hereafter referred to as materials) prepared by Contractor
    under this Agreement shall become the property of the County Office of Education and shall be promptly delivered to the County Office
    of Education. In the event of termination, Contractor shall be paid for all work satisfactorily performed until termination, except where
    the Superintendent determines the quality or quantity of the work performed is unacceptable. Such payment shall be that portion of the
    full payment, which is determined by comparing the work/services completed to the work/services required by the Agreement.

11. Payment of Permits/Licenses It shall be the Contractor's responsibility to obtain any license, permit or approval required from any
    agency for work/services to be performed at his/her own expense, prior to commencement of said work/services or forfeit any right to
    compensation under this Agreement.

12. Non-Discrimination No person shall be excluded from participation in, denied benefits of, or be subject to discrimination under this
    Agreement on the basis of their race, color, religion, national origin, age, sex, sexual orientation, pregnancy, childbirth or related
    conditions, medical condition, mental or physical disability or veteran's status. Contractor shall ensure full compliance with federal, state
    and local laws, directives and executive orders regarding non-discrimination for all employees and Subcontractors under this Agreement.
    Contractor shall comply fully with the non-discrimination requirements required by 41 CFR 60-741.5(a), which is incorporated herein as
    if fully set forth.

     Violation of the non-discrimination provisions of this Agreement shall be considered a breach of this Agreement and may subject the
     Contractor to penalties, including but not limited to: i) termination of this Agreement; ii) disqualification of the Contractor from bidding
     on or being awarded a County Office of Education contract for a period of up to 3 years; iii) liquidated damages of $2,500 per violation;
     iv) imposition of other appropriate contractual and civil remedies and sanctions, as determined by the Superintendent.

     To effectuate the provisions of this paragraph, Superintendent shall have the authority to: i) examine Contractor's employment records
     with respect to compliance with this paragraph; ii) set off all or any portion of the amount described in this paragraph against amounts
     due to Contractor under the Contract or any other Contract between Contractor and Superintendent.

     Section 504 applies only to contractors who are providing services to members of the public. Contractor shall comply with Section 504
     of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which provides that no otherwise qualified handicapped individual shall, solely by reason of a
     disability, be excluded from the participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination in the performance of this
     contract.

13. Equal Benefits With respect to the provision of employee benefits, Contractor shall comply with the County Ordinance which prohibits
    contractors from discriminating in the provision of employee benefits between an employee with a domestic partner and an employee
    with a spouse.

14. Retention of Records Contractor shall maintain all records related to this Agreement for no less than three years after Superintendent
    makes final payment or after termination of this contract and all other pending matters are closed. All records shall be subject to the
    examination and/or audit by agents of the County Office of Education, the State of California and/or Federal grantor agencies.

15. Merger Clause This Agreement, including Exhibits "A" and "B" attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference, constitutes the
    sole Agreement of the parties hereto and correctly states the rights, duties, and obligations of each party as of this document's date. Any
    prior agreement, promises, negotiations, or representations between the parties not expressly stated in this document are not binding. All
    subsequent modifications shall be in writing and signed by the Superintendent or her authorized designee. In the event of a conflict
    between the terms, conditions, or specifications set forth herein and those in Exhibit "A" and "B" attached hereto, the terms, conditions,
    or specifications set forth herein shall prevail. This Agreement, or facsimile proposal of the Agreement, constitutes the entire Agreement
    between Superintendent and Contractor. Further, liability referenced to in section 6 is limited to Contractor's negligence during the
    Contractor's performance under this contract.

                                EXHIBIT A
                  SCOPE OF WORK TO BE PERFORMED
           BY ALTA PLANNING FOR PACIFICA SCHOOL DISTRICT
                       July 1, 2012 to June 30, 2013
Task 1: Suggested Walking and Bicycling Routes to School Map

Alta will develop a Suggested Walking and Bicycling Routes to School Map for six Pacifica School District
schools.

Alta will facilitate one meeting to gather staff, parent, and community member input on suggestions for
recommended routes. Alta will then develop one school site specific map for each of the six schools. Each map
will show suggested walking and bicycling routes to school for up to a one-mile radius from the campus. All
maps will include key traffic controls, bicycle facilities, recommended crossing locations, school access points
and drop off and pick up recommendations.

Alta will deliver six Draft Suggested Walking and Bicycling Routes to School Maps for comment by
stakeholders. Alta will revise the six maps based on a single set of comments and provide six Final Suggested
Walking and Bicycling Routes to School Maps. Maps will be provided in PDF format.

Task #1 Deliverables
    · One (1) community meeting
    · Six (6) Draft Suggested Routes to School Maps (pdf)
    · Six (6) Final Suggested Routes to School Maps

Task #1 Schedule
Services to be provided by June 30, 2013
   · One (1) community meeting
   · Six (6) Draft Suggested Routes to School Maps (pdf)
   · Six (6) Final Suggested Routes to School Maps

Task #1 Fee Schedule
Route Maps (6 @ $4,000)                                                      $24,000

Task 2: Grant Application
Alta will prepare one SR2S grant application for school related improvements. Alta will work with staff
to confirm the recommended infrastructure improvements and refine the preliminary engineering
specifications and cost estimates and prepare an updated Improvement Plan for inclusion in the grant
application. Final cost estimates will be reviewed and approved by the City and school district.

Alta will work closely with staff to develop the schedule, project descriptions, cost estimates and other
supporting documentation. Alta will work with City staff, law enforcement, school district and other
agencies for necessary letters of support and signatures for the grant application as needed.
Alta will submit an electronic draft grant application for staff review. Based on comments Alta will make
necessary revisions to the grant as requested by the City and school district, and provide the school district with
an electronic version of the final grant, in PDF and Word form, for printing and submittal.

Task #2 Deliverables
   · Draft Grant Application
                                                                                                                   4
   ·   Final Grant Application

Services to be provided by June 30, 2013
   · 1 (one) final grant application

                               EXHIBIT B
                 SCOPE OF WORK TO BE PERFORMED
          BY ALTA PLANNING FOR PACIFICA SCHOOL DISTRICT
                      July 1, 2012 to June 30, 2013
Task 1: Traffic Counts at Vallemar School
Alta will conduct A.M. peak hour motor vehicle, pedestrian, and bicycle counts in the vicinity of Vallemar
school to document the school-related traffic volumes. Traffic counts, collecting all vehicle, pedestrian, and
bicycle movements will be conducted between 7 A.M. and 9 A.M. on a Tuesday and Thursday at the following
locations:

  Highway 1 and Reina Del Mar
  P-town Café / 76 Gas Station
  Reina Del Mar at Lauren Avenue
  Reina Del Mar at Hillside Drive
  Reina Del Mar at school entrance/Reichling Avenue

Pending completion of the counts, Alta will summarize our findings in a draft and final memo. Memo will
include a summary of vehicle, pedestrian, and bicycle volumes and movements at the five count locations,
and an estimate of the number of motor vehicles accessing Vallemar school from Highway 1.

Task #1 Deliverables
  Peak hour traffic counts from 7 A.M. to 9 A.M. (2 days at 5 locations)
  Draft Summary of Counts Memo
  Final Summary of Counts Memo

This page intentionally left blank.




iv | Pacifica School District
                                                                                          Introduction




1. Introduction
Parents provide a number of reasons for choosing to drive their
children to school, often citing distance, convenience, the ages
of the children, and safety. Safe Routes to School programs
address a number of these obstacles that prevent students from
walking and biking to school.
The Pacifica School District encourages safe access and active
transportation to school. The purpose of this report is to
identify programs and infrastructure projects to improve
student safety and encourage walking and biking to school.
This report presents infrastructure and programmatic projects
recommended to improve student safety and access to the six
Pacifica School District schools shown in Figure 1-1, including:
    ·   Cabrillo Elementary School
    ·   Ingrid B. Lacy Middle School
    ·   Ocean Shore Elementary School
    ·   Ortega Elementary School
    ·   Sunset Ridge Elementary School
    ·   Vallemar Elementary School

Walk audit teams included Alta Planning + Design staff, the
school principals, and concerned parents. Audits were
conducted at each school either during morning drop-off or
afternoon pick-up. Each visit began with a discussion of
current challenge areas and what types of issues observers pay
attention to. The team then observed student access and
reviewed the area near each school for quality of sidewalks,
curb ramps, signage, and other engineering elements and
patterns of activity. Based on the observations and input
provided by school staff and parents, the project team
developed a report of recommendations which are presented for
each school in a narrative and graphical format.
                                                                   Traveling to school in Pacifica
The San Mateo Safe Routes to School program surveyed
students and parents in the Pacifica School District to
determine the baseline mode split and to identify key
opportunities to promote walking, bicycling, carpooling, and
transit use at each of the six schools in the district. Student
hand tallies were conducted in classes, where teachers asked
students to raise their hands if they used a particular mode to
get to or from school. Parent surveys were available online and

                                                                    Safe Routes to School Report | 1-1
Chapter 1


paper copies were sent home with students. This report presents a summary of the results of the student hand
tally and the parent survey for each school and identifies key strategies for encouraging students to walk, bike,
carpool, and use transit.
The report's programmatic and engineering recommendations are based on input gathered at the walk audit
observations and meetings afterward, as well as information from the student hand tallies, parent surveys, and
enrollment maps.
This report also presents district-wide recommendations that address issues observed at many of the schools.
These recommendations, presented in Chapter 8, focus on the other "4 E's" of Safe Routes to School:
Education, Encouragement, Enforcement, and Evaluation.
This report includes the following sections:
1.        Introduction ................................................................................................................................. 1-1
2.        Cabrillo Elementary Recommendations .................................................................................... 2-1
3.        Ingrid B. Lacy Middle Recommendations .................................................................................. 3-1
4.        Ocean Shore Elementary Recommendations ............................................................................ 4-1
5.        Ortega Elementary Recommendations ...................................................................................... 5-1
6.        Sunset Ridge Elementary Recommendations............................................................................ 6-1
7.        Vallemar Elementary Recommendations .................................................................................. 7-1
8.        Pacifica District-Wide Overview and Recommendations.......................................................... 8-1
9.        District-Wide Action Plan ............................................................................................................ 9-1
Appendix A. Example Engineering Devices and Cost Assumptions .................................................... A-1
Appendix B. Suvey and Tally Results by School .................................................................................... B-1



1.1. How to Use this Report
At the heart of every successful Safe Routes to School program is a coordinated effort by parent volunteers,
school staff, City staff, and the Police Department.
For each school, engineering recommendations are presented in graphic improvement plans with
accompanying tables that identify the agency intended to implement the recommendation. Some
recommendations are on school district property, while other recommendations in City right-of-way must be
implemented by the City. Following the school-specific recommendations in this report are district-wide
recommendations, meant to address common challenges. Appendix A presents a summary of school area
signs, crosswalks, and other physical improvements recommended in this report. Appendix B shows the
complete results of the student hand tallies and parent surveys both district-wide and for individual schools.




1-2 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                                  Introduction


How can you use this report?
Parents can use this report to understand the conditions at their children's school and to become familiar
with the ways this program is working to make walking and biking safer.
School district and school staff can use this report to prioritize improvements identified on District
property and develop programs that educate and encourage students and parents to seek alternatives to single
family commutes to school. In many cases, education and encouragement programs require dedicated parent
volunteers to carry them out.
City staff can use this report to identify citywide issues and opportunities related to walking and biking and
to prioritize infrastructure improvements. City staff can also use this report to support Safe Routes to School
funding opportunities such as:
    ·   California Safe Routes to School (SR2S) grants
    ·   Federal Safe Routes to School (SRTS) grants
    ·   Office of Traffic Safety grants
    ·   Bicycle Transportation Account grants

Police department staff can use this report to understand issues related to walking and biking to school
and to plan for and prioritize enforcement activities that may make it easier and safer for students to walk and
bike to school.




                                                                              Safe Routes to School Report | 1-3
Chapter 1




                                 Figure 1-1: Pacifica Schools Map


1-4 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                          Cabrillo Elementary




2. Cabrillo Elementary
   Recommendations
2.1. School Information
Principal:                Scott Carson
Enrollment:               554 Students, K-8
School Arrival:           All grades ­ 8:20 AM
School Dismissal:         Kindergarten: ­ 1:20 PM
                          1st ­ 3rd Grade ­ 2:20 PM
                          4th ­ 5th Grade ­ 2:30 PM
                                                                             Cabrillo Elementary
                          6th ­ 8th Grade ­ 2:40 PM

2.1.1. Layout
Cabrillo Elementary School is located in southern Pacifica on Crespi Drive approximately two blocks
southeast of Highway 1. Surrounding land uses are residential and commercial, with a large tract of open space
directly north of the school. There is a loading zone in front of the school, at the far end of the staff parking
lot. Parents using the loading zone must travel across the campus and through the staff parking lot. School
access points include:
    ·   The main school entrance facing the main parking lot.
    ·   A side entrance facing Crespi Drive.
    ·   A back gate accessed by paths from a small secondary parking lot.

A significant challenge for walking and biking to Cabrillo Elementary is that it is not a neighborhood school
and students enroll from all over Pacifica.

2.1.2. Site Visit
The project team conducted a walk audit at Cabrillo Elementary School on March 27, 2012 during morning
drop-off. The weather was cool with light rain. The bell rings at 8:20 for all grades. The walking audit was
followed by a meeting afterward, which four parents and one student attended.

2.1.3. Loading Zones
There is one official off-street loading zone to allow parents to pick up their children, accessed from Crespi
Drive along the southeast side of the school. This loading zone also serves as the primary parking lot for the
school. Some parents stop short of the zone and turn into a hatched area immediately in front of the school
entrance to drop off their children. In addition, parents frequently drop off their children in two other areas:
along Crespi Drive and in the small parking lot off Crespi Drive immediately to the northwest of the site.

2.1.4. Crossing Guard Location
There is one crossing guard stationed at a midblock crossing across Crespi Drive in front of a side entrance to
the school. The crossing guard is outfitted with a high visibility vest and hand-held stop sign.


                                                                               Safe Routes to School Report | 2-1
Chapter 2


2.1.5. Existing Programs
There is a walk and bike to school day held at Cabrillo School every year in May and October. The school has
an especially high number of parent volunteers, which suggests high potential for walking and biking to
school programs.

2.2. Travel Survey Results
2.2.1. Student Hand Tally Results
Student hand tallies at Cabrillo Elementary were conducted in 19 classrooms, capturing 3,000 trips. Shown in
Figure 2-1, most students travel by family vehicles, with relatively high rates of carpooling. More students are
driven alone in the morning, while they are more likely to walk, carpool, or ride transit in the afternoon.

Parents were asked what barriers keep them from allowing their children walking and bicycling to school. At
Cabrillo Elementary, most barriers concerned traffic safety. Personal safety concerns and scheduled before or
after school activities were also issues. The most frequent barriers to walking and bicycling include the
following:
               ·     Unsafe intersections (10 percent)                       ·   Stranger danger (7 percent)
               ·     Speeding traffic along route (10 percent)               ·   Lack of bikeways (7 percent)
               ·     Too much traffic along the route (9                     ·   Child's before or after school activities (7
                     percent)                                                    percent)

Parents were asked what reasons they would find most compelling to reduce their driving to school. As
shown in Figure 2-4, parents would be most inclined to reduce their driving if they felt their children knew
how to walk and bicycle safely, and if it was easier to coordinate with other parents and children.

Chapter 8



2.3. Issues and Recommendations
2.3.1. Feasibility of Walking, Biking, and Ridesharing to School
The National Center for Safe Routes to School predicts that the majority of students who live within 1.35
miles can walk to and from school, while the majority of students within 2.6 miles can bicycle.1 Since 55
percent of Cabrillo's student enrollment is within a mile and 22 percent between one and two miles, there are
substantial opportunities for students to walk and bicycle. Figure 2-5 shows student enrollment. Few
students currently bike, likely due to steep topography in the area, so shifting trips from driving solo will
likely require a focus on walking, carpooling, and transit where appropriate.
As shown in Table 2-1, most students are currently driven alone in family vehicles, even the 156 students
whose parents reported living within a half-mile of school. The relatively high proportion of students who
carpool, particularly families who live one to two miles from the school, indicates a potential for shifting trips
away from driving alone to carpooling. Very few students currently take transit.


                         Table 2-1: Cabrillo Elementary Mode Split by Distance from School

                            Percent of                                      School                   City Bus/
Distance from School       Enrollment       Walks      Bikes    Driven       Bus       Carpools       Transit      Other

1/4 mile or less                    9%          20%        0%       77%           0%          3%            0%        0%

1/4 - 1/2 mile                     16%          12%        4%       78%           0%          4%            1%        2%

1/2 - 1 mile                       30%          11%        0%       83%           0%          6%            0%        0%

1 - 2 miles                        23%           6%        2%       61%           0%         30%            2%        0%

More than 2 miles                  22%           1%        1%       85%           0%         12%            1%        0%

Total                            100%            8%       1%        77%          0%          12%            1%       0%

Source: Parent Survey Results


The enrollment map shows that the majority of students live to the south of the school and are relatively
clustered, which indicates a potential for many students to participate in walking school buses and bike
trains. Several students live across Highway 101 or east of the school, where the topography is particularly
hilly. In these locations, transit can be encouraged where feasible, and carpooling education and
encouragement has potential.


1 This is based on the finding that people are generally willing to travel about 30 minutes each way, regardless of travel
mode. Assuming a student walking speed of 2.7 miles per hour and a bicycling speed of 8 mph, a child can travel 1.35
miles by foot or 4 miles via bicycle in 30 minutes. However, accounting for stop light interruptions, hilly terrain, and
other factors, the National Center recommends a student bicycling distance target of 2.6 miles.
http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/program-tools/what-distances-are-reasonable-expect-elementary-school-students-bike-
school

                                                        Cabrillo Elementary

Chapter 8



2.3.2. Engineering Improvements
Engineering recommendations are shown and mapped in Figure 2-6. Improvement identification numbers
reference numbers on the figure.

                                                      Main Passenger Loading Zone
                                                      The main passenger loading zone appears to work
                                                      moderately well, aided by the dispersal of parent drop-
                                                      offs at other sites around the school. However, parents
                                                      mentioned that in the afternoon, some parents park in
                                                      the loading zone, obstructing traffic for those who
                                                      simply want to pick up their children.
                                                      Students approaching the school from the south,
                                                      whether they are walking or dropped off by parents
                                                      nearby, cross the entrance to the parking lot where there
   Vehicles exiting the Cabrillo main parking lot     is no crosswalk.
Recommendations (ID #1)
    ·    Stripe a high visibility yellow school zone crosswalk across the entrance to the school parking lot.
    ·    Institute a student valet program where students in 5th grade and above help younger students in and
         out of their vehicles to improve the efficiency of the loading area.
    ·    Enlist a rotating team of parent volunteers to help for a half hour in the parking lot in the morning to
         curb illegal behavior and help move students safely and efficiently into school.

School Grounds
The school connects to a large tract of open space, through which there are several informal trails. The
additional land on the northwest side of the school provides an opportunity to provide an additional
passenger drop-off area if needed in the long term. Bicycle parking is located 225 feet from the school building
and is uncovered, which may cause security concerns.
Recommendations (ID #2 and #3)
    ·    Replace existing bike racks with covered bicycle parking.
    ·    Over the long term, the school could consider establishing an alternate drop-off zone that utilizes the
         abandoned road right of way north of the post office and connects to Crespi Drive at the existing
         secondary parking area. This would require coordination with the City and with San Mateo County.

Crespi Drive
Crespi Drive is the main street serving Cabrillo School. It has one lane in each direction with a two way left
turn lane. Both pedestrians and motorists exhibit disorderly behavior on Crespi Drive. U-turns are common in
both directions, likely because there are very few routes other than the main loading zone that would allow
parents to turn around without making a U turn. There is a midblock crosswalk with a crossing guard across
Crespi Drive but jaywalking is also common, among both parents and students. There are no curb ramps at
either end of the crosswalk.




2-6 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                         Cabrillo Elementary


Adjacent to the school site, Crespi Drive has a yellow hatched area where parking is prohibited. This area
prevents parking in the areas that would most obstruct visibility of pedestrians crossing in the crosswalk.
Motorists generally comply with this regulation. A white curb, designating a loading zone, is striped west of
the hatched area up to the small parking lot northwest of the school.
Parents cited the intersection of Ladera Way and Crespi Drive as a challenging intersection. Because of the
configuration of the streets and width of the intersection, motorists turning onto Crespi Drive may not see
students approaching in the crosswalk from the right.
There is no sidewalk on the east side of Crespi Drive between Peralta Road and De Solo Drive. At the existing
sidewalk and crosswalks, there are no curb ramps.
Recommendations (ID #4, #5, and #6)
    ·   Install curb ramps on the main crosswalk in front of the school site.
    ·   Over the long term, consider extending the sidewalk onto the hatched area in the street. This will
        increase space for walking on a crowded sidewalk and further increase pedestrian visibility.
    ·   Tighten the turning radii at both corners of the intersection of Ladera Way and Crespi Drive. There is
        a drainage inlet on the north corner, but significant amount of space could still be reclaimed from the
        roadway.
    ·   Install a sidewalk on the east side of Crespi Drive from Peralta Road to De Solo Drive. While the
        undeveloped area has a steep cross slope, there appears to be sufficient right-of-way along this
        important corridor.
    ·   Install curb ramps for existing crosswalks at the intersection of Crespi Drive and Peralta Road.

Roberts Road
Roberts Road is the first street to the west of the school off Crespi Drive. It is stop controlled and connects
north to Fassler Avenue. Roberts Road serves as an important parallel route to Highway 1. The road is very
steep and may not be suitable for bicyclists. The roadway design with a striped shoulder and adjacent
properties are not developed which may encourage high speeds. Crespi Drive widens to two lanes in each
direction west of Roberts Road and audit participants noted a student was hit at the intersection of Roberts
Road and Crespi Drive. There is a yellow high-visibility crosswalk on the west leg of the intersection
Recommendations (ID #7)
    ·   Stripe high visibility school zone crosswalks at the north and east legs of the Roberts Road/Crespi
        Drive Intersection. Remove the crosswalk on the west leg of the intersection.
    ·   Install school speed limit signage on Roberts Road.

De Solo Drive
De Solo Drive would be a likely candidate for a walking school bus route as it is a continuous street that
directly connects the school to the surrounding neighborhoods. The crosswalk at the intersection of De Solo
Drive and Crespi Drive is approximately 120 feet wide. The unusually wide turning radius not only encourages
fast vehicle speeds, but directs motorists' attention at a more extreme angle in one direction, reducing their
awareness of pedestrians. In addition, the long crossing distance increases pedestrian exposure.




                                                                             Safe Routes to School Report | 9-1
Chapter 8



There is a park-and-ride lot with unused capacity at the intersection of De Solo Drive and Linda Mar
Boulevard. This parking lot would be a good candidate for a park-and-walk, as there are continuous sidewalks
on De Solo Drive.
Recommendations (ID#9)
     ·     Develop a park and walk program at the existing park-and-ride lot at the intersection of De Solo
           Drive and Linda Mar Boulevard.
     ·     Stripe transverse crosswalks with curb ramps on the west side of De Solo Drive across Arguello
           Boulevard and Fernandez Way.
     ·     Install curb extensions at the intersection with De Solo Drive and Crespi Drive. Enough space could
           be reclaimed in the pavement to create a small pocket park or rain garden. Any treatments along the
           curb should maintain adequate line of sight through the intersection.

Engineering Improvement Summary
Table 2-2 lists the recommended improvements to address circulation issues around Cabrillo School and
Figure 2-6 presents an improvement plan of these recommendations. The project IDs in Table 2-2
correspond to those in Figure 2-6. The table identifies the agency likely to lead the improvement, the
recommended priority level for implementation, and a planning level cost estimate. The priority level is based
on the anticipated safety and circulation benefit, the feasibility of implementation, and the projected cost.
