Chapter 8



2.3.3. Recommended Education, Encouragement and Ridesharing Programs
Due to the relatively flat terrain and high population density directly to the south of the school, Cabrillo
School has high potential for walking and somewhat more limited potential for bicycling. However, the large
number of students living more than a mile from Cabrillo Elementary indicates a need for transit and
carpooling education and encouragement.
The parent survey results indicate that parents would be receptive to programmatic improvements such as
safe walking and bicycling instruction and coordination with other parents and students.

Programmatic Recommendations
Key programmatic recommendations are listed below. These programs and others are described in more detail
in Section 8.2.
A School Safety Campaign implemented through a variety of media outlets can reduce the frequency of illegal
and unsafe driving behavior. Such a campaign would help to address parental concerns about traffic and
intersection crossings as well as unsafe motorist behavior, and would improve safety for students walking and
bicycling to school.
    ·    A circulation map would help to alleviate traffic congestion at Cabrillo Elementary, symbolized by
         blue dashed lines in Figure 2-6. These circulation maps could be distributed via school newsletters
         and websites.
    ·    Walking school buses can encourage families to walk to school together or can enable busy families
         to coordinate with other parents who already walk their children to school. A walking school bus
         should have a regular route and a parent contact to oversee the program. Several possible routes exist
         in the area south of Cabrillo Elementary.
    ·    Carpooling can be encouraged with the use of the 511 SchoolPool Tool, a ride matching service that
         locates families with similar commutes and facilitates coordination so they can commute to school
         together. Cabrillo Elementary has a high density of families who live too far to walk, and with steep
         terrain that discourages bicycling, but who could carpool together to and from school.
    ·    Establishing a park-and-walk at the existing park and ride lot at the intersection with Linda Mar
         Boulevard or at the community center at the intersection of Crespi Drive and Highway 1 (ID #8 and
         #9) would enable parents to drop their children off and either walk the last leg of the journey into
         school or link them with other parents who can complete the journey to school with their children.
         Such a program can disperse congestion through a larger area around the school site and demonstrate
         solidarity with their peers who walk and bike to school.
    ·    Parent and student volunteers can be trained as parent or student valets to manage traffic and assist
         in loading and can significantly improve safety and the traffic flow around schools. Volunteers can be
         outfitted with florescent vests to increase their visibility and denote their role as a school
         representative. While valet duties are not suitable for young children, students in the 4th grade and
         above can act effectively as a valet program when under adult supervision. The student government is
         looking for projects and student valet parking would be an opportunity to contribute to their school
         community.
    ·    Bike rodeos were a consensus recommendation at the parent meeting to teach children to operate
         bicycles safely and confidently. Bicycle rodeos would improve student bicycling skills and would
         likely increase parents' confidence and willingness to allow their children to bike to and from school.

                                                              Cabrillo Elementary

3. Ingrid B. Lacy Middle
   Recommendations
3.1. School Information
Principal:       Tina Van Raaphorst
Enrollment:      612
Arrival:         All Grades ­ 8:57 AM
Dismissal:       All Grades ­ 3:09 PM
Wednesday Minimum Days:
                                                                            Ingrid B. Lacy Middle
                 All Grades ­ 1:41 PM

3.1.1. Layout
Ingrid B. Lacy School is located on Palmetto Avenue
between Shoreview Avenue and Bella Vista Avenue.
Highway 1 borders the school to the east, and the ocean
is approximately 600 feet to the west, resulting in
Palmetto Avenue being the only north-south street
providing access to the school. The Highway 1 exit is
located on Paloma Avenue, the westbound component of
a one-way couplet Carmel Avenue. The staff parking lot
is located along Bella Vista Avenue. Parents can park and
drop off or pick up their children from the loading zone
in front of the school, which enters and egresses onto
                                                                Bicycle and skateboard parking at the school's
Palmetto Avenue. The school does not offer bussing aside
                                                                                north entrance
from a single special needs bus.
While few students walk to school due to access challenges, some students bicycle and skateboard. Racks for
bicycles and skateboards are located behind a gate by the north exit to the school, which is locked during the
day. Students are required to walk their bicycles and skateboards on the school campus from the bus stop.

3.1.2. Site Visit
The project team conducted a walk audit at Ingrid B. Lacy School on March 1, 2012 during afternoon pick-up.
Conditions were sunny with a breeze, although the morning had been rainy. No extraneous circumstances
appeared to influence traffic circulation. Assistant Principal Chido Garcia and one parent participated in the
audit. The group observed school access, traffic circulation, infrastructure in the school vicinity and met with
the School Site Committee to discuss their observations.

3.1.3. Loading Zone
The official loading zone for the school is on a loop drive in front of the school. Few parents were observed
loading students from the teacher parking lot or southbound on Palmetto Avenue. In advance of school


                                                                                     3-1 | Pacifica School District
Chapter 3


                                                         dismissal, parents park or wait on either side of the
                                                         loop road, resulting in a single narrow travel lane. A
                                                         small number of students are picked up on Palmetto
                                                         Avenue south of Paloma Avenue, where parents can
                                                         exit the highway and turn left on Carmel Avenue
                                                         without turning around.
                                                         The school purchased traffic cones to block the
                                                         parking space on the southern approach to the
                                                         crosswalk, in order to preserve visibility. They also
                                                         have an in-street pedestrian warning sign, which the
                                                         school replaced after it was damaged by a vehicle.
 The main loading zone is the loop road, which becomes   While some students were observed crossing
      congested with parked and waiting vehicles
                                                         Palmetto Avenue at an undesignated location, this
                                                         was not a prevalent concern. The northern crosswalk
                                                         was not regularly used.
To the north of the school, students leaving by SamTrans generally used the sidewalk to access the bus stops.
A teacher was on hand to prevent students from leaving the sidewalk while waiting for the buses to load.
Parents leaving the loop drive generally continued north on Palmetto Avenue, with a smaller number making
an illegal left turn. Few students crossed Palmetto Avenue north of the school.

                                                         3.1.4. Crossing Guard Location
                                                         A crossing guard is located south of the school, on
                                                         Palmetto Avenue at Shoreview Avenue. She assists
                                                         students crossing Palmetto Avenue to the south of
                                                         the school and reduces illegal left turns into the loop
                                                         drive, which were observed prior to the crossing
                                                         guard being present.

                                                         3.1.5. Bus Stop
                                                         Many students use SamTrans buses to get to and
                                                         from school. Bus stops are located to the north and
   In-street pedestrian crossing sign and crossing guard south of the school, and bus schedules have been
         on Palmetto Avenue at Shoreview Avenue          coordinated with the arrival and dismissal bells.
                                                         However, on Wednesday early release days students
who bus have to wait until the regular departure time. A Boys and Girls club on the school campus provided
activities and supervision on those days. Students who miss their bus and need to wait for the next bus are
not supervised. Teachers assist with student loading onto SamTrans at the bus stop to the north of the school,
on Palmetto Avenue at Shell Street. Students are not supervised on the buses, and SamTrans does not report
issues on the bus.

in Figure 3-1, most students are driven alone. This school also has the highest use of transit and carpooling
among students, likely because middle school students are older and involved in more after school activities.

When asked about the barriers to their children walking and bicycling to school, parents cited a range of
concerns including both systemic issues such as distance to school and having too much to carry, as well as
traffic concerns such as speeding traffic and unsafe intersections. The most frequent barriers to walking and
bicycling include the following:
                   ·    Too far from school (9 percent)                                ·     Unsafe intersections (7 percent)
                   ·    Speeding traffic along route (8 percent)                       ·     Lack of bikeways (7 percent)
                   ·    Child has too much to carry (8 percent)                        ·     Too much traffic along the route (7
                   ·    Stranger danger (7 percent)                                          percent)

As shown in Figure 3-4, parents at Ingrid Lacy Middle School would find improved transit and school buses
to be the most compelling reason to reduce driving to school, as well as coordinating with other parents to
arrange carpools or other possibilities for school travel. Another important reason for using active
transportation modes would be if their children wished to walk or bike to improve their health.

3.3. Issues and Recommendations
3.3.1. Feasibility of Walking, Biking, and Ridesharing to School
The National Center for Safe Routes to School recommends distance targets that the majority of students who
live within 1.35 miles can walk to and from school, while the majority of students within 2.6 miles can
bicycle. 2 Figure 3-5 shows student enrollment. As shown in Table 3-1. Ingrid B. Lacy Middle has a higher
proportion of students who live more than two miles from school, and the lack of street connectivity resulting
in few walking and bicycling routes to school is a significant barrier to walking and bicycling.


                        Table 3-1: Ingrid B. Lacy Middle Mode Split by Distance from School

                           Percent of                                     School                  City Bus/
Distance from School Enrollment            Walks      Bikes    Driven      Bus       Carpools      Transit       Other

1/4 mile or less                    3%          0%       0%      100%          0%           0%           0%           0%

1/4 - 1/2 mile                      2%          0%       0%      100%          0%           0%           0%           0%

1/2 - 1 mile                        6%          3%       0%       85%          0%           0%         13%            0%

1 - 2 miles                        36%          3%       0%       44%          0%         31%          21%            0%

More than 2 miles                  53%          1%       1%       50%          1%         25%          21%            1%

Total                            100%           2%       0%       53%          0%         25%          20%           1%

Source: Parent Survey Results


School and District efforts should therefore be focused on carpooling and encouraging transit use. The
enrollment map shows that the majority of the school enrollment is located to the north of the school, and
students are clustered relatively densely. This indicates a high potential for carpooling, as families can meet up
and drive together to school.




2 This is based on the finding that people are generally willing to travel about 30 minutes each way, regardless of travel
mode. Assuming a student walking speed of 2.7 miles per hour and a bicycling speed of 8 mph, a child can travel 1.35
miles by foot or 4 miles via bicycle in 30 minutes. However, accounting for stop light interruptions, hilly terrain, and
other factors, the National Center recommends a student bicycling distance target of 2.6 miles.
http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/program-tools/what-distances-are-reasonable-expect-elementary-school-students-bike-
school
                                                                                     Safe Routes to School Report | 9-1
Chapter 8




                                 Figure 3-5: Ingrid Lacy Middle School Enrollment Map




3-6 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                         Ingrid B. Lacy Middle


3.3.2. Engineering Improvements
Engineering recommendations are shown and mapped in Figure 3-6: Ingrid B. Lacy Middle School
Improvement Plan. Improvement identification numbers reference numbers on the figure.

Loading Zone and Surf Street
The loading zone drive is one way and serves as the primary loading location. This area becomes congested
with parents parking and waiting for their children. Congestion would be reduced by dispersing passenger
loading activity to alternate locations. Multiple parents were observed making illegal left turns into and out of
the loading zone drive. Few students were observed crossing the loop drive, and they were accessing vehicles
waiting on the west side of the drive or students crossed Palmetto Avenue at the mid-block crosswalk.
There is an existing high-visibility crosswalk across Palmetto Avenue north of Surf Street with no additional
treatments to heighten pedestrian and driver awareness.
Recommendation (ID #1 and #2)
    ·   Reduce turning radii on both sides of Palmetto Avenue at intersection with Loop Drive and Shell
        Street
    ·   Enforce left turn restrictions
    ·   Install pedestrian-activated Rectangular Rapid Flashing Beacon at the existing crosswalk at Palmetto
        Avenue and Surf Street
    ·   Install truncated domes at curb ramps

Palmetto Avenue at Shoreview Avenue
The main crosswalk across Palmetto Avenue at Shoreview Avenue
is significantly improved by the crossing guard, in-pavement
warning signs, high-visibility markings, and traffic cones
prohibiting parking on the approach. The crosswalk to the north is
midway on the loading zone, although there is no pedestrian
accommodation through the buffer between Palmetto Avenue and
the loading zone. This crosswalk was not well-used, and more
students were observed crossing Palmetto Avenue north of the
loading zone drive exit.
Parents accessing and leaving the loop road from Palmetto Avenue
were observed making illegal left turns. Regardless of which
direction the parent drives from, the parent will want to drive back
in the direction they came from. There are few turn-arounds, and
parents sometimes use Shoreview Avenue to turn, although another
Highway 1 exit is located just north of the school.
Recommendation (ID #3)
    ·   Continue coning off parking on approach to crosswalk.
    ·   Continue crossing guard supervision at the crosswalk. The crossing guard is an essential part of
        circulation and would become increasingly important if more parents used the southbound side of
        Palmetto Avenue for passenger loading as recommended.
                                                                               Safe Routes to School Report | 9-1
Chapter 8




    ·    Install high-visibility yellow school zone crosswalks on south and west legs of the Palmetto
         Avenue/Shoreview Avenue intersection.
    ·    Provide pedestrian warning signage.
    ·    Tighten the turning radius at the southwest corner of the intersection.
    ·    Install truncated domes at curb ramps.
    ·    Enforce left turn restrictions.

Staff Parking Lot and Bella Vista Avenue
Currently, parents are discouraged from parking or waiting in the teacher parking lot located south of the
school on Bella Vista Avenue. This space could be used for loading, but parents are concerned about the lack
of supervision in the parking lot. Additionally the curb ramps do not have truncated domes. Encouraging
parents to load in the teacher parking lot would reduce the number of illegal turns into the loading zone as
well as mitigating congestion in that area.
Recommendations (ID #4 and #5)
    ·    Encourage parents to drop off students in the staff parking lot and station a teacher to assist with
         pick-up and to supervise students.
    ·    Install truncated domes at curb ramps.
    ·    Tighten the turning radii at the northeast and southeast corners of the intersection of Bella Vista
         Avenue and Palmetto Avenue.
    ·    Stripe a high-visibility yellow crosswalk on east leg of Bella Vista Avenue intersection.

Palmetto Avenue between Paloma Avenue and Carmel Avenue
Paloma Avenue provides an additional opportunity for passenger loading in such a way that would disperse
some of the congestion in the school area. However, crosswalks are faded at what would become an important
intersection for any students dropped off or picked up at this location.
Recommendations (ID #6)
    ·    Encourage alternative loading on southbound side of Palmetto Avenue and along Paloma Avenue.
    ·    Stripe high-visibility yellow school zone crosswalk on the west, east and south legs of the
         intersection.

recommended priority level for implementation, and a planning level cost estimate. The priority level is based
on the anticipated safety and circulation benefit, the feasibility of implementation, and the projected cost.

3.3.3. Recommended Education, Encouragement and Ridesharing Programs
Because so few students at Ingrid B. Lacy live within a mile of the school, programmatic strategies should
focus on transit use and carpooling opportunities. Parents should be educated about transportation options,
including SamTrans schedules and routes, as well as the SchoolPool RideMatching tool. In addition, the
school and SR2S program should promote activities and events that encourage bus usage and carpooling.
While modifications to transit and school bus schedules may be difficult to implement, parents may be
encouraged by improvements to the bus stop at the school site and by student education about how to use
transit.
The school should also identify sites for park-and walk programs, which would allow students living further
away to be included in active transportation activities and benefits from Safe Routes to School despite being
driven part way. In addition, all of the students who live within a half-mile of school are currently driven
alone, and improvements to the walking routes as well as education and encouragement are likely to influence
mode shift on these students.
In addition to the infrastructure enhancements described above, the programmatic strategies listed below
would be especially effective at Ingrid B. Lacy School: These programs and others are described in more detail
in Section 8.2.
    ·    A School Safety Campaign implemented through a variety of media outlets can reduce the frequency
         of illegal and unsafe driving behavior. Such a campaign would help to address parental concerns
         about traffic and intersection crossings as well as unsafe motorist behavior, and would improve safety
         for students walking and bicycling to school.
    ·    Carpooling can be encouraged with the use of the 511 SchoolPool Tool, a ride matching service that
         locates families with similar commutes and facilitates coordination so they can commute to school
         together. Ingrid B. Lacy Middle has a high density of families who live too far to walk, and with steep
         terrain that discourages bicycling, but who could carpool together to and from school. Parents were
         unaware of the 511.org SchoolPool Tool, but would consider using it if the tool were advertised.
    ·    Provide reminders of bus schedules and maps to parents in the parent newsletter to encourage more
         students to ride SamTrans to and from school.
    ·    A circulation map would help to alleviate traffic congestion at Ingrid B. Lacy Middle by encouraging
         drop-off in the teacher parking lot and by reinforcing the prohibition on left turns from the loading
         zone drive onto Palmetto Avenue, symbolized by blue dashed lines in Figure 3-6. These circulation
         maps could be distributed via school newsletters and websites.
    ·    Work with police to enforce left turn restrictions and reduce speeds on Palmetto Avenue.




3-10 | Pacifica School District
                                                                 Ingrid B. Lacy Middle




Figure 3-6: Ingrid B. Lacy Middle School Improvement Plan

4. Ocean Shore Elementary Recommendations
4.1. School Information
Principal:        Karen Gnusti
Enrollment:       Kindergarten ­ 8th grade
Arrival:          All Grades ­8:25 AM
Dismissal:        Kindergarten ­ 2:00 PM

                   Grades 1-3 ­ 2:40 PM
           Grades 4-8 ­ 3:00 PM

                   Kindergarten ­ 12:35 PM
                   Grades 1-3 ­ 12:45 PM                                      Ocean Shore
           Grades 4-8 ­ 1:00 PM

4.1.1. Layout
Ocean Shore School is located on a large campus adjacent
to two frontage roads, Oceana Boulevard on the western
perimeter and Monterey Road on the northern perimeter.
An access drive from Oceana Boulevard leads to a teacher
and staff parking lot, as well as a vehicular drop-off/pick
up area at the school's main entrance. The schoolyard and
sports fields are located along the eastern and northern
end of the campus. Students enter the schoolyard through
gates off of Nelson Avenue and Monterey Road. The gates
are locked with a combination lock when the school is
closed. The locked gates on Monterey Road pose a
challenge to pedestrian access to school. Due to the
physical distance from the school to the Monterey Road
gates it is difficult for staff to unlock the gate during
school arrival and dismissal times.
Students commute to Ocean Shore from all over the
district. Due to the nature of a cross-district commute,
the majority of children are driven to and from the school,   The Cabrillo Highway, immediately west of Oceana
though some families carpool. Some students walk or               Boulevard, runs in a trench near the school
bike to and from school. A bike rack in the schoolyard
holds approximately 16 bikes. On the morning of the audit, five bikes were parked at the bike rack. Education
and encouragement programs such as pedestrian safety assemblies, bike rodeos, and classroom competitions
for greatest collective walking and/or biking distance can help turn walking and biking to school a common
practice.


                                                                             Safe Routes to School Report | 4-1
Chapter 4


4.1.2. Site Visit
The project team conducted a walk audit at Ocean Shore Elementary on March 6, 2012 during morning drop-
off. The weather was cold and windy. Principal Karen Gnusti greeted the audit team at 8:00am and described
the circulation and access to the school. The walk audit team observed how students access the school, traffic
circulation, infrastructure in the school vicinity and then convened to discuss their observations.
On the evening of the walk audit, Ocean Shore School hosted a meeting for parents, teachers, and faculty. The
project team gave a presentation on safe routes to school and facilitated a group discussion about the school's
specific safety issues and recommended solutions.

4.1.3. Loading Zones
The school bus drops off students at the school's main entrance. Parents who drive their children to school use
the following three loading areas:
    ·    The access drive off of Oceana Boulevard (formal zone)
    ·    The cul-de-sac at the end of Edgemar Avenue (formal zone)
    ·    The dead-end at Nelson Avenue that leads to a pedestrian gate to the schoolyard (informal)

4.1.4. Crossing Guard Location
No crossing guards currently assist at Ocean Shore School.

4.2. Travel Survey Results
4.2.1. Student Hand Tally Results
Student hand tallies at Ocean Shore Elementary were conducted in 16 classrooms, capturing 1,539 trips. As
shown in Figure 4-1, most student travel occurs in family vehicles, although relatively high numbers of
students walk and carpool to school as well.

Parents expressed a wide range of reservations about their children walking and bicycling to school,
particularly issues that can be addressed through programs, including lack of crossing guards, fear of stranger
danger, and lack of adults to walk or bike with, as well as traffic safety concerns. The most frequent barriers to
walking and bicycling include the following:
               ·     No crossing guards (9 percent)
               ·     Stranger danger (8 percent)
               ·     Unsafe intersections (8 percent)
               ·     No adults to walk or bike with (8 percent)
               ·     Too much traffic along the route (8 percent)
               ·     Speeding traffic along route (8 percent)
               ·     Too far from school (8 percent)

that they would appreciate easier coordination with other parents and students. Parents would also be most
interested in driving less if they were confident in their children's traffic skills or if their child wanted to
improve their health, shown in Figure 4-4.

4.3. Issues and Recommendations
4.3.1. Feasibility of Walking, Biking, and Ridesharing to School
The National Center for Safe Routes to School recommends distance targets that the majority of students who
live within 1.35 miles can walk to and from school, while the majority of students within 2.6 miles can
bicycle. 3 Shown in Table 4-1, Ocean Shore Elementary has a relatively high proportion of students who live
within a mile of the school, compared to other schools in the district. Of the students who live within a half-
mile of school, 23 percent already walk and no students bicycle, likely due to steep topography and a lack of
bikeways appropriate for students. Ocean Shore Elementary also has a relatively high proportion of carpooling
for students who live a mile or more away from school.




3 This is based on the finding that people are generally willing to travel about 30 minutes each way, regardless of travel
mode. Assuming a student walking speed of 2.7 miles per hour and a bicycling speed of 8 mph, a child can travel 1.35
miles by foot or 4 miles via bicycle in 30 minutes. However, accounting for stop light interruptions, hilly terrain, and
other factors, the National Center recommends a student bicycling distance target of 2.6 miles.
http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/program-tools/what-distances-are-reasonable-expect-elementary-school-students-bike-
school

                                                                                    Ocean Shore Elementary

for carpool encouragement to shift families away from driving alone to school.

4.3.2. Engineering Improvements
Engineering recommendations are shown and mapped in Figure 4-6: Ocean Shore Elementary
Improvement Plan. Improvement identification numbers reference numbers on the figure.

                                                            School Parking Lot
                                                            The access drive off of Oceana Boulevard leads to
                                                            staff and visitor parking, as well as the vehicular
                                                            drop off/pick up area at the school's main entrance.
                                                            The eastern portion of the parking lot circulates
                                                            traffic in a one-way flow with angled parking off of
                                                            the travel lane. The western portion of the parking
                                                            lot circulates traffic in a one-way flow to the exit
                                                            onto the Edgemar Avenue cul-de-sac. At this
                                                            egress, there is one travel lane marked with two
                                                            white pavement arrows. There is a "Do Not Enter"
                                                            sign posted at the egress. In addition, there are
                                                            speed bumps along the travel lane to slow down
          The loading loop at Ocean Shore School
                                                            traffic.


                                                              The audit team observed that parents commonly do
                                                              not pull over to the curb, but rather stop in the
                                                              middle of the travel lane to drop off their children.
                                                              The act of stopping and unloading in the drive isle is
                                                              unsafe and frequently causes a backup of cars in the
                                                              drive isle. A parent volunteer stated that the most
                                                              automobile congestion occurs during the afternoon
                                                              pick-up. While the audit team did not notice
                                                              drivers speeding through the parking lot during the
                                                              morning of the audit, school staff reported that
                                                              speeding has been an issue in the past. The
                                                              installation of the speed bumps has helped to slow
                                                              down traffic. Another common issue raised by a
      The one-way parking lot exit at Edgemar Avenue;
   parents often attempt to enter the parking lot from here   staff member are cars and delivery trucks illegally
                                                              entering the parking lot the wrong way (from the
eastern exit) to drive through the parking lot to access Oceana Boulevard. Although there is a "Do Not Enter"
sign posted at the parking lot's egress, the sign is not visible from all vantage points on Edgemar Avenue's cul-
de-sac.
There are several daycares located along the section of Edgemar Avenue immediately adjacent to the Ocean
Shore School. The daycares have morning drop offs between 7:00 to 7:30 am. There is perpendicular on-street
parking on Edgemar Avenue in front of two of the daycares. Parents use the on-street parking and the cul-de-
sac as a loading zone for dropping off and picking up their children. There is high demand for loading zone



                                                                                       4-7 | Pacifica School District
Chapter 4


space during morning and afternoon drop off/pick up times. Ocean Shore School parents and neighboring
daycare parents both use a relatively short street for loading.
Participants who attended the Safe Routes to School audit said Edgemar Avenue becomes a very hectic street,
especially during the afternoon pickup time. Participants noted they have witnessed many near misses of
vehicle/pedestrian collisions.
Recommendations (ID #1)
    ·    Narrow the parking lot exit to one lane and paint a one MUTCD standard size white arrow on the
         exit lane. Make sure the narrowed lane is still wide enough to allow for emergency vehicle access.
    ·    Install a "No Right Turn" sign on the northwest approach to the exit lane from Edgemar Avenue's cul-
         de-sac.
    ·    Organize teams of parent volunteers paired with students from fifth through eighth grades to monitor
         the activity in the parking lot during morning and afternoon drop off/pickup. The teams should wear
         reflective vests to be visible and also to show that they have the authority to point out unsafe driving
         in the school zone.

Oceana Boulevard
Oceana Boulevard is a two lane road that runs
along the school's western frontage. Pedestrians
access the school's main entrance and a bus
stop on Oceana Boulevard. During the evening
meeting, participants reported that drivers who
are traveling along Oceana Boulevard to access
Highway 1 appear to be driving above the
posted 25 mile per hour speed limit. The fast
moving traffic on Oceana Boulevard creates a
challenging environment for pedestrians and
bicyclists.
There are currently no crosswalks at the             The exit lane from the school parking lot onto Oceana
parking lot's driveway entrance and egress onto                            Boulevard
Oceana Boulevard. During the evening meeting, participants reported that drivers who are entering or exiting
the parking lot from Oceana Boulevard commonly do not yield to pedestrians who are crossing the driveway.
The hardware store on Oceana Boulevard is adjacent to the school's parking lot entrance and egress. In the
morning, big delivery trucks use on-street parallel parking on Oceana Boulevard to unload their deliveries to
the hardware store. Parked delivery trucks can block visibility to the school's parking lot entrance/exit, which
in turn, blocks driver's view of pedestrians crossing the driveway and vehicles entering and exiting the
parking lot.
Recommendations (ID #2)
    ·    Install speed feedback sign to the north of the school's entrance on Oceana Boulevard.
    ·    Install high-visibility yellow school zone crosswalks at the parking lot's entrance and exit onto
         Oceana Boulevard.

                                                                                    Ocean Shore Elementary


                                                             · Work with the hardware store owner to
                                                         cone off an area six to eight feet back from the
                                                         school's parking lot entrance to prevent the delivery
                                                         trucks from blocking sight lines to the school's
                                                         parking lot entrance.

                                                         Oceana Boulevard at Manor Drive
                                                         The intersection of Manor Drive and Oceana
                                                         Boulevard is a common route for students
                                                         walking/biking to school. This is a four-way stop

                                                         a school may be yellow. Areas of conflict are
                                                         recommended to have high visibility crosswalks.
                                                         Recommendation (ID # 3)

                                                         Edgemar Avenue is a common route for students
                                                         walking/biking to school. Only the eastern leg of the
The car to the right is parked on the unpaved sidewalk
  portion, blocking the walking route of this family     intersection has a high-visibility crosswalk; other
                                                         intersection legs have no crosswalks. During the
                                                         evening meeting, participants expressed the desire to
                                                         channel students who are walking or biking to
                                                         school via Manor Drive and Edgemar Avenue to
                                                         western side of the Edgemar Avenue cul-de-sac. The
                                                         current crosswalk on the eastern leg of the
                                                         intersection forces children to the eastern side of the

                                                         eventually have to cross the street without the safety

  Student bicyclists crossing Manor Drive at Edgemar     intersection.
                         A



                                                                                    4-9 | Pacifica School District
Chapter 4


There is a 7-11 Store at the corner of Manor Drive and Edgemar Avenue that is very busy in the morning with
adults and students. The sidewalk on the eastern edge of the 7-11 Store's parking lot is surfaced with loose
crushed gravel, which is not an ADA accessible walking surface. During the walk audit, the team noticed a car
was parked on the sidewalk, thus blocking the safe pedestrian route to Ocean Shore School via Edgemar
Avenue. If the sidewalk was upgraded from gravel to concrete, it would look like an official sidewalk rather
than an informal parking space.
Commercial driveways along the northern side of Manor Drive between Edgemar Avenue and Oceana
Boulevard are ill-defined and wide. Students commonly walk along the northern side of Manor Drive to access
the school. The lack of defined driveways presents a safety challenge for pedestrians walking along this side of
Manor Drive.
Recommendations (ID # 4)
    ·    Remove the crosswalk on the eastern leg of the intersection and install high-visibility yellow school
         zone crosswalks at the northern, western, and southern legs of the intersection.
    ·    Upgrade sidewalk on Edgemar Avenue along the 7-11 Store's frontage from crushed gravel to concrete
         pavement.
    ·    Work with the City and 7-11 Store owner to reduce width of driveways along northern side of Manor
         Drive between Edgemar Avenue and Oceana Boulevard.

Oceana Boulevard at Monterey Road
The curb radius at the southeast corner of Oceana Boulevard and Monterey Road is very wide which
encourages drivers to turn the corner onto Monterey Road at unsafe speeds. In the morning and afternoon,
students are commonly crossing Monterey Road to get to the school, the bus stop on Oceana Boulevard, or
their home. Cars turning the corner onto Monterey Road are commonly travelling too fast to stop quickly for
pedestrians crossing the street.
Recommendation (ID # 5)
    ·    Reduce the radius at the southeast corner of Oceana
         Boulevard and Monterey Road to encourage drivers to
         slow down as they turn onto Monterey Road.

Monterey Road at Waterford Street
The intersection of Monterey Road and Waterford Street is a
common route for students walking/biking to school and to the
nearby bus stops on Waterford Street and Oceana Boulevard.
Students and parents walking from Waterford Street enter the
schoolyard through a pedestrian gate off of Monterey Road.
Audit participants noted drivers on Monterey Road who are
eager to get on the highway are often driving above the speed
limit. Currently, there is no crosswalk on Monterey Road at the
Waterford Street intersection. The combination of speeding
cars and lack of a crosswalk makes this a challenging                    One of the two pedestrian gates on
pedestrian crossing.                                                               Monterey Road



4-10 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                    Ocean Shore Elementary


About 120 feet to the east of the intersection, there is a yellow high-visibility crosswalk on Monterey Road
that leads to a gate at the northeast corner of the schoolyard. The crosswalk is paired with a school crossing
sign. The north end of the crosswalk leads into a residential driveway ramp and the south end of the
crosswalk doesn't have a curb ramp. In addition, a stair connection is the only formal access to the schoolyard
gate.
Recommendations (ID # 6)
    ·   Install a speed feedback sign on Monterey Road.
    ·   Remove existing crosswalk on Monterey Road.
    ·   Stripe a high-visibility yellow crosswalk approximately 20 feet west of existing crosswalk, with curb
        ramps at both ends.
    ·   Install Assembly D signage 100 feet in advance of crossing and Assembly B signage and pedestrian-
        activated Rectangular Rapid Flashing Beacons (RRFBs) at the crossing.
    ·   Conduct a warrant study for a three-way stop control for the intersection of Monterey Road and
        Waterford Street to see if a stop sign is warranted.

Johnson Avenue at Nelson Avenue
Students and parents access the schoolyard through a pedestrian gate at the end of Nelson Avenue. Drivers
often use the dead end of Nelson Avenue as an informal loading/unloading area. This is a hectic loading zone,
where drivers frequently make U-turns and block access to residential driveways. The vehicular activity in
this area makes pedestrian access and safety a challenge.
Recommendation (ID #7)
    ·   Install "No U-turn" signage for westbound drivers on Nelson Avenue.
    ·   Stripe high-visibility yellow school zone crosswalk in the southern leg of the intersection of Johnson
        Avenue and Nelson Avenue.

Fremont Avenue at Nelson Avenue
The intersection of Fremont Avenue at Nelson Avenue in not an aligned intersection and is uncontrolled for
those on Fremont Avenue. At the evening meeting, participants indicated that drivers travelling on Fremont
Ave often cross the intersection without looking for pedestrians or bicyclists.
Recommendation (ID #8)
    ·   Conduct a warrant study for stop control on Fremont Avenue at Nelson Avenue. Install STOP signs
        on Fremont Avenue, if warranted.
    ·   If not, install YIELD signs and "shark teeth" yield pavement markings.

Engineering Improvement Summary
Table 4-2 lists the recommended improvements to address safety and circulation issues around Ocean Shore
School and Figure 4-6 presents an improvement plan of these recommendations. The project identification
numbers in Table 4-2 correspond to those in Figure 4-6. The table identifies the agency likely to lead the
improvement, the recommended priority level for implementation, and a planning level cost estimate. The
priority level is based upon the anticipated safety and encouragement impact, the projected cost, and the
feasibility of implementation.

4.3.3. Recommended Education, Encouragement and Ridesharing Programs
Because of the numbers of students at Ocean Shore Elementary who live within a mile from the school,
students and parents should be educated about walking and bicycling. The parent survey suggests that
bicycle rodeos and traffic skills instruction in and outside the classroom would help students become more
comfortable walking and bicycling to school. These courses could also emphasize the health benefits of
walking and bicycling to school. The school should also develop a walking school bus program to help parents
living close to one another coordinate, addressing both stranger danger and a lack of trusted adults to walk
with their children.
In addition, the school and SR2S program should promote activities and events that encourage bus usage and
carpooling among students who live further than a mile from school. For the students living further away from
school, coordination programs such as the 511 SchoolPool RideMatching service can be used to find
ridesharing partners.
Key programmatic recommendations for Ocean Shore Elementary are listed below. These programs and others
are described in more detail in Section 8.2.
A School Safety Campaign implemented through a variety of media outlets can reduce the frequency of illegal
and unsafe driving behavior. Such a campaign would help to address parental concerns about traffic and
intersection crossings as well as unsafe motorist behavior, and would improve safety for students walking and
bicycling to school.
    ·   A circulation map would help to alleviate traffic congestion at Ocean Shore Elementary, symbolized
        by blue dashed lines in Figure 4-6. These circulation maps could be distributed via school
        newsletters and websites.
    ·   Walking school buses can encourage families to walk to school together or can enable busy families
        to coordinate with other parents who already walk their children to school. A walking school bus
        should have a regular route and a parent contact to oversee the program.
    ·   Carpooling can be encouraged with the use of the 511 SchoolPool Tool, a ride matching service that
        locates families with similar commutes and facilitates coordination so they can commute to school

                                                                                           4-13 | Pacifica School District
Chapter 4


         together. Ocean Shore Elementary has a high density of families who live too far to walk, and with
         steep terrain that discourages bicycling, but who could carpool together to and from school.
    ·    Parent and student volunteers can be trained as parent or student valets to manage traffic and assist
         in loading and can significantly improve safety and the traffic flow around schools. Volunteers can be
         outfitted with florescent vests to increase their visibility and denote their role as a school
         representative. While valet duties are not suitable for young children, students in the 4th grade and
         above can act effectively as a valet program when under adult supervision.
    ·    Bike rodeos can teach children to operate bicycles safely and confidently. Bicycle rodeos would
         improve student bicycling skills and would likely increase parents' confidence and willingness to
         allow their children to bike to and from school.
         .

                                                       Ocean Shore Elementary

5. Ortega Elementary Recommendations
5.1. School Information
Principal:       Marc Lorenzen
Enrollment:      560 Students, K-5
Arrival:         All Grades ­ 8:30 AM
Dismissal:       Kindergarten ­ 12:30 PM
                 Grades 1-3 ­ 2:35 PM
                 Grades 4-5 ­ 2:50 PM

5.1.1. Layout                                                              Ortega Elementary
Ortega Elementary School is located on Terra Nova
Boulevard, approximately 1800 feet from Terra Nova High School. It is nestled in a residential neighborhood
with steep hills in most directions. There is a one way loading zone through school parking to the main
school entrance. Students access the school site from the loading zone and adjacent sidewalks.
Students commute from all over the city of Pacifica, with most traveling to the school from the south on Terra
Nova Boulevard. Steep hills in all other directions present a barrier to walking and bicycling.

5.1.2. Site Visit
The project team conducted a walk audit at Ortega Elementary School on March 22, 2012 during morning
drop-off. The weather was cool with light rain. The school day begins at 8:30 for all grades. The walking audit
was followed with a meeting during the afternoon, at which school principal, five parents, and one youth
attended to discuss their experience accessing the school and suggestions for improvement.

5.1.3. Loading Zones
There is one official loading zone, but two on-street areas
adjacent to the school building are also used. The official loading
zone is accessed from Terra Nova Boulevard, with traffic
proceeding in a one-way direction around a loop at the front of
the school. There are two rubber speed bumps in the path of
travel. Traffic splits into two lanes in the parking lot, with some
students unloading at the curb and other students unloading in
the middle of the street, assisted by an adult volunteer. During
the site visit, the volunteer was not wearing a yellow vest, though
she usually does.

5.1.4. Crossing Guard Location
There are no crossing guards at Ortega Elementary School. One
                                                                        Ortega Elementary holds "Low Carbon
parent volunteer regularly assists children in the school loading
                                                                        Fridays" to encourage students to walk
zone.


                                                                                    5-1 | Pacifica School District
Chapter 5


5.1.5. Existing Programs
Ortega Elementary School already has a Green Team, headed by a parent volunteer. The school's programs
include a "Lower Your Carbon Footprint Friday" during which students are encouraged to walk or carpool to
school. There are bike racks on the school site, generally used by one or two students.

5.2. Travel Survey Results
5.2.1. Student Hand Tally Results
Student hand tallies at Ortega Elementary were conducted in 17 classrooms, capturing 2,163 trips. As shown in
Figure 5-1, most students are driven in a family vehicles and several students walk or carpool.

Parents expressed a range of reservations about their children walking and bicycling to school. Four of the
parents' top five concerns were related to traffic, including a lack of crossing guards, unsafe intersections, and
traffic speeds and volumes. The most frequent barriers to walking and bicycling include the following:
               ·     No crossing guards (10 percent)                       ·    Too much traffic along the route (9 percent)
               ·     Unsafe intersections (10 percent)                     ·    Stranger danger (7 percent)
               ·     Speeding traffic along route (10 percent)
Parents were also asked which reasons they found most compelling to reduce their driving to and from school.
Their responses are shown in Figure 5-4. Nearly one third of parents would feel more comfortable if their
children knew how to walk and bicycle safely. Other promising possibilities included better coordination
with other parents and students and better transit and school bus connections at the school.

5.3. Issues and Recommendations
5.3.1. Feasibility of Walking, Biking, and Ridesharing to School
The National Center for Safe Routes to School recommends distance targets that the majority of students who
live within 1.35 miles can walk to and from school, while the majority of students within 2.6 miles can
bicycle. 4 As shown in Table 5-1, only 18 percent of students live within a half-mile of school.

Steep topography around Ortega Elementary limits the potential for students to bicycle to and from school.
However, the enrollment map shows that students live in relatively dense distribution to the east and west of
the school. This pattern indicates potential for encouraging students to carpool and take transit where
appropriate.


                         Table 5-1: Ortega Elementary Mode Split by Distance from School

                            Percent of                                      School                   City Bus/
Distance from School       Enrollment       Walks      Bikes     Driven      Bus       Carpools       Transit     Other

1/4 mile or less                   12%          33%        0%       67%           0%          0%            0%        0%

1/4 - 1/2 mile                      6%           0%        0%       80%           0%         20%            0%        0%

1/2 - 1 mile                       27%          18%        0%       53%           1%         25%            2%        0%

1 - 2 miles                        33%           0%        0%       82%           0%         16%            1%        0%

More than 2 miles                  22%           0%        0%       93%           0%          7%            0%        0%

Grand Total                      100%            9%       0%        75%          0%          15%            1%       0%

Source: Parent Survey Results


Because of the large numbers of students at Ortega Elementary who live more than a mile from the school,
parents should be educated about transportation options, including SamTrans schedules and routes, as well
as the SchoolPool RideMatching tool. In addition, the school and SR2S program should promote activities and
events that encourage bus usage and carpooling.




4 This is based on the finding that people are generally willing to travel about 30 minutes each way, regardless of travel
mode. Assuming a student walking speed of 2.7 miles per hour and a bicycling speed of 8 mph, a child can travel 1.35
miles by foot or 4 miles via bicycle in 30 minutes. However, accounting for stop light interruptions, hilly terrain, and
other factors, the National Center recommends a student bicycling distance target of 2.6 miles.
http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/program-tools/what-distances-are-reasonable-expect-elementary-school-students-bike-
school

5.3.2. Engineering Improvements
Engineering recommendations are shown and mapped in Figure 5-6. Improvement identification numbers
reference numbers on the figure.

Main Passenger Loading Zone
Traffic splits into two informal lanes of traffic soon after entering the parking lot. While the zone was
probably not intended to accommodate two travel lanes, it is embedded in travel patterns and likely to make
passenger loading and unloading more efficient. Students are unloaded between two travel lanes which is
generally not a best practice, despite assistance from a volunteer. The width of the passenger loading area
varies from 25 to 26 feet.
Recommendations (ID #1)
    ·    The volunteer assisting with passenger loading and unloading should always wear a reflective vest.
    ·    While not best practice, the two lane loading is preferred by those who participated in the audit. If
         kept, a hatched area between the two loading lanes should be striped. This will provide a landing area
         for students exiting vehicles in the middle of the pavement and provide the volunteer a more secure
         location to stand. Consideration should be given to liability issues that may arise from formalizing the
         two-lane drop-off area.

                                                   Terra Nova Boulevard
                                                   Terra Nova Boulevard is the main street that accesses the
                                                   school. It is a local collector street that also serves Terra
                                                   Nova High School and therefore sees high traffic volumes. A
                                                   SamTrans bus that picks students up for other schools
                                                   stops in front of Ortega Elementary School, boarding at
                                                   8:20.
                                                   Many parents park on the east side of Terra Nova
                                                   Boulevard. They then either walk their children into the
                                                   school site or send them across the street unaccompanied.
School-related traffic congestion on Terra Nova    While there is an existing crosswalk at Lerida Way,
Boulevard challenges motorists and pedestrians.    jaywalking is very common in this location in front of the
                                                   school.
A high volume of school traffic comes from the south and attempts to turn left into the parking lot. Because of
the high demand for access to the loading zone, access is a challenge for those who wish to turn left and traffic
backs up to the south on Terra Nova Boulevard as far as Aspen Drive.
Recommendations (ID #2 and #3)
    ·    Install a high visibility yellow school zone crosswalk across from the school building accompanied by
         an advance warning signage, a Rectangular Rapid Flashing Beacon and advance yield lines to improve
         visibility. A crossing guard should monitor the site, an improvement that would minimize impacts to
         traffic flow. No formalized crossing should be implemented at this location without additional
         improvements.



5-6 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                           Ortega Elementary


    ·   Stripe a red curb at the bus stop on Terra Nova Boulevard to improve visibility and the efficiency of
        transit operations.
    ·   Install curb ramps at Lerida Way.
    ·   Work with St. Andrew Presbyterian Church to establish a park and walk location in the parking lot.
    ·   Stripe a high visibility yellow school zone crosswalk at Alicante Way and install curb ramps.

Lerida Way
Lerida Way serves as the school's northeastern boundary. It
is a steep residential street that connects Terra Nova
Boulevard to Crespi Drive. There are some parents that drop
their children off on Lerida Way, but this practice is
relatively uncommon. A high-visibility crosswalk crosses
the street at Poplar Avenue, connecting to a gate to the
school yard. There is no path between the gate and the
school buildings. Youth sports leagues use the athletic
facilities for games. Parents in attendance at the meeting
suggested that students used the gate during nice weather
but did not like to walk through the field during wet              A pathway from Lerida Way could become a key
weather.                                                              component of a secondary drop-off area.
Developing a secondary drop-off area at this location could
relieve some pressure from the main loading zone. Currently SamTrans buses have a brief layover at the
intersection of Lerida Way and Elm Court. If additional space is needed for a secondary loading zone, the
district should negotiate with SamTrans to establish an alternate location.
Recommendations (ID #4)
    ·   Develop a path from the Poplar Avenue crosswalk to the school buildings. This path could be
        oriented and designed to minimize impacts to the athletic fields by using soft-surface materials.
    ·   Install curb ramps at the Poplar Street crosswalk.
    ·   Encourage the parents of older children to drop their students off at Lerida Way instead of the main
        loading zone. The circulation plan can include routing vehicles up Alicante Drive and Redwood Way
        or down Lerida Way from Crespi Drive. This will
        relieve the pressure on the main passenger loading
        zone and reduce congestion in the school area.

Alicante Path
A path approaches the school from the south on Alicante
Drive. The path is not currently well used, possibly due to
its physical condition and a lack of visibility from the street.
Recommendations (ID #5)
    ·   Ensure that a continuously paved route exists
        between Alicante Drive and the school site along
        this path.                                                   Completion of this path would provide an
    ·   Consider striping a high-visibility yellow school             alternative walking route from the west.


                                                                              Safe Routes to School Report | 9-1
Chapter 8


           zone crosswalk across Alicante Drive to increase access to the path. This crosswalk should include
           Assembly B signage and school crossing stenciling. Alternatively, install a barrier directing
           pedestrians to the crosswalk at Banyan Way.

 Linda Mar Boulevard at Oddstad Boulevard
The intersection of Linda Mar Boulevard and Oddstad Boulevard was cited as a challenging location for
pedestrians and bicyclists. Traffic coming from Linda Mar Boulevard is not required to stop. Because of the
width of the intersection, this turn can be made at fast speeds. Increasing the complexity of the intersection is
that traffic turning right from Oddstad Boulevard is not required to stop, but traffic continuing straight has a
stop sign placed in the center median and STOP stenciled in the pavement. This intersection is located along
the route to school for one of the parents attending the meeting. A common potential walking route to school
would involve crossing Aspen Drive on Oddstad Boulevard, where there is no crosswalk.
Recommendations (ID #6)
     ·     Conduct a warrant study for an all-way stop control.
     ·     Decrease the turning radius for vehicles turning right from Oddstad Boulevard.
     ·     Stripe a transverse crosswalk across Aspen Drive at the intersection with Oddstad Boulevard.

correspond to those in Figure 5-6. The table identifies the agency likely to lead the improvement, the
recommended priority level for implementation, and a planning level cost estimate. The priority level is based
on the anticipated safety and circulation benefit, the feasibility of implementation, and the projected cost.

5.3.3. Recommended Education, Encouragement and Ridesharing Programs
While the school's location and traffic volumes pose challenges to students wishing to walk and bicycle to
school, the Ortega Elementary can build on its existing programs and active parental network to implement
additional measures to encourage walking and bicycling to school safely.
The parent survey results suggest that walking and bicycling education programs could be especially effective
at Ortega Elementary, with one third of parents responding that better student traffic skills would be a
compelling reason to reduce their driving to school. School assemblies and in-classroom activities designed to
teach traffic skills are recommended, along with bike rodeos. Opportunities for coordination between parents
are also promising, suggesting that the school should support a SchoolPool program to encourage families
living close together to carpool or otherwise travel to school together.




                                                                                   Safe Routes to School Report | 9-1
Chapter 8



Recommendations:
    ·    Walking school buses were a popular suggestion among parents.

Programmatic Recommendations
Key programmatic recommendations are listed below. These programs and others are described in more detail
in Section 8.2.
    ·    Establishing a park-and-walk to the south along Terra Nova Boulevard would enable parents to drop
         their children off and either walk the last leg of the journey into school or link them with other
         parents who can complete the journey to school with their children. Locations may include the Terra
         Nova Christian Day Care, the Pacifica Sanchez Library, and the Park Pacifica Shopping Center. The
         school should inquire at these establishments about such a partnership. Such a program can disperse
         congestion through a larger area around the school site and demonstrate solidarity with their peers
         who walk and bike to school.
    ·    Student volunteers can be trained as student valets to manage traffic and assist in loading and can
         significantly improve safety and the traffic flow around schools. Volunteers can be outfitted with
         florescent vests to increase their visibility and denote their role as a school representative. While valet
         duties are not suitable for young children, students in the 4th grade and above can act effectively as a
         valet program when under adult supervision.
    ·    Walking school buses can encourage families to walk to school together or can enable busy families
         to coordinate with other parents who already walk their children to school. A walking school bus
         should have a regular route and a parent contact to oversee the program.
    ·    A circulation map would help to alleviate traffic congestion at Ortega Elementary, symbolized by
         blue dashed lines in Figure 5-6. These circulation maps could be distributed via school newsletters
         and websites.
    ·    Carpooling can be encouraged with the use of the 511 SchoolPool Tool, a ride matching service that
         locates families with similar commutes and facilitates coordination so they can commute to school
         together. Ortega Elementary has a high density of families who live too far to walk, and with steep
         terrain that discourages bicycling, but who could carpool together to and from school.
    ·    Bike rodeos should be held to teach children to operate bicycles safely and confidently. Bicycle
         rodeos would improve student bicycling skills and would likely increase parents' confidence and
         willingness to allow their children to bike to and from school.




5-10 | Pacifica School District
                                                               Ortega Elementary




Figure 5-6: Ortega Elementary Improvement Plan


                                                 Safe Routes to School Report | 5-11

5-12 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                     Sunset Ridge Elementary




6. Sunset Ridge Elementary
   Recommendations
6.1. School Information
Principal:         Ellie Cundiff
Vice Principal: Monicao Lobao
Enrollment:        660 Students, K-5
Arrival:           All Grades ­ 8:25 AM
Dismissal:         Kindergarten ­ 2:25
                   1st ­ 5th Grades ­ 2:41 PM
                                                                          Sunset Ridge Elementary


6.1.1. Layout
Sunset Ridge Elementary School is situated in a residential neighborhood on a hill that overlooks the Pacific
Ocean. Its entrance is on Inverness Drive, a short block up from Hickey Boulevard, a minor arterial road. There
is a parking lot with a loading zone in front of the main school building.
Students access the school site from:
    ·      A pedestrian walkway through the main parking lot.
    ·      A pedestrian path that connects Hickey Boulevard with the faculty parking lot.

The school location presents challenges for walking and bicycling. The site is unapproachable without
ascending or descending a steep hill. A bike rack prominently located on school grounds was empty of
bicycles and administrators generally discourage students from bicycling or skateboarding to school. While
students are located throughout Pacifica, many students live within walking distance, and walking to school
is not uncommon.

6.1.2. Site Visit
The project team conducted a walk audit at Sunset Ridge Elementary School on Thursday, March 8, 2012
during afternoon dismissal times. Weather was warm and sunny. Kindergarten classes are dismissed at 2:25
and all other grades are dismissed at 2:41. All grades arrive at 8:25 AM. The vice principal explained that travel
conditions are not generally worse in the morning than in the afternoon. Five stakeholders attended an
evening meeting to discuss safety and accessibility issues.

6.1.3. Loading Zones
There is one official off-street loading zone to allow parents to pick up their children, located in the main
parking lot off Inverness Avenue. There is an informal passenger loading location at the intersection of
Catalina Avenue and Hickey Boulevard, where a pedestrian path connects the street to the school site. Many
parents park on nearby streets such as Inverness Avenue and Horizon Way.




                                                                               Safe Routes to School Report | 6-1
Chapter 6


6.1.4. Crossing Guard Location
One crossing guard, funded by the school district, monitors the intersection of Hickey Boulevard and
Inverness Avenue. It is a busy three-way stop intersection and the crossing guard monitors all three legs,
generally channeling students to the southeast and southwest legs. The crossing guard is outfitted with the
appropriate vest and a hand-held stop sign.

6.2. Travel Survey Results
6.2.1. Student Hand Tally Results
Student hand tallies at Sunset Ridge Elementary were conducted in 19 classrooms, capturing 2,680 trips. As
shown in Figure 6-1, most student travel occurs in family vehicles. Over fifteen percent of students reported
walking or bicycling to school, which is encouraging for a neighborhood with challenging topography.

                         1/4 mile or less 1/4 - 1/2 mile   1/2 - 1 mile   1 - 2 miles    More than 2
                                                     Distance from School                  miles

                                                Figure 6-3: Trip Mode by Distance to School

When asked about the barriers preventing their children from walking or bicycling to school, parents cited a
range of reservations including the convenience of driving, personal safety concerns, a lack of trusted adults to
accompany their children, traffic safety concerns, and distance from school. The most frequent barriers to
walking and bicycling include the following:
               ·     Driving is more convenient (11 percent)              ·    Too much traffic along the route (9 percent)
               ·     Stranger danger (9 percent)                          ·    Too far from school (9 percent)
               ·     No adults to walk or bike with (9 percent)
Parents were also asked about what reasons would be most compelling to reduce their driving to school. By
far the most common response was better coordination with other students and parents, as shown in Figure
6-4. This likely reflects the challenging distance and topography that make ridesharing an especially
appealing Safe Routes to School program.



   30%                                                                                                               29%

   20%

                           14%               14%              14%              14%               14%
