6.3. Issues and Recommendations
6.3.1. Feasibility of Walking, Biking, and Ridesharing to School
The National Center for Safe Routes to School recommends distance targets that the majority of students who
live within 1.35 miles can walk to and from school, while the majority of students within 2.6 miles can
bicycle. 5 As shown in Table 6-1 and shown in Figure 6-5, the majority of respondents to the parent survey live
more than two miles from the school. However, the survey had a very low response rate and the enrollment
map shows that a number of students live within a half-mile of the school, indicating that strategies to
encourage walking and bicycling may be more effective at this school than at others where students live
further away.


                      Table 6-1: Sunset Ridge Elementary Mode Split by Distance from School

                            Percent of                                      School                   City Bus/
Distance from School       Enrollment       Walks      Bikes    Driven       Bus       Carpools       Transit      Other

1/4 mile or less                   31%          13%        0%       63%           0%         25%            0%        0%

1/4 - 1/2 mile                      0%           0%        0%        0%           0%          0%            0%        0%

1/2 - 1 mile                       15%           0%        0%      100%           0%          0%            0%        0%

1 - 2 miles                         8%           0%        0%      100%           0%          0%            0%        0%

More than 2 miles                  46%           3%        0%       70%           0%         27%            0%        0%

Grand Total                      100%            6%       0%        74%          0%          21%            0%       0%

Source: Parent Survey Results


The steep topography near Sunset Ridge Elementary is a deterrent to bicycling, but programs such as
Walking School Buses could help parents coordinate to walk to school. Walking School Buses can address
two of the principal barriers to walking to school: stranger danger and a perception that there are no adults to
accompany their children. As many parents currently navigate significant traffic congestion at the school site
on a daily basis, it is likely that a few parents may be available to lead walking school buses.
Parents similarly noted that improving coordination with other parents and students would likely encourage
them to walk and bicycle for more trips.




5 This is based on the finding that people are generally willing to travel about 30 minutes each way, regardless of travel
mode. Assuming a student walking speed of 2.7 miles per hour and a bicycling speed of 8 mph, a child can travel 1.35
miles by foot or 4 miles via bicycle in 30 minutes. However, accounting for stop light interruptions, hilly terrain, and
other factors, the National Center recommends a student bicycling distance target of 2.6 miles.
http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/program-tools/what-distances-are-reasonable-expect-elementary-school-students-bike-
school


6-4 | Pacifica School District
                                                     Sunset Ridge Elementary




Figure 6-5: Sunset Ridge Elementary Enrollment Map




                                              Safe Routes to School Report | 6-5
Chapter 6


6.3.2. Engineering Improvements
Engineering recommendations are shown and mapped in Figure 6-6: Sunset Ridge Elementary Improvement
Plan. Improvement identification numbers reference numbers on the figure.

                                                            Main Passenger Loading Zone
                                                            The main passenger loading zone has issues with
                                                            double-parking, congestion, speeding, and unattended
                                                            vehicles. The Vice Principal regularly enforces rules
                                                            regarding unattended vehicles, and parents are
                                                            generally responsive, although one argument was
                                                            witnessed during the walk audit. Congestion is
                                                            worsened by the challenges at the intersection of
                                                            Horizon Way and Inverness Drive ­ motorists leaving
                                                            the parking lot encounter severe congestion at the
                                                            intersection.
   The Vice Principal directs traffic out of the school's
                   main parking lot.
                                                          There is a pedestrian walkway from the street through
                                                          the middle of the parking lot that crosses the loading
                                                          zone in front of the school entrance. The crosswalk has
fairly low visibility, exacerbated by large vehicles that park within the loading zone.
Traffic moves very quickly through the parking lot, especially when motorists stopped in congestion find an
opening and accelerate quickly to take advantage of it.
There are not enough ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act) accessible parking spaces for observed need.
There are three accessible parking stalls, however during the afternoon audit, all were filled, and one vehicle
with a placard parked within the access area between two handicap stalls and one blocking the parked cars.
Another vehicle with a placard was parked along the central loading area.
Recommendations (ID #1)
    ·    Paint the curbs of all legal loading zones white.
    ·    Cone off the staff parking area during arrival and dismissal times. Notify staff that if they arrive
         during those times, they will need to move the cones.
    ·    Increase the number of ADA-accessible parking spaces from three to six. This would ensure that
         parking stalls are available for the people that most need them.
    ·    Consider a circulation plan that disperses students to different locations on the school grounds.
         Fourth and fifth grade students could access the school site from the presently locked gate on
         Inverness Drive that leads to the building with their classrooms. Second and third grade students
         could use the pedestrian path that connects Hickey Boulevard to their classroom building and
         kindergarten and first graders could continue to use the main parking lot. Parents with students in
         multiple grades may park in the designated area for their youngest student.
    ·    The crosswalk connecting the pedestrian walkway through the parking lot to the school entrance
         should be restriped to meet California MUTDC (Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices)
         standards. The curb ramps on either end should have truncated domes.
    ·    Vegetation along the central crosswalk should be trimmed to increase visibility.
    ·    Install speed bumps in the travel lane.

6-6 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                      Sunset Ridge Elementary


Inverness Drive at Horizon Way Intersection
Access to the school is most challenging at the
intersection of Inverness Drive and Horizon Way. The
intersection is also the only entrance to the school
parking lot area. A sign prohibits left turns from the
parking lot onto Inverness Avenue during school hours.
The Vice Principal directs traffic nearly every day at this
intersection, waving motorists on to make right turns.
Many motorists also drive up Inverness Avenue to East
Foothill Drive and loop down along Horizon Way,
causing a high volume of right-turning movements from
Horizon Way onto Inverness Drive.
There are no curb ramps at the intersection of Horizon        There is significant pedestrian demand at this legal
Way and Inverness Drive. In addition to ADA access               unmarked crosswalk. Treatments to increase
issues, many parents walk with strollers to the school                visibility would improve its safety.
site. Accessibility issues are compounded by motorists
parking right along the curb on the corner. Motorists
were also observed parking in locations that blocked
residential driveways.
A sign prohibits pedestrian crossing on the north leg of the intersection. Crossing is not strictly prohibited on
the south leg of the intersection, which is a legal unmarked crosswalk, but students and parents are
discouraged from doing so and instead encouraged to walk down to Hickey Boulevard to use the crosswalk.
Nonetheless, demand for a crossing of Inverness Avenue at this location is very high. Diverting pedestrians to
Hickey Boulevard would involve a 400-foot detour with crossings of the school parking lot entrance,
Inverness Drive, and Horizon Way, which has a high volume of right-turning motorists who may be
preoccupied with finding gaps in traffic approaching from the left. One instance of a motorist cutting off a
child in the crosswalk of Horizon Way was witnessed during the audit.
Recommendations (ID #2)
    ·   Stripe a high-visibility yellow school zone crosswalk on the south leg of the intersection of Inverness
        Drive and Horizon Way. This is a legal crossing with high demand from students and parents. No
        formal crossing should be implemented without dedicated funds for and deployment of a crossing
        guard.
    ·   Hire a second crossing guard to protect this new high-visibility crossing. A well-trained crossing
        guard can help with efficiency for both pedestrians and motorists by platooning pedestrians.

Inverness Drive at Hickey Boulevard intersection
This extremely wide intersection is patrolled by a crossing guard. There are two wide travel lanes in each
direction on Hickey Boulevard, with a curb-to-curb width of 65 feet. As parking is prohibited adjacent to the
corner, this road effectively becomes three wide lanes northbound. The wide cross-section of this roadway
vastly increases the crossing distance for students walking to and from school.




                                                                               Safe Routes to School Report | 6-7
Chapter 6


Inefficient traffic flow results because the long crossing distances by students require that traffic be stopped
for long periods of time at each crossing. Motorists also appear to be confused about appropriate times to
drive through the intersection, the traditional all-way-stop rules being more difficult to follow due to high
pedestrian volumes. Sight lines are poor around the (south) corner adjacent to the school.
The intersection was recently upgraded, with accessible curb
ramps with truncated domes installed on the east and west
corners of the intersection, and yellow transverse crosswalks
upgraded to school zone high visibility crosswalks.
Recommendations (ID #3)
    ·    Install a curb extension on the south corner of the
         intersection. This improvement will increase the
         space available for students on the corner, increase
         visibility between students and motorists on the
         corner, and shorten crossing distances, and reducing
                                                                    A curb extension would create more room for
         pedestrian exposure.
                                                                         pedestrians and increase visibility.
    ·    Install advance stop bars at all approaches for
         improved pedestrian visibility.

Inverness Drive
Inverness Drive is the main road providing access to the school. It has two wide lanes and parking in each
direction, totaling 40 feet of pavement between the curbs, along with sidewalks that are in good condition.
There is a SamTrans bus route that makes frequent stops on the southwest side of the intersection of
Inverness Avenue and Horizon Way. The bus does not pull over to the side of the road during school hours
because of the amount of parked cars.
Outside the school arrival and departure times, audit participants noted that motorists drive very fast on
Inverness. This was also observed between the kindergarten dismissal and the dismissal for older students.
Parents indicated that crossing Inverness Drive was a barrier to walking to Sunset Ridge Elementary. Another
crossing opportunity further to the south on the street would allow children to cross the street without facing
the congestion at the parking lot entrance.
Recommendations (ID #4)
    ·    Install school area signage on Inverness Drive. Pair a school speed limit sign with a speed-feedback
         sign to increase driver awareness and calm traffic.
    ·    Install a school-zone high visibility yellow school zone crosswalk on the south leg of the intersection
         of Inverness Drive and East Foothill with curb ramps and Assembly B signage.
    ·    Consider other traffic calming treatments such as speed cushions.
    ·    Unlock southern gate to school grounds during school arrival and dismissal times

Hickey Boulevard and Path
Hickey Boulevard is a major collector street. It includes two travel lanes and parking in each direction, with
curb-to-curb width totaling 65 feet. There are sidewalks in good condition in both directions. Many students
and parents use Hickey Boulevard to walk to Sunset Ridge Elementary.


6-8 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                               Sunset Ridge Elementary


The intersection of Hickey Boulevard and Catalina Avenue
serves as an informal drop-off area on both sides of the
street. Many children use the pedestrian path that
connects from Hickey Boulevard to the school site. The
crossing is a legal but unmarked crosswalk, and many
parents and students use it to access the residential
neighborhoods to the north or parked vehicles.
The path is well used by students and parents, but the
grade change to the staff parking area is steep.                             Many students and parents meet at the
                                                                          intersection of Hickey Blvd and Catalina Ave
Recommendations (ID #5)
      ·   Install improvements at intersection with Inverness Drive as described above.
      ·   Consider installation of a high-visibility yellow school zone crosswalk at the intersection of Hickey
          Boulevard and Catalina Avenue. This would be an uncontrolled school zone crossing and should
          therefore be marked with Assembly B signage and preceded by "Slow School Crossing" stenciling and
          Assembly D signage. Rectangular rapid flashing beacons should also be considered.
      ·   Over the long term, consider curb extensions on Catalina Avenue, shortening crossing distances and
          increasing visibility for pedestrians.
      ·   Remove change of grade in pedestrian walkway as it crosses the driveway to the faculty parking lot.

Engineering Improvement Summary
Table 6-2 lists the recommended improvements to address circulation issues around Sunset Ridge
Elementary and Figure 6-6 presents an improvement plan of these recommendations. The project IDs in
Table 6-2 correspond to those in Figure 6-6. The table identifies the agency likely to lead the improvement,
the recommended priority level for implementation, and a planning level cost estimate. The priority level is
based on the anticipated safety and circulation benefit, feasibility of implementation, and the projected cost.

6.3.3. Recommended Education, Encouragement and Ridesharing Programs

Programmatic Recommendations
In the parent survey, many parents expressed interest in the implementation of education and encouragement
programs at the school. Parents who attended the school meeting were generally interested in suggestions
such as walking school buses, friendly walking competitions, and school pools.
The school and District should focus efforts on encouraging walking among students who live within a half-
mile of school and facilitate coordination between parents living further from the school to enable carpooling.
Key programmatic recommendations are listed below. These programs and others are described in more detail
in Section 8.2.
    ·   A School Safety Campaign implemented through a variety of media outlets can reduce the frequency
        of illegal and unsafe driving behavior. Such a campaign would help to address parental concerns
        about traffic and intersection crossings as well as unsafe motorist behavior, and would improve safety
        for students walking and bicycling to school.
    ·   A circulation map would help to alleviate traffic congestion at Sunset Ridge Elementary, symbolized
        by blue dashed lines in Figure 6-6. These circulation maps could be distributed via school
        newsletters and websites.
    ·   Walking school buses can encourage families to walk to school together or can enable busy families
        to coordinate with other parents who already walk their children to school. A walking school bus
        should have a regular route and a parent contact to oversee the program. Several possible routes exist
        in the area south of Sunset Ridge Elementary.
    ·   Carpooling can be encouraged with the use of the 511 SchoolPool Tool, a ride matching service that
        locates families with similar commutes and facilitates coordination so they can commute to school
        together. Sunset Ridge Elementary has a high density of families who live too far to walk, and with
        steep terrain that discourages bicycling, but who could carpool together to and from school.
    ·   Bicycle rodeos would improve student bicycling skills and would likely increase parents' confidence
        and willingness to allow their children to bike to and from school.
    ·   Crossing guards have proven to be essential for pedestrian safety and orderly traffic operations and
        extremely popular among parents. An additional crossing guard may be beneficial for Sunset Ridge
        Elementary at Inverness Drive and Horizon Way.
    ·   Due to the small number of surveys received from Sunset Ridge Elementary (14 total), a strategy for
        encouraging a higher response rate is recommended for future surveying.

Chapter 6

7. Vallemar Elementary
   Recommendations
7.1. School Information
Principal:         Barbara Ng
Enrollment:        560
Arrival:           Kindergarten ­ 3rd Grade - 8:30 AM
                   Grades 4th ­ 8th - 8:19 AM
Dismissal:         All Grades - 2:41 PM

                                                                          Vallemar Elementary
7.1.1. Layout
Vallemar Elementary School is located on Reina del Mar Avenue, approximately two blocks east of Highway 1.
It is nestled in a residential neighborhood located within a valley accessible via Reina del Mar Avenue. There
is a loading zone in front of the main building. Staff parking is located in the center of the loop and a small
visitor parking area (Kinder lot) is adjacent to the lower level classroom buildings. Adjacent to Vallemar
Elementary is the Pacifica School District offices. Students access the school from:
    ·      The main school entrance from the passenger loading zone.
    ·      A gate from the school district parking lot.

A significant challenge for walking and bicycling to Vallemar Elementary School is that it is not a
neighborhood school and students enroll from all over Pacifica. Only a small percentage of students live in the
surrounding neighborhood, and Pacifica's neighborhoods are isolated from one another by steep hills and
Highway 1.

7.1.2. Site Visit
The project team conducted a walk audit at Vallemar Elementary School on February 28, 2012 during
afternoon pick-up. The weather was cool and windy, but sunny. Many parents arrived well in advance of the
school bell and waited for their children in the Vallemar loading zone and in the Kinder parking lot. Parents
also waited in the through travel areas of the Pacifica School District offices lot.
Before the walking audit, six parents attended a meeting to discuss their experience accessing the school and
suggestions for improvement.

7.1.3. Loading Zones
The school has one official loading zone on the main loop in front of the school; however circulation through
the parking and loading zone at Vallemar Elementary is complex. Drivers can enter the circulation system
from two points, at the entrance to the main loading zone and the entrance to the school district parking lot.
The main loading zone discharges back onto Reina del Mar Avenue, but motorists entering the school district
office parking lot may choose to continue forward towards the school side gate or turn right into a small
parking area known as the Kinder parking lot which exits with the main loading zone. If continuing forward


                                                                             Safe Routes to School Report | 7-1
Chapter 7



in the school district parking lot, cars return to Reina
del Mar Avenue on a driveway shared with the Police
Department but separated with bollards.
In addition to the formal loading zone and parking
areas, many parents park at nearby locations on Reina
del Mar Avenue or on connecting streets such as
Reichling Avenue and Hillside Drive.

7.1.4. Crossing Guard Location
One crossing guard protects the crosswalk across
Reina del Mar Avenue on the west side of Reichling
Avenue. She is experienced and parents expressed                A vehicle is triple-parked in the School District Parking
appreciation for her efforts. The crossing guard is                                         Lot
outfitted with an appropriate vest and a hand-held
stop sign with flashing lights.

shown in Figure 7-1, most students are driven solo, though many students do walk to school or carpool.

Seventy-one percent of students live more than a mile from school, where the overwhelming majority of

The largest barriers to walking and bicycling that parents identified related to transportation infrastructure,
including unsafe intersections, a lack of bikeways, sidewalks and bike paths, and high traffic volumes and
speeds. The most frequent barriers to walking and bicycling include the following:
    ·    Unsafe intersections (10 percent)
    ·    Lack of bikeways (9 percent)
    ·    Lack of sidewalks and/or paths (9 percent)
    ·    Stranger danger (8 percent)
    ·    Too much traffic along the route (8 percent)
    ·    Speeding traffic along route (8 percent)

When asked about the most compelling reason why they might reduce their driving to school, parents
commonly cited easier coordination with other parents and students, more convenient transit options, or a
child's desire to walk and bike to improve their health. These results are shown in Figure 7-4.

7.3. Issues and Recommendations
7.3.1. Feasibility of Walking, Biking, and Ridesharing to School
The National Center for Safe Routes to School recommends distance targets that the majority of students who
live within 1.35 miles can walk to and from school, while the majority of students within 2.6 miles can
bicycle. 6 As shown in Figure 7-5: Vallemar Elementary Enrollment Map and Table 7-1, a small cluster of
school families live within a half-mile of the school, and the majority of families live a mile or more away from
school.
                        Table 7-1: Vallemar Elementary Mode Split by Distance from School

                           Percent of                                       School                   City Bus/
Distance from School       Enrollment       Walks      Bikes     Driven      Bus       Carpools       Transit     Other

1/4 mile or less                    4%        100%         0%         0%          0%          0%            0%        0%

1/4 - 1/2 mile                     17%          45%      28%        28%           0%          0%            0%        0%

1/2 - 1 mile                        8%          80%        0%       20%           0%          0%            0%        0%

1 - 2 miles                        33%           0%        0%       60%           0%          3%           38%        0%

More than 2 miles                  38%           0%        0%       87%           0%         13%            0%        0%

Grand Total                      100%          18%        5%        59%          0%           6%          13%        0%

Source: Parent Survey Results


Most of the parents who live within a half-mile of school report that their children walk to school and some
ride bicycles. A relatively high proportion of students who live more than one more from school use the city
bus, while several students who live further than two miles from school carpool. The school and district can
shift trips from driving alone by promoting walking and bicycling among students who live within a mile of
school, and carpooling and transit use for families who live further away.




6 This is based on the finding that people are generally willing to travel about 30 minutes each way, regardless of travel
mode. Assuming a student walking speed of 2.7 miles per hour and a bicycling speed of 8 mph, a child can travel 1.35
miles by foot or 4 miles via bicycle in 30 minutes. However, accounting for stop light interruptions, hilly terrain, and
other factors, the National Center recommends a student bicycling distance target of 2.6 miles.
http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/program-tools/what-distances-are-reasonable-expect-elementary-school-students-bike-
school

                                                                                          Vallemar Elementary


7.3.2. Engineering Improvements
Engineering recommendations are shown and mapped in Figure 7-6: Vallemar Elementary Improvement Plan.
Improvement identification numbers reference numbers on the figure.

School District Parking Lot and Kinder Lot
Vallemar Elementary is adjacent to the Pacifica School District office. The District parking lot is the only
entrance to the Kinder lot. The School district parking lot is a one-way loop counter-clockwise around the
building. Both lots were used by many parents on the audit day.
The District parking lot was full during the walk audit. Many parents double-parked to pick up their
children, often well in advance of the school bell. A few instances of triple-parking were observed. There was
an altercation between two parents during the site visit. Exiting the school district parking lot requires
motorists to turn right across another driveway, separated lane of traffic serving the Pacifica Police
Department headquarters.
To use the Kinder lot parents must enter the District lot. This puts most vehicle activity through the school
crosswalk, the main pedestrian path of travel.
Recommendations (ID #1)
    ·   Reconfigure the circulation through the parking and loading areas. The new circulation plan will
        reverse the direction of traffic through the Kinder lot and the District office parking lot, and require
        orienting angled parking spaces in the opposite direction for these areas. This will simplify the
        circulation patterns within the school site and reduce the number of vehicles crossing the highly used
        crosswalk in front of the school. To reduce truck traffic near the school, coordinate with the police
        department to allow trucks, but not passenger vehicles, to exit via the Police driveway.
    ·   Restripe all parking accordingly.

                                           Main Passenger Loading Zone
                                           Enforcement of existing regulations is an issue in the main zone.
                                           While student pick-up areas should have white striping to indicate
                                           loading zones, they are currently striped red, which indicates no
                                           parking or stopping. Motorists park in these areas and as a result
                                           circulation becomes congested. Vegetation is overgrown in some
                                           locations adjacent to the loading zone, decreasing visibility.
                                           Recommendations (ID #2)
                                               ·      Paint the curbs of all legal loading zones white.
                                               ·      Enlist a staff person to monitor the passenger drop-off in
                                                      the morning. This could be a rotating cadre of adult
  This curb should be painted white and
   the driver should not be permitted to              volunteers, or school staff if available. This person should
       leave the vehicle unattended.                  be outfitted with a yellow vest.
                                               ·      Trim vegetation on the west side of the loading zone to
                                                      increase visibility.
                                               ·      Reconfigure the circulation through the parking and
                                                      loading areas as described above.



                                                                               Safe Routes to School Report | 7-7
Chapter 7



Bicycle Parking
Existing bicycle parking is located off the main loop behind a green storage container on the eastern side of
the campus. The existing rack does not meet current security and stability standards, is rusted, and on a dirt
slope that gets muddy in the winter.
Recommendations (ID #3)
    ·    Replace existing substandard bicycle parking on eastern side of the campus with bicycle parking that
         meets current standards. Bicycle racks should be installed on a level concrete pad.
    ·    Install new bicycle parking on western side of campus near the Kinder Lot. Bicycle racks should be
         installed on a level concrete pad.

Reina del Mar Avenue
Reina del Mar Avenue is the only street providing access to the school and surrounding neighborhood from
other parts of Pacifica. It is a two-lane road at most times of the day, but during school arrival times, parking is
prohibited on the north side of the street to allow for a second travel lane. The crossing guard is stationed at
the intersection of Reina del Mar and Reichling Avenue. Parents noted that speeding is an issue in both
directions. There is only one school area sign posted westbound, adjacent to the crosswalk. School signs face
eastbound traffic at the intersections with Hillside Drive and the district parking lot.
Participants and the school crossing guard noted that some motorists run the stop sign at the end of Reichling
Avenue. There is an in-pavement school crosswalk sign at this intersection, but it has been worn down over
time.
Crosswalks at side streets from Reina del Mar Avenue are not marked.
There are sidewalks on both sides of the street from the school property to the west, and both are well-used
by students. The southern sidewalk has one location with a thick, low-hanging tree branch that may present a
hazard, especially to children biking on the sidewalk. Sidewalks are intermittent east of the school site,
ultimately disappearing further up the hill.
Because circulation within the school loading zones can be challenging, many parents were observed
conducting illegal U-turns on Reina del Mar Avenue east of the school, a maneuver whose danger is
compounded by missing sidewalks.
Recommendations East (ID #4)
    ·    Consider placement of speed table to slow traffic
         near school.
    ·    Install sidewalks in the public right of way from
         school up to Winona Avenue.
    ·    Install Assembly D Signage to indicate school
         crossing.

Recommendations West (ID #5)
    ·    Install crosswalk across Reichling Avenue at Reina
                                                                         A parent crossing Reina del Mar Avenue
         del Mar.
                                                                                  without a crosswalk.
    ·    Update curb ramps with yellow truncated domes at


7-8 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                         Vallemar Elementary


        all intersections where missing.
    ·   Trim vegetation along sidewalks.
    ·   Install Rectangular Rapid Flash Beacon and SSX stencils at existing high-visibility crosswalk
    ·   Install school zone signage in both directions well in advance of the crosswalk.
    ·   Consider a school-zone high visibility crosswalk with Rectangular Rapid Flash Beacon at the
        intersection of Lauren Avenue and Reina del Mar Avenue. Install Assembly B and Assembly D
        signage.

Cabrillo Highway Intersection
                                                California State Highway 1, also known as the Cabrillo
                                                Highway, runs up the spine of the City of Pacifica. It is a busy
                                                multi-lane highway that intersects Reina del mar Avenue at a
                                                traffic signal two short blocks west of the school site. In
                                                addition, there is a small parking area on the west side of the
                                                highway, with enough spaces for eight vehicles.
                                                A SamTrans bus route drops passengers off on the west side
                                                of the highway in the morning and on the east side of the
                                                highway in the afternoon. Some students use this bus route,
                                                but the stop occurs well in advance of the school bell, so they
  Crossing the Cabrillo Highway can present a
                                                are not immediately allowed on campus. The pedestrian walk
     challenge for students arriving by bus.
                                                signal across Cabrillo Highway is short and students must
                                                start immediately and walk quickly to cross the intersection.
                                                The crosswalks are faded and difficult to see.
The short traffic signal for Reina del Mar Avenue can compound the school area congestion. Audit
participants noted there is a long wait time and short proceed time to leave Reina del Mar Avenue. Some
motorists, especially the Pacifica Police, choose to make U-turns when heading southbound despite the
present but faded No U-Turn sign. Some parents expressed concerns about the leg of the intersection that
crosses Reina del Mar Avenue as well, owing to the wide turning radius and lengthy crossing distance.
There is a small parking lot that serves local businesses such as the Vallemar Bar and Grill and P-town coffee.
Some parents discussed the possibility of using this area as an additional parking location. Adjacent to the bus
stop, it might also provide a starting point for a walking school bus.
Recommendations (ID #6)
    ·   Adjust cycle length to allow for walking speed of 2.8 feet per second when crossing Highway 1.
    ·   Enforce no U-turns from southbound to northbound for all vehicles except police. This would help to
        make the intersection more predictable for motorists wishing to turn right from Reina del Mar
        Avenue to Cabrillo Highway and lessen congestion that backs up into the school area.
    ·   Work with Caltrans to consider changing the signal from being timed to detection at the intersection
        so that Reina del Mar Avenue gets a longer green signal when there is significant congestion.
    ·   Stripe high-visibility yellow school zone crosswalks with curb ramps and truncated domes across the
        south and east legs of the intersection.
    ·   Establish a walking school bus that departs from the adjacent parking lot.

Chapter 7

recommended priority level for implementation, and a planning level cost estimate. The priority level is based

7.3.3. Recommended Education, Encouragement and Ridesharing Programs
The most common parent-identified barriers to walking and bicycling to Vallemar Elementary involved traffic
safety and a lack of bicycle and pedestrian infrastructure. In addition to encouraging more students to walk
and bicycle, transportation improvements would increase conditions and safety for students already walking
and bicycling.
Due to the high active transportation mode split from nearby families, the survey suggests that most of the
potential decrease in driving to school would come from students living over a mile away from the school site.
Key programmatic recommendations are listed below. These programs and others are described in more detail
in Section 8.2.
    ·    A School Safety Campaign implemented through a variety of media outlets can reduce the frequency
         of illegal and unsafe driving behavior. Such a campaign would help to address parental concerns
         about traffic and intersection crossings as well as unsafe motorist behavior, and would improve safety
         for students walking and bicycling to school.
    ·    A circulation map would help to alleviate traffic congestion at Vallemar Elementary, symbolized by
         blue dashed lines in Figure 7-6. These circulation maps could be distributed via school newsletters
         and websites.
    ·    Walking school buses can encourage families to walk to school together or can enable busy families
         to coordinate with other parents who already walk their children to school. A walking school bus
         should have a regular route and a parent contact to oversee the program.
    ·    Carpooling can be encouraged with the use of the 511 SchoolPool Tool, a ride matching service that
         locates families with similar commutes and facilitates coordination so they can commute to school
         together. The enrollment map shows that many students are clustered and therefore have
         opportunities to carpool together, though that is not yet a common transportation choice for
         Vallemar Elementary.
    ·    Establishing a park-and-walk would enable parents to drop their children off and either walk the
         last leg of the journey into school or link them with other parents who can complete the journey to
         school with their children. Such a program can disperse congestion through a larger area around the
         school site and demonstrate solidarity with their peers who walk and bike to school.
    ·    Bike rodeos were a consensus recommendation at the parent meeting to teach children to operate
         bicycles safely and confidently. Bicycle rodeos would improve student bicycling skills and would
         likely increase parents' confidence and willingness to allow their children to bike to and from school.




7-12 | Pacifica School District
                                                         District-Wide Action Plan




Figure 7-6: Vallemar Elementary Improvement Plan

8. Pacifica District-Wide Overview and
Recommendations
This chapter presents common issues reported and observed at
the six schools studied as part of this report. Recommendations
addressing these issues are programmatic and may require
coordination between the District, the City of Pacifica, and the
police department. Crossing guards are one example of a
program funded from a variety of sources, with some crossing
guards funded through Parent-Teacher Organizations and
others through the school district.
The continuation of the crossing guard program, along with
other programmatic recommendations, will help to create a              Meetings with parents, school principals
unified sense of safety and order during school commute times.         and staff guide the development of these
The continuation of other existing programs or the                                recommendations.
implementation of new programs may require support from
multiple partner organizations and funding sources. The Safe
Routes to School Action Plan, described in Chapter 9 will help
to coordinate efforts to foster active lifestyles and reduce traffic
congestion in the community.

8.1. District-Wide Issues
Issues common to most schools in Pacifica include:
    ·    Citywide enrollment, which disperses students throughout the city and increases travel distance
    ·    Poor traffic circulation around schools
    ·    High traffic volumes and unsafe motorist behavior around schools
    ·    Hilly topography that presents barriers to walking and bicycling
    ·    Inconvenient crossing opportunities for pedestrians
    ·    Parental concerns about traffic safety and their children's lack of walking and bicycling education

8.1.1. Travel Survey Results
Evaluating Safe Routes to School (SR2S) programs helps implementers identify the existing conditions at
schools and understand parental attitudes about what improvements, programs, or policies are likely to have
the most impact on school commute modes. This data establishes the baseline conditions, for comparison
with data in future years that will indicate the success of programmatic and infrastructure improvements.
Tallies of how students traveled to and from school establish the initial mode split of students at different
schools for comparison with future data. Parent surveys indicate major barriers parents perceive that keep
them from allowing their children to walk, bicycle, carpool, or take transit to and from school. These data can
identify priorities appropriate for a particular context. For example, a school where few students live within a
half-mile would be a good location to promote carpooling and park-and-walks, while if many students live



                                                                               Safe Routes to School Report | 8-1
Chapter 8



within a half-mile of the school, education, encouragement, and infrastructure improvements can increase the
number of students walking and bicycling. Collecting and analyzing school commute data is also an excellent
way to support grant applications and other funding applications, and to track effectiveness of different
programs and policies.
The San Mateo Safe Routes to School program surveyed students and parents in the Pacifica School District to
determine the baseline mode split and to identify key opportunities to promote walking, bicycling, carpooling,
and transit use at each of the six schools in the district. Parent surveys also ask about the factors influence
their school commute mode choice and if they are interested in participating in SR2S programs.

Table 8-1 and Figure 8-2 show the results by school. Sunset Ridge has the highest walking share (16 percent),

Ortega, and Vallemar all have less than 1 percent bicycling, while Ocean Shores had the most (2 percent).
Ingrid B. Lacy had substantially higher rates of transit use than the other schools, likely due to an older
student population.

Parent Survey Results
The parent survey was distributed via an online SurveyMonkey format and available to parents in paper form
at each school. Surveys were offered in English and Spanish. Each family was asked to complete a single
survey. If multiple children from a single family attend school in San Mateo County, the parents were asked a
series of questions for each child individually, as well as a series of questions. In total, 185 surveys were
completed, with responses for 296 individual students.
Parents were asked to report what mode they use to get to and from school depending on the day of the week.
This question format captured families that use multiple modes. Figure 8-3 shows the overall results of the
survey. The parent survey results are similar to those for the student tally, but differed due to the way the
question was asked and the differing survey methodology. The parent survey found that 68 percent of
students are driven alone, 15 percent carpool, and 7 percent take the city bus, while 8 percent walk and 1
percent bicycle.




                                                                                       Safe Routes to School Report | 8-3
Chapter 8

                                                          Figure 8-3: Trip Mode by Day of Week



Parents were also asked how far from school they live, to identify appropriate strategies to promote
alternatives to driving solo to and from school. Overall, 34 percent of students live more than 2 miles from
their schools. Only 20 percent live within a half-mile, indicating that carpooling and park-and-walk
encouragement may be preferred.
This information can be cross-referenced with the reported mode split, to find that 22 percent of students
who live within a quarter-mile of school, as shown in Figure 8-4. As can be expected, rates of driving increase
as students live further from school, and walking rates reduce.

Parents were asked questions about their perceptions of walking and bicycling. In general, parents agreed that
walking and bicycling is fun for their children, important for their children's health, and something they wish
they did more often. Most parents did not feel that their children's school encouraged walking and bicycling.

more often for school trips.

Most parents reported being willing to allow their children to walk or bike to/from school without an adult
beginning in 6th Grade (31 percent). As shown in Figure 8-7, parent's primary concerns include traffic safety
issues, including unsafe intersections, speeding traffic along the route, and too much traffic along the route.
Several parents also felt that `stranger danger' (or personal safety concerns), lack of crossing guards, lack of
bikeways, and distance from school presented barriers to walking and biking.
The survey also asked whether parents would allow their children to walk or bike more often if the concern
was addressed. Barriers whose removal might result in more walking and biking include:
    ·    Too much traffic along route (70 percent)             ·   No adults to walk or bike with (64 percent)
    ·    Walking or biking takes too long (68                  ·   Children's before or after school activities (61
         percent)                                                  percent)
    ·    Driving is more convenient (68 percent)

behaviors if it were easier to coordinate with other parents or kids. In addition, improving transit access and
bicycle and pedestrian education are also opportunities. Parents were less inclined to think that competing for
prizes in contests would result in their driving for fewer trips.

8.2. District-Wide Recommendations
The student hand tally and parent survey indicate substantial opportunities to encourage alternative modes to
for families traveling to and from school. With an overall 70 percent drive alone mode split, encouraging
walking, bicycling, carpooling, and transit use will enable more families to make the choice to not drive alone
to and from school.
The 72 percent of students who live within a quarter-mile of school and 70 percent within a half-mile being
driven alone indicate that many families could walk or bicycle if appropriate physical improvements, policies,
and programs are provided. With 5 percent of students who live within a half-mile of school already bicycling,
there is potential for encouragement to increase the numbers of students who choose to bicycle. There is also
substantial potential for encouraging carpooling and transit use by students who live further than a half-mile
from school. As discussed in Chapter 3, many middle schoolers at Ingrid B. Lacy already take transit.
Parents were generally supportive of walking and bicycling as being fun, important for health, and something
they wish they did more often. However, most parents felt that their children's school did not encourage
walking and bicycling. As the SR2S program is implemented in Pacifica and schools make a concerted effort to


                                                                              Safe Routes to School Report | 8-7
Chapter 8



encourage walking and bicycling, parents should begin to change their opinions on this question. Similarly,
the low participation in Safe Routes programs is due to few programs being available, and lack of advertising
the opportunities that currently exist. The comparison of parents' answers to these questions in the future
will indicate the success of the program at the different schools.
Parents most often identified unsafe intersections, speeding traffic along the route, too much traffic along the
route, and lack of bikeways as being barriers to walking and bicycling, indicating a need for infrastructure
improvements and suggested route maps that highlight lower-traffic streets and recommended street
crossings. However, the other top barriers represent more perception-based issues that can be addressed
through programs and encouragement (`stranger danger', lack of crossing guards).
Top programmatic recommendations include coordination with other parents and children, potentially
through use and promotion of the 511 SchoolPool RideMatching tool and organizing Walking School Buses
and Bike Trains. Working with SamTrans to provide bussing on the school bell schedules, providing transit
education to students, and working with drivers to improve bussing are likely to encourage more students
traveling via transit. Finally, walking and bicycling education was a high priority for parents and is a key
component of SR2S programs.

8.3. District-Wide Program Guide
The recommended programs below address these common issues. The recommendations address the other "4
E's" of Safe Routes to School (Education, Encouragement, Enforcement, and Evaluation). The San Mateo
County Safe Routes to School Program Guide provides additional information about the recommended
programs and includes additional potential encouragement and educational programs. The program is
available at http://www.smcoe.k12.ca.us/sr2s

                                            8.3.1.       Education Programs

                                            School Safety Campaign
                                            District-wide, parents and school administrators expressed
                                            concern about unsafe motorist behavior. Such behavior, reported
                                            and observed, includes illegal turning movements, loading in the
                                            travel lane, illegal parking and speeding.
                                            A School Safety Campaign implemented through a variety of
                                            media outlets can reduce the frequency of illegal and unsafe
                                            driving behavior. An example safety campaign is "Street Smarts",
                                            which communities throughout the San Francisco Bay Area have
                                            implemented with great success. The Street Smarts campaign
                                            provides implementing agencies with customizable materials
                                            about traffic safety for radio, TV, classrooms, outdoor media and
                                            much more. These high quality materials show the community
  The StreetSmarts marketing campaign       that the District and City value safe school commuting.
   educates students, parents, and other    The district may consider working with the City to develop or
     drivers about how to travel safely.    purchase a similar campaign.


8-8 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                    District-Wide Action Plan


8.3.2. Encouragement Programs

School Specific Circulation Maps
School related traffic congestion is common at most schools in the district. Congestion typically occurs in
specific locations and could be reduced if parents choose alternative routes to school.
Where an alternative circulation plan would help to alleviate traffic congestion at schools in Pacifica, they are
symbolized by blue dashed lines in the improvement plans of this report. These may be modified to achieve
maximum effectiveness and developed for other schools in coordination with the city.
After review by the District, administration, and parents from the affected school, the District should consider
developing circulation maps for distribution via school newsletters and websites. The circulation map should
be graphically simple and recommend routes for motorists and pedestrians, in addition to locations of on- and
off-site loading zones, crossing guards and traffic signals. The District and affected school should review the
circulation plan annually and modify accordingly.

SchoolPool
SchoolPool is a Ride Matching service that helps families coordinate with each other to commute to school
together by matching parents with similar commutes. The interactive website is offered by 511.org, a program
of the Metropolitan Transportation Commission (MTC). Fliers and brochures are available to download and
distribute to parents to promote the program, and schools can offer incentives for parents who sign up.
Such a program may reduce school related congestion, particularly at schools where families live within close
proximity of school but do not feel comfortable walking to school. This scenario is thought to play out at
many schools due to the amount of congestion relative to the small enrollment areas.
The Peninsula Congestion Relief Alliance provides commuter incentives to parents who carpool and
Metropolitan Transportation Commission provides matching services at the websites below.
http://www.commute.org
http://www.schoolpool.511.org

Park and Walk
Pacifica does not have neighborhood schools; students are dispersed throughout the city and may live a
significant distance away from their schools. This and the city's hilly topography create barriers to walking
and bicycling. Park and Walk programs designate meeting points where parents can drop their children off
and either walk the last leg of the journey into school or link them with other parents who can complete the
journey to school with their children. Such a program can disperse congestion through a larger area around
the school site and demonstrate solidarity with their peers who walk and bike to school. Most schools in
Pacifica have nearby sites that could serve as Park and Walk locations.




                                                                               Safe Routes to School Report | 8-9
Chapter 8



8.3.3. Enforcement Programs

                                                 Crossing Guard Program
                                                 Crossing guards serve a critical function to ensure safe school
                                                 crossings and acting as ad-hoc traffic controllers. While some
                                                 school crossing guards are funded from the Pacifica School
                                                 District, others are funded through Parent-Teacher
                                                 Organizations.
                                                 The District should ensure that a crossing guard program is
                                                 provided for every future school year. Crossing guards have
                                                 proven to be essential for pedestrian safety and orderly traffic
  A crossing guard helps students cross a busy   operations and extremely popular among parents. Additional
      street near Sunset Ridge Elementary.       crossing guards may be beneficial for some schools in Pacifica.

Parent & Student Valet
School loading areas often become congested and disorderly without supervision. At the same time, expecting
teachers or school staff to manage all the loading zones of a school can be infeasible. Training parent and
student volunteers to manage traffic and assist in loading can significantly improve safety and the traffic flow
around schools.
Under a valet program, parents and students are trained in how to keep traffic moving in a loading zone, how
to properly assist students in and out of vehicles, and how to properly discourage unsafe or undesirable habits
in the loading zone. Volunteers are often outfitted with florescent vests to increase their visibility and denote
their role as a school representative.
While valet duties are not suitable for young children, students in the 4th grade and above can act effectively
as a valet program when under adult supervision. Such programs also provide responsibilities and valuable
character-building opportunities for students.

8.3.4. Evaluation Programs

Student Hand Tallies and Parent Surveys
Collecting and analyzing school commute data is an excellent way to support grant applications and other
funding applications. Student Hand Tallies ask students to raise their hands in response to the commute mode
they use to get to and from school. Typically the teacher administers the survey, which only takes a few
minutes. Parent surveys also ask how students get to and from school, but since the parent completes the
questionnaire, parents are also asked about the factors that influence their school commute mode choice and if
they are interested in participating in SR2S programs.
The National Center for Safe Routes to School provides Student Hand Tally and Parent Survey forms and will
enter the data from those forms. This can be a cost effective way to understand how families get to and from
school and the reasons for their mode choice. The District should consider administrating one or both types of
surveys. More information about survey administration and collection can be found at:
http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/data-central/data-collection-forms


8-10 | Pacifica School District
                                                                                                               District-Wide Action Plan




9.           District-Wide Action Plan
1. Form a Safe Routes to School Taskforce
Most successful Safe Routes to School programs are directed by a Taskforce that identifies improvements to
school access points and circulation. The Taskforce should be a partnership from a variety of organizations
and agencies such as:
        ·    District/school staff and administration                                  ·     City planners and engineers
        ·    Parent/Teacher                 Association                                ·     Community representatives such as
             representatives                                                                 bicycle/pedestrian advocates and non-
        ·    Police Department representation                                                profit organizations with a goal of a
                                                                                             sustainable community

These partners serve to represent and address the four "E's" of Safe Route to School: Education,
Encouragement, Enforcement and Evaluation. The Palo Alto SR2S Taskforce serves as a successful example.
Formed by community members in 2004, the Palo Alto SR2S Taskforce is made up of a multi-disciplined
partnership of organizations and agencies that has leveraged resources from throughout the community to
create a sustainable SR2S program.

2. Prioritize Programs
District administration should use the information contained in this report, and the accompanying County of
San Mateo Safe Routes to School Tool Box, to begin a prioritization process for projects deemed worthy. This
process may begin with student and parent surveys, followed by consultation with City staff, Police
Department staff, and other key stakeholders.

3. Identify Funding Sources
There are numerous funding sources for both Safe Routes to School infrastructure improvements and
programs. Most of sources are competitive and typically award applicants that demonstrate existing and
ongoing support for Safe Routes to School. Some typical funding sources are listed below. 7
        ·    State and Federal Safe Routes to School Grant The typical state application due date is in March
             and applicants may use 10% of funds for programs. The typical federal application due date is in July
             and applicants may use funds for infrastructure projects or programs.
        ·    Bicycle Transportation Account, typical application due in March and funds bicycle facilities.
        ·    Office of Traffic Safety has in the past provided mini grants for helmet giveaways and other
             programs.

4. Identify School Champions
School Champions are typically volunteer parents or community members that lead and organize SR2S
programs. Potential candidates may be people that are already passionate about walking and bicycling or
traffic issues. Ideal candidates are well connected within their community and enjoy organizing initiatives.
Potential Champion duties may include organizing walking school buses and helping organize school events.


7   Additional information about these sources can be found at: http://www.dot.ca.gov/hq/LocalPrograms/


                                                                                                          Safe Routes to School Report | 9-1
Chapter 9


This page left intentionally blank




9-2 | Pacifica School District
                                                    Example Engineering Devices and Cost Assumptions




Appendix A. Example Engineering Devices and Cost
            Assumptions
Design of the physical environment around schools is integral to a comprehensive Safe Routes to School
Program that ensures walking, biking, and other "green" forms of travel are convenient and safe. The
engineering improvements presented in this report follow the standards set forth by the California
Department of Transportation (Caltrans). Most of the proposed signage and striping improvements are
relatively simple and cost effective to install when compared to more intensive engineering devices, such as
curb extensions and paths. Planning level construction cost estimates for the recommendations are intended
to inform the reader and are provided for informational purposes only. Costs may change as recommendations
are implemented.

In accordance with Caltrans and industry standard terms, "shall" "should" or "may" are used to denote when
to install the example engineering devices. Shall is used when an improvement is required to be installed
under pre-defined conditions. May is used when an improvement installation is optional under pre-defined
conditions. Should is used when an improvement supports the effectiveness of required improvements.




                                                                           Safe Routes to School Report | A-1
Appendix A


Signage
School related signage warns motorists of a school zone or crosswalk and regulates their movements to ensure
the safest conditions possible for pedestrians and bicyclists. Warning signs and regulatory signs with posts
typically cost around $400 and $200 each, respectively.

A.1.1.1. Warning Signs
       Assembly A                       Assembly B                       Assembly D                   In-Pavement Sign




 May be installed up to 500         Shall be installed at an      Shall be installed 100 feet in       May be installed in an
 feet in advance of a school.       uncontrolled crosswalk        advance of an uncontrolled          uncontrolled crosswalk.
                                        (no stop sign).                    crosswalk.


A.1.1.2. Regulatory Signs
         No Turn                         No U-Turn                       Loading Zone                  School Speed Limit




No Right and Left Turn signs     No U-Turn signs are typically     Loading zones designate a pick     May be installed up to 500
are typically used to improve     used to reduce conflicts with     up/drop off location and may      feet in advance of a school
circulation and reduce queue       pedestrians and motorists.        include a plaque allowing        and is installed with a time
           lengths.                                               parking during off-loading times.    sensitive flashing beacon.
                                                                                                        Engineers determine the
                                                                                                              posted speed.




A-2 | Pacifica School District
                                                         Example Engineering Devices and Cost Assumptions



Striping
School related striping includes crosswalks and curb colors. Bicycle lane striping and markings can be also
considered school related. Bicycle-related striping improvements, however, were not recommended in this
report. Thermoplastic is recommended for striping improvements. Thermoplastic costs about $2 per square
foot, equating to $200 to $400 for crosswalk installation.

A.1.1.3. Crosswalks
Crosswalks connect one corner of a street to the opposite side and do not have to be marked with paint or
thermoplastic unless where no corner exists (mid-block crosswalk). In California, yellow crosswalks can be
used on roadways where students frequently cross. Caltrans standard is for all crosswalks contiguous to
schools to be yellow. Crosswalk may also be yellow if within 600 feet of a school or school grounds. White
crosswalks are used in all other areas.
    High Visibility Crosswalk                  Transverse Crosswalk                     Lighted Crosswalk




    High visibility crosswalks have      Transverse crosswalks have latitudinal    Pedestrian activated lights may be
   longitudinal and latitudinal lines.                   lines.                     installed on a sign and/or in the
                                                                                               pavement.


A.1.1.4. Curb Colors
School Loading Zone curbs are white.

Freight/Bus Loading Zone curbs are yellow.
Accessible curbside parking curbs are blue.

No Parking Zone curbs are red.




                                                                                  Safe Routes to School Report | A-3
Appendix A


Curb Extensions
There are a range of devices that work to reduce motorist speeds. This report recommends curb extensions in
many locations, most of which are skewed intersections (where streets do not intersect at 90 degree angles).
Curb extensions are recommended where the radius of a corner could be increased to reduce the speed of
turning vehicles, discourage U-turns, and/or reduce crosswalk distance. The cost of installing a curb
extension depends of several circumstances including the presence of drainage utilities. On average, curb
extensions typically cost around $30,000 each to install.
                                               Curb Extension




                                  Curb extensions reduce the width of a roadway.

More than 2 miles                                                         0%             0%           87%       0%                    13%                  0%               0%
Grand Total                                                             18%              5%          59%        0%                     6%                 13%               0%

                                           Attorney
                      115 An g elit a Av en ue · Pacifica, C A 94044
                                  ph/fax 650-359-4257
                                hbohner@earthlink.net




                                        sent by email to
                           heidemarie.carle@dot.ca.gov April 9, 2013



Ms. Heidemarie Carle
Public Records Act Coordinator
Caltrans District 4
111 Grand Ave.,
Oakland, CA 94612


       Re:     Request under California Public Records Act


Dear Heidi:


        Pursuant to the California Public Records Act please provide me the opportunity to
inspect and copy certain documents which are identified below. I assume that there will be no
charge for responding to my request. If I am incorrect please advise me before incurring costs.

      My request relates to Caltrans' Draft Environmental Impact Report / Environmental
Assessment for State Route 1 / Calera Parkway / Highway 1 Widening Project San Mateo
County, California 04-SM-1 / PM 41.7/43.0 / EA 04-254600. (The DEIR)

        Prior to issuing the DEIR Caltrans held public meetings in Pacifica concerning their
proposed project. I am attaching a document titled "State Route 1/Calera Parkway Project
Public Information Meeting June 22, 2010" (Hwy-1-Calera_Public_Info_Mtg_6-22-
10_v15_web.pdf). At the meeting Caltrans representatives explained that they had use computer
simulations to arrive at many of their conclusions about predicted traffic flow. For example,
computer simulations are mentioned at pages 11 and 12 of 47.

        Please provide me all computer simulations concerning or related to the Calera Parkway
project. Of course, I do not have the computer software to run the program which Caltrans used,
which I believe is called VISSIM. However, I assume that videos have been made of the
simulation runs and I am requesting copies of those videos.

        Also please provide me any written documents which concern or relate to the simulations
and the results of those computer runs including documents that summarize or discuss the results
of the simulations.


Page 1 of 2
       Thank you for your cooperation.



Sincerely,




Hal Bohner

Acknowledgments


U.S. PIRG Education Fund and Frontier Group sincerely thank Nick Donohue and David Goldberg
of Transportation for America; Darnell Grisby of the American Public Transportation Association;
Todd Litman of the Victoria Transport Policy Institute; Danny Katz of CoPIRG Foundation; Kirstie
Pecci of MASSPIRG Education Fund; Adie Tomer of the Brookings Institution; Serena Unrein of
Arizona PIRG Education Fund; Clark Williams-Derry of the Sightline Institute, and others for
their review of drafts of this document, as well as for their insights and suggestions. Thanks also
to Clark Williams-Derry and to Bruce Speight of WISPIRG Foundation for their contributions
to this paper. The authors sincerely thank Tom Van Heeke of Frontier Group for his research as-
sistance and Elizabeth Ridlington of Frontier Group for her editorial assistance.

U.S. PIRG Education Fund and Frontier Group thank the Rockefeller Foundation for making this
report possible.

The authors bear responsibility for any factual errors. The recommendations are those of U.S. PIRG
Education Fund. The views expressed in this report are those of the authors and do not necessarily
reflect the views of our funders or those who provided review.

   2013 U.S. PIRG Education Fund. Some Rights Reserved. This work is licensed under a Creative
Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives 3.0 Unported License. To view the terms
of this license, visit creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/3.0.

With public debate around important issues often dominated by special interests pursuing their own
narrow agendas, U.S. PIRG Education Fund offers an independent voice that works on behalf of the
public interest. U.S. PIRG Education Fund, a 501(c)(3) organization, works to protect consumers
and promote good government. We investigate problems, craft solutions, educate the public and
offer Americans meaningful opportunities for civic participation. For more information, please
visit our website at www.uspirgedfund.org.

Frontier Group conducts independent research and policy analysis to support a cleaner, healthier
and more democratic society. Our mission is to inject accurate information and compelling ideas
into public policy debates at the local, state and federal levels. For more information about Frontier
Group, please visit www.frontiergroup.org.

                                                                                    The End of the Driving Boom 15
                     Implications of Changing Driving Trends:
                     The View from the Pacific Northwest
                     By Clark Williams-Derry, Sightline Institute



                     T  he Pacific Northwest was well ahead of the curve in the national trend toward
                        reduced driving and fuel consumption. Out here in the land of mist and mountains,
                     gasoline consumption plateaued way back in 1999.43 (See Figure 6.) Total vehicle
                     travel on Washington and Oregon's state highways flattened out in 2002.44 And, after
                     factoring in population growth, gas consumption per resident in the two states has
                     now fallen to its lowest level since 1964--a dramatic decline, though one that has
                     received surprisingly little attention from the region's policy-makers.45


                     Figure 6. Gasoline Consumption in Oregon and Washington46




                       Because driving slumped here before it did in the rest of the nation, we're among
                     the first to confront the fiscal fallout of stagnating gas tax revenues.
                       Like many states across the country, Washington and Oregon financed highway
                     expansion by floating bonds, intending to pay for highway construction by tapping




16 A New Direction
into ever-growing fuel tax collections anticipated in the future. But flat-lining gas
tax receipts have driven the region's transportation officials into a panic. Oregon
recently announced that flat or declining revenue from the gasoline tax, coupled
with rising debt payments, decreased federal funding, and increasing construction
costs, could force deep cuts in the state's transportation budget in the next several
years.47
    Washington is in even worse shape. After years of denial, the state recently slashed
long-term revenue forecasts by billions of dollars.48 But since the state back-loaded
interest payments on many of its highway bonds, its debt obligations will rise even
if fuel tax receipts dip. Within just a few years, more than 70 percent of the state's
gas tax receipts will go to pay off debts on projects that have already been com-
pleted--leaving precious little gas tax revenue for maintenance of existing roads,
let alone new construction.49
    Both Oregon and Washington have flirted with tolling to finance new high-
ways--gambling that drivers who are reluctant to pay for expensive gas will prove
willing to pay costly tolls instead. Washington took a foray into toll-financed con-
struction on the Tacoma Narrows Bridge. But the fiscal outlook for the project is
grim. Traffic across the new span has fallen,50 rather than growing as anticipated,51
leaving a widening gap between toll collections and the rising payments for con-
struction debt. At the same time, a high-occupancy toll (HOT) lane pilot project
southeast of Seattle has generated far less revenue than hoped.52 And the state has
been forced to slash its projected toll revenue from a tunnel project under downtown
Seattle; the state now expects to raise at most $200 million in tolls53 towards a $4
billion project.54
    In short, Washington's and Oregon's transportation agencies are speeding towards
a fiscal cliff of their own making. If anything, they're stepping on the accelerator
by continuing to move forward with costly megaprojects--wider highways, bigger
bridges and a budget-busting tunnel--that the states don't need and can't afford.
    One obvious solution to the Northwest's transportation finance crisis is to cancel,
or at least downsize, some of these megaprojects. (Who needs bigger highways if
traffic isn't growing?) Yet so far, transportation officials see flat-lining traffic simply
as the cause of a funding shortfall, rather than an opportunity to rethink the region's
road construction priorities.
    It took the Northwest states nearly a decade to accept that a sea change in car
travel trends had sown the seeds of a transportation revenue crisis. Let's hope it
doesn't take another decade to accept that the best solution to that crisis is to scale
back our highway-building ambitions, so that they match both our financial means
and our newly restrained driving habits.

Sightline Institute is an independent, nonprofit research and communications center based in
Seattle, dedicated to making the Pacific Northwest a global model of sustainability --strong
communities, a green economy and a healthy environment.
